818<article>

821

822 <h1>

823Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma Treatment (PDQ)Health Professional Version</h1>

824

825 <div id="cgvBody">

826

827 <div class="summary-sections">

828

829 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

830

831 <h6>

832On This Page</h6>

833

834 <ul>

835

836 <li>

837<a href="#_1">

838General Information About Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

839</li>

840

841 <li>

843Cellular Classification for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

844</li>

845

848Stage Information for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

849</li>

850

854</li>

858Special Considerations for the Treatment of Children With Cancer</a>

859</li>

864</li>

886 <div class="accordion">

887

888

889

890 <section id="_1">

891

892 <h2>

893General Information About Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</h2>

894

895 <div id="_section_1" class="pdq-sections">

896<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

897<h6>

898In This Section</h6>

899<ul>

900<li>

901<a href="#_583_toc">

902Incidence</a>

903</li>

904<li>

905<a href="#_778_toc">

906Risk Factors</a>

907</li>

908<li>

909<a href="#_586_toc">

910Prognostic Factors<ul>

911<li>

912<a href="#_1882_toc">

913Age</a>

914</li>

915<li>

916<a href="#_1888_toc">

917Site of origin</a>

918</li>

919<li>

920<a href="#_1890_toc">

921Tumor size</a>

922</li>

923<li>

924<a href="#_1892_toc">

925Resectability</a>

926</li>

927<li>

928<a href="#_1894_toc">

929Histopathological subtype</a>

930</li>

931<li>

932<a href="#_1897_toc">

933<em class="gene-name">

934PAX3</em>

935::<em class="gene-name">

936FOXO1</em>

937 or <em class="gene-name">

938PAX7</em>

939::<em class="gene-name">

940FOXO1</em>

941 gene fusion status</a>

942</li>

943<li>

944<a href="#_1899_toc">

945Metastases at diagnosis</a>

946</li>

947<li>

948<a href="#_1901_toc">

949Lymph node involvement at diagnosis</a>

950</li>

951<li>

952<a href="#_1904_toc">

953Biological characteristics</a>

954</li>

955<li>

956<a href="#_1906_toc">

957Response to therapy</a>

958</li>

959<li>

960<a href="#_2098_toc">

961Circulating tumor DNA and RNA</a>

962</li>

963</ul>

964</a>

965</li>

966</ul>

967</nav>

968<div class="pdq-hp-patient-toggle">

969<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/patient/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq">

970Go to Patient Version</a>

971</div>

972<p id="_170" tabindex="-1">

973Continual improvements in survival have been achieved for children and adolescents with cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9741</a>

975] Between 1975 and 2020, childhood cancer mortality decreased by more than 50%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9761</a>

977-<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

9783</a>

979] Between 1975 and 2017, the 5-year relative survival rate for patients with rhabdomyosarcoma increased from 53% to 71% for children younger than 15 years and from 30% to 52% for adolescents aged 15 to 19 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9801</a>

981,<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9822</a>

983] In more recent years, improvements in outcome have plateaued.</p>

984<p id="_1880" tabindex="-1">

985Childhood and adolescent cancer survivors require close monitoring because side effects of cancer and its therapy may persist or develop months to years later. For specific information about the incidence, type, and monitoring of late effects in childhood and adolescent cancer survivors, see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq">

986Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer</a>

987.</p>

988<section id="_583">

989<h3 id="_583_toc">

990Incidence</h3>

991<p id="_584" tabindex="-1">

992Childhood rhabdomyosarcoma is a soft tissue malignant tumor of mesenchymal

993origin. It accounts for approximately 2.7% of cancer cases among children aged 0

994to 14 years and 1.4% of the cases among adolescents and young adults aged 15 to 19

995years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9962</a>

997] The incidence is 4.6 cases per 1 million children younger than 20 years, which translates into about 350 new cases per year. Fifty percent of these cases are seen in the first decade of life.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9982</a>

999,<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

10004</a>

1001]</p>

1002<p id="_2080" tabindex="-1">

1003The 2020 World Health Organization classification distinguishes four histological subtypes of rhabdomyosarcoma, including embryonal, alveolar, spindle cell/sclerosing, and pleomorphic.[<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

10045</a>

1005] While these subtypes classify rhabdomyosarcoma into prognostically useful histological categories, <em class="gene-name">

1006FOXO1</em>

1007 gene fusions uniquely occur in alveolar histology tumors; however, not all tumors that have been classified as alveolar histology have a <em class="gene-name">

1008FOXO1</em>

1009 fusion. Molecular characterization has replaced histopathological assessment for treatment risk assignment. Male patients have a higher incidence of embryonal tumors, and Black patients have a slightly higher incidence of alveolar tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

10104</a>

1011] For more information, see the sections on <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_13">

1012Cellular Classification for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

1013 and <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_788">

1014Molecular Characteristics of Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

1015.</p>

1016<p id="_613" tabindex="-1">

1017Incidence may depend on the histological subtype of rhabdomyosarcoma, as follows:</p>

1018<div class="pdq-content-list">

1019<ul id="_614">

1020<li>

1021<strong>

1022Embryonal:</strong>

1023 Patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma are predominantly male (male-to-female ratio, 1.5). The peak incidence is in children between the ages of 0 and 4 years, with approximately 4 cases per 1 million children. The incidence rate is lower in adolescents, with approximately 1.5 cases per 1 million adolescents. This subtype constitutes 57% of patients in the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program database.[<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

10244</a>

1025] </li>

1026<li>

1027<strong>

1028Alveolar:</strong>

1029 The incidence of alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma does not vary by sex and is constant from ages 0 to 19 years, with approximately 1 case per 1 million children and adolescents. This subtype constitutes 23% of patients in the SEER database.[<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

10304</a>

1031]</li>

1032<li>

1033<strong>

1034Spindle cell/sclerosing:</strong>

1035 Spindle cell and sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma are considered in the same diagnostic category. This uncommon variant accounts for 3% to 10% of all cases.[<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

10365</a>

1037]</li>

1038<li>

1039<strong>

1040Pleomorphic:</strong>

1041 Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is a high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma seen in adults. Childhood cases are considered to be rhabdomyosarcoma with diffuse anaplasia.[<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

10425</a>

1043]</li>

1044</ul>

1045</div>

1046<p id="_608" tabindex="-1">

1047Rhabdomyosarcoma may occur anywhere in the body. The most common primary sites include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

10486</a>

1049,<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

10507</a>

1051]</p>

1052<div class="pdq-content-list">

1053<ul id="_775">

1054<li>

1055Head and neck region (parameningeal) (approximately 25%).</li>

1056<li>

1057Genitourinary

1058tract (approximately 31%).</li>

1059<li>

1060Extremities (approximately 13%). Within extremity tumors, tumors of the hand and foot occur more often in older patients and usually have an alveolar histology.[<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

10618</a>

1062] </li>

1063</ul>

1064</div>

1065<p id="_776" tabindex="-1">

1066Other less common primary sites include the

1067trunk, chest wall, perineal/anal region, and abdomen, including the retroperitoneum and

1068biliary tract.[<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

10697</a>

1070]</p>

1071</section>

1072<section id="_778">

1073<h3 id="_778_toc">

1074Risk Factors</h3>

1075<p id="_585" tabindex="-1">

1076Most cases of rhabdomyosarcoma occur sporadically, with no

1077recognized predisposing risk factor. </p>

1078<p id="_2044" tabindex="-1">

1079 Predisposition factors reported for rhabdomyosarcoma include the following:</p>

1080<div class="pdq-content-list">

1081<ul id="_763">

1082<li>

1083Genetic factors:<div class="pdq-content-list">

1084<ul id="_766" class="list-dash">

1085<li>

1086Li-Fraumeni

1087cancer susceptibility syndrome (with germline <em class="gene-name">

1088TP53</em>

1089 mutations).[<a href="#cit/section_1.9">

10909</a>

1091-<a href="#cit/section_1.11">

109211</a>

1093]</li>

1094<li>

1095<em class="gene-name">

1096DICER1</em>

1097 syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.12">

109812</a>

1099,<a href="#cit/section_1.13">

110013</a>

1101]</li>

1102<li>

1103Neurofibromatosis type I (NF1).[<a href="#cit/section_1.14">

110414</a>

1105,<a href="#cit/section_1.15">

110615</a>

1107]</li>

1108<li>

1109Costello syndrome (with germline <em class="gene-name">

1110HRAS</em>

1111 mutations).[<a href="#cit/section_1.16">

111216</a>

1113-<a href="#cit/section_1.19">

111419</a>

1115]</li>

1116<li>

1117Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (more commonly associated with Wilms

1118tumor and hepatoblastoma).[<a href="#cit/section_1.20">

111920</a>

1120,<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

112121</a>

1122]</li>

1123<li>

1124Noonan syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.19">

112519</a>

1126,<a href="#cit/section_1.22">

112722</a>

1128,<a href="#cit/section_1.23">

112923</a>

1130]</li>

1131</ul>

1132</div>

1133</li>

1134<li>

1135High birth weight and large size for gestational age are associated with an increased incidence of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.24">

113624</a>

1137]</li>

1138</ul>

1139</div>

1140<p id="_2052" tabindex="-1">

1141The Children's Oncology Group (COG) performed retrospective exome sequencing on germline DNA to determine the prevalence of 63 autosomal dominant cancer-predisposing genes in 615 patients with newly diagnosed rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.25">

114225</a>

1143] They identified germline cancer-predisposition variants in 45 patients with rhabdomyosarcoma (7.3%; all <em class="gene-name">

1144FOXO1</em>

1145 fusion negative) across 15 autosomal dominant genes. Specifically, 73.3% of the predisposition variants were found in predisposition syndrome genes previously associated with pediatric rhabdomyosarcoma risk, such as Li-Fraumeni syndrome (<em class="gene-name">

1146TP53</em>

1147, n = 11) and NF1 (<em class="gene-name">

1148NF1</em>

1149, n = 9). Notably, five patients had well-described oncogenic missense variants in <em class="gene-name">

1150HRAS</em>

1151 (p.G12V and p.G12S) associated with Costello syndrome, and two patients each had mutations in <em class="gene-name">

1152DICER1</em>

1153 and <em class="gene-name">

1154CBL</em>

1155, respectively. Germline variants were more frequent in patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma than in those with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma (10% vs. 3%, <em>

1156P</em>

1157 = .02), but all of the patients with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma were <em class="gene-name">

1158FOXO1</em>

1159 negative, and no germline variants were identified in patients with <em class="gene-name">

1160FOXO1</em>

1161 translocations. Although patients with a cancer-predisposition variant tended to be younger at diagnosis (<em>

1162P</em>

1163 = .00099), 40% of germline variants were identified in patients older than 3 years.</p>

1164</section>

1165<section id="_586">

1166<h3 id="_586_toc">

1167Prognostic Factors</h3>

1168<p id="_615" tabindex="-1">

1169Rhabdomyosarcoma is usually curable in children with localized disease who

1170receive combined-modality therapy, with more than 70% of patients surviving 5 years after

1171diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

11726</a>

1173,<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

11747</a>

1175,<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

117626</a>

1177] Relapses are uncommon in patients who were alive and event free at 5 years, with a 10-year late-event rate of 9%. Relapses are more common in patients who have unresectable disease, tumor in an unfavorable site at diagnosis, or metastatic disease at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.27">

117827</a>

1179]</p>

1180<p id="_587" tabindex="-1">

1181The prognosis for children or adolescents with rhabdomyosarcoma is related to

1182 many clinical and biological factors, including the following:</p>

1183<div class="pdq-content-list">

1184<ul id="_1881">

1185<li>

1186<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1882">

1187Age</a>

1188.</li>

1189<li>

1190<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1888">

1191Site of origin</a>

1192.</li>

1193<li>

1194<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1890">

1195Tumor size</a>

1196.</li>

1197<li>

1198<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1892">

1199Resectability</a>

1200.</li>

1201<li>

1202<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1894">

1203Histopathological subtype</a>

1204.</li>

1205<li>

1206<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1897">

1207<em class="gene-name">

1208PAX3</em>

1209::<em class="gene-name">

1210FOXO1</em>

1211 or <em class="gene-name">

1212PAX7</em>

1213::<em class="gene-name">

1214FOXO1</em>

1215 gene fusion status</a>

1216.</li>

1217<li>

1218<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1899">

1219Metastases at diagnosis</a>

1220.</li>

1221<li>

1222<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1901">

1223Lymph node involvement at diagnosis</a>

1224.</li>

1225<li>

1226<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1904">

1227Biological characteristics</a>

1228.</li>

1229<li>

1230<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1906">

1231Response to therapy</a>

1232.</li>

1233<li>

1234<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_2098">

1235Circulating tumor DNA and RNA</a>

1236.</li>

1237</ul>

1238</div>

1239<p id="_590" tabindex="-1">

1240Because treatment and prognosis partly depend on the histology and molecular characterization of the tumor,

1241it is necessary that the tumor tissue be reviewed by expert pathologists with

1242experience in the evaluation and diagnosis of tumors in children.

1243Typically, accurate diagnosis requires additional molecular characterization. The diversity of primary sites, the distinctive surgical and

1244radiation therapy treatments for each primary site, and the subsequent

1245site-specific rehabilitation underscore the importance of treating children

1246with rhabdomyosarcoma in medical centers with appropriate experience in all

1247therapeutic modalities.

1248</p>

1249<section id="_1882">

1250<h4 id="_1882_toc">

1251Age</h4>

1252<p id="_1883" tabindex="-1">

1253Children aged 1 to 9 years have the best prognosis, while those younger than 1 year and older than 10 years fare less well. In Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study Group (IRSG) and COG trials, the 5-year failure-free survival (FFS) rate was 57% for patients younger than 1 year, 81% for patients aged 1 to 9 years, and 68% for patients older than 10 years. The 5-year overall survival (OS) rates were 76% for patients younger than 1 year, 87% for patients aged 1 to 9 years, and 76% for patients older than 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

125428</a>

1255] Historical data show that adults have fared less well than children (5-year OS rates, 27% &#177; 1.4% vs. 61% &#177; 1.4%; <em>

1256P</em>

1257 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_1.29">

125829</a>

1259-<a href="#cit/section_1.32">

126032</a>

1261]</p>

1262<div class="pdq-content-list">

1263<ul id="_1884">

1264<li>

1265<strong>

1266Young age:</strong>

1267 Infants tend to do poorly, often because of treatment modifications to reduce toxicity. Typically, chemotherapy doses are reduced by 50% on the basis of reports that infants have higher death rates related to chemotherapy toxicity when compared with older patients; therefore, young patients may be underdosed.[<a href="#cit/section_1.33">

126833</a>

1269] In addition, infants younger than 1 year are less likely to receive radiation therapy for local control because of the high incidence of late effects in this age group.[<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

127026</a>

1271,<a href="#cit/section_1.34">

127234</a>

1273,<a href="#cit/section_1.35">

127435</a>

1275] <p id="_1885" tabindex="-1">

1276The 5-year FFS rate was 67% for infants, compared with 81% in a matched group of older patients treated by the COG.[<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

127728</a>

1278,<a href="#cit/section_1.36">

127936</a>

1280] This inferior FFS rate was largely the result of a relatively high rate of local failure. </p>

1281<p id="_1886" tabindex="-1">

1282In another retrospective study of 126 patients (aged &#8804;24 months) who were enrolled on the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075582">

1283ARST0331 (NCT00075582)</a>

1284 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00354835">

1285ARST0531 (NCT00354835)</a>

1286 trials, the 5-year local failure rate was 24%, the 5-year event-free survival (EFS) rate was 68.3%, and the OS rate was 81.9%. Forty-three percent of the patients had an individualized local therapy plan that more frequently omitted radiation therapy. These patients had inferior local control and EFS rates.[<a href="#cit/section_1.36">

128736</a>

1288]</p>

1289<p id="_1853" tabindex="-1">

1290Members of the Cooperative Weichteilsarkom Studiengruppe (CWS) reviewed 155 patients with rhabdomyosarcoma presenting from birth to age 12 months; 144 patients had localized disease; 11 patients had metastases; and 32 patients presented with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma pathology. The following results were reported:[<a href="#cit/section_1.37">

129137</a>

1292][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1293Level of evidence C1</a>

1294]</p>

1295<div class="pdq-content-list">

1296<ul id="_1887">

1297<li>

1298Of the 144 patients with localized disease, 129 had a complete response.</li>

1299<li>

1300Fifty-one infants had a recurrence of their disease; 63% of patients with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma had a relapse, and 28% of patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma had a relapse.</li>

1301<li>

1302The 5-year OS rates were 69% for patients with localized disease, 14% for patients with metastatic disease, and 41% for patients with relapsed disease.</li>

1303</ul>

1304</div>

1305<p id="_2012" tabindex="-1">

1306A retrospective analysis of five consecutive studies from the CWS group examined infants and older children with localized rhabdomyosarcoma of the female genitourinary tract.[<a href="#cit/section_1.38">

130738</a>

1308] Among 67 patients treated from 1981 to 2019, age of 12 months or younger at diagnosis was the only significant negative prognostic factor that influenced EFS.</p>

1309<p id="_2051" tabindex="-1">

1310The European Paediatric Soft Tissue Sarcoma Study Group (EpSSG) enrolled 490 children younger than 36 months in their prospective RMS2005 study. The study included 110 patients younger than 12 months and 380 patients aged 12 to 36 months. Chemotherapy was given according to the risk group. Radiation therapy (22% received brachytherapy) was administered to 33.6% of the infants and 63.5% of the children aged 12 to 36 months. The 5-year OS rate was 88.4% for the infants, which was significantly better than the 72.5% rate observed in children aged 12 to 36 months. The treatment protocol in this trial, which used an increased application of adequate local therapy, may have contributed to these improved outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_1.39">

131139</a>

1312][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1313Level of evidence B4</a>

1314]</p>

1315<p id="_2047" tabindex="-1">

1316The EpSSG analyzed neonates with congenital rhabdomyosarcoma, which they defined as infants younger than 2 months at diagnosis who were enrolled in EpSSG trials.[<a href="#cit/section_1.40">

131740</a>

1318] Twenty-four patients with congenital rhabdomyosarcoma were registered. All patients had favorable histology and localized disease, except for one patient with <em class="gene-name">

1319PAX3</em>

1320::<em class="gene-name">

1321FOXO1</em>

1322 fusion&#8211;positive metastatic rhabdomyosarcoma. Three patients had <em class="gene-name">

1323VGLL2</em>

1324::<em class="gene-name">

1325CITED2</em>

1326 or <em class="gene-name">

1327VGLL2</em>

1328::<em class="gene-name">

1329NCOA2</em>

1330 fusions. Complete tumor resection was achieved in ten patients. No radiation therapy was given. Chemotherapy doses were adjusted to age and weight. Only two patients required further dose reduction for toxicity. The 5-year EFS rate was 75.0% (95% confidence interval [CI], 52.6%&#8211;87.9%), and the OS rate was 87.3% (95% CI, 65.6%&#8211;95.7%).</p>

1331<p id="_2096" tabindex="-1">

1332 An international consortium identified 40 infants with spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.41">

133341</a>

1334] The 5-year EFS rate for these infants with localized disease was 86% (&#177; 11%; 95% CI), and the OS rate was 91% (&#177; 9%; 95% CI). These outcomes compare favorably with those of all infants with localized rhabdomyosarcoma, for whom the 5-year failure-free survival rates range from 42% to 72% and the 5-year OS rates range from 61% to 88%. This finding suggests that infants with congenital spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma have a favorable outcome compared with infants with other subtypes of rhabdomyosarcoma.</p>

1335</li>

1336<li>

1337<strong>

1338Older children:</strong>

1339 In older children, the upper dosage limits of vincristine and dactinomycin are based on body surface area (BSA), and these patients may require reduced vincristine doses because of neurotoxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_1.35">

134035</a>

1341,<a href="#cit/section_1.42">

134242</a>

1343]</li>

1344<li>

1345<strong>

1346Adolescents:</strong>

1347 A report from the Associazione Italiana Ematologia Oncologia Pediatrica Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee suggests that adolescents may have more frequent unfavorable tumor characteristics, including alveolar histology, regional lymph node involvement, and metastatic disease at diagnosis, accounting for their poor prognosis. This study also found that 5-year OS and progression-free survival (PFS) rates were somewhat lower in adolescents than in children, but the differences among age groups younger than 1 year and aged 10 to 19 years at diagnosis were significantly worse than those in the group aged 1 to 9 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.43">

134843</a>

1349]<p id="_1977" tabindex="-1">

1350Two reports from the COG have documented inferior 5-year EFS rates in patients older than 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.35">

135135</a>

1352,<a href="#cit/section_1.42">

135342</a>

1354] When compared with younger patients, this group of older patients was more likely to present with advanced-stage, large, and invasive alveolar tumors, with nodal involvement arising in the extremity and paratesticular sites. Older patients experienced less myelosuppression and more peripheral nervous system toxicity, suggesting that dose modifications during therapy cannot account for the age-related differences in EFS.</p>

1355<p id="_2092" tabindex="-1">

1356Adolescent and young adult (AYA) patients were more likely to have worse survival outcomes than children.[<a href="#cit/section_1.44">

135744</a>

1358] </p>

1359<div class="pdq-content-list">

1360<ul id="_2097">

1361<li>

1362AYA patients were more likely to have metastatic tumors (61 of 257 [23.7%] vs. 197 of 1,720 [11.5%]; <em>

1363P</em>

1364 &lt; .0001), unfavorable histological subtypes (119 [46.3%] vs. 451 [26.2%]; <em>

1365P</em>

1366 &lt; .0001), tumors larger than 5 cm (177 [68.9%] vs. 891 [51.8%]; <em>

1367P</em>

1368 &lt; .0001), and regional lymph node involvement (109 [42.4%] vs. 339 [19.7%]; <em>

1369P</em>

1370 &lt; .0001) than children.</li>

1371<li>

1372AYA patients had lower 5-year EFS rates (52.6% [95% CI, 46.3%&#8211;58.6%] vs. 67.8% [95% CI, 65.5%&#8211;70.0%]; <em>

1373P</em>

1374 &lt; .0001) and OS rates (57.1% [95% CI, 50.4%&#8211;63.1%] vs. 77.9% [95% CI, 75.8%&#8211;79.8%]; <em>

1375P</em>

1376 &lt; .0001) than children.</li>

1377<li>

1378The multivariable analysis confirmed the inferior prognosis of patients aged 15 to 21 years (hazard ratio [HR], 1.48 [95% CI, 1.20&#8211;1.83; <em>

1379P</em>

1380 = .0002] for poorer EFS; HR, 1.73 [95% CI, 1.37&#8211;2.19; <em>

1381P</em>

1382 &lt; .0001] for poorer OS).</li>

1383</ul>

1384</div>

1385</li>

1386<li>

1387<strong>

1388Adults:</strong>

1389 Adult patients with rhabdomyosarcoma have a higher incidence of pleomorphic histology (19%) than do children (&lt;2%). Adults also have a higher incidence of tumors in unfavorable sites than do children.[<a href="#cit/section_1.29">

139029</a>

1391]</li>

1392</ul>

1393</div>

1394</section>

1395<section id="_1888">

1396<h4 id="_1888_toc">

1397Site of origin</h4>

1398<p id="_1889" tabindex="-1">

1399 Prognosis for childhood rhabdomyosarcoma varies according to the primary tumor site (see <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_785">

1400Table 1</a>

1401).</p>

1402<table id="_785" class="table-default expandable-container">

1403<caption>

1404Table 1. 5-Year Survival by Primary Site of Disease</caption>

1405<colgroup>

1406<col width="34.19%">

1407<col width="32.25%">

1408<col width="33.54%">

1409</colgroup>

1410<THead>

1411<tr>

1412<th>

1413Primary Site</th>

1414<th>

1415Number of Patients</th>

1416<th>

1417Survival at 5 Years (%)</th>

1418</tr>

1419</THead>

1420<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

1421<tr>

1422<td colspan="3">

1423<span class="sup">

142645</a>

1427]</td>

1428</tr>

1429<tr>

1430<td colspan="3">

1431<span class="sup">

1432b</span>

1435]</td>

1436</tr>

1437<tr>

144247</a>

1443]</td>

1444</tr>

1445<tr>

1447<span class="sup">

1449Combined result from the Children's Oncology Group, German Cooperative Soft Tissue Sarcoma Study, Italian Cooperative Group, and International Society of Pediatric Oncology groups.[<a href="#cit/section_1.48">

145048</a>

1451]</td>

1452</tr>

1453<tr>

1454<td colspan="3">

1455<span class="sup">

1456e</span>

1457Pooled analysis of European and North American groups.[<a href="#cit/section_1.49">

145849</a>

1459]</td>

1460</tr>

1461<tr>

1462<td colspan="3">

1463<span class="sup">

1464f</span>

1465Patients treated on Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study III.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

14666</a>

1467]</td>

1468</tr>

1469<tr>

1470<td colspan="3">

1471<span class="sup">

1472g</span>

1473Patients treated on Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Studies I&#8211;IV.[<a href="#cit/section_1.50">

147450</a>

1475]</td>

1476</tr>

1477<tr>

1478<td colspan="3">

148251</a>

1483]</td>

1484</tr>

1485</TFoot>

1487<tr>

1497</td>

1498<td>

149982</td>

1500<td>

150197</td>

1502</tr>

1503<tr>

1504<td>

1505Head and neck (nonparameningeal)<span class="sup">

1506b</span>

1507</td>

1508<td>

1509164</td>

1510<td>

151183</td>

1512</tr>

1513<tr>

1514<td>

1515Cranial parameningeal<span class="sup">

1516c</span>

1517

1518</td>

1519<td>

1520204</td>

1521<td>

152269.5</td>

1523</tr>

1524<tr>

1525<td>

1526Genitourinary (excluding bladder/prostate)<span class="sup">

1527b</span>

1528</td>

1529<td>

1530158 </td>

1531<td>

153289</td>

1533</tr>

1534<tr>

1535<td>

1536Localized bladder/prostate<span class="sup">

1537d</span>

1538</td>

1540322</td>

1541<td>

1542 84</td>

1543</tr>

1544<tr>

1545<td>

1546Localized extremity<span class="sup">

1547e</span>

1548</td>

1549<td>

1550643</td>

1551<td>

155267</td>

1553</tr>

1554<tr>

1555<td>

1556Trunk, abdomen, perineum, etc.<span class="sup">

1557f</span>

1558</td>

1559<td>

1560147 </td>

1561<td>

156267</td>

1563</tr>

1564<tr>

1565<td>

1566Biliary<span class="sup">

1567g,h</span>

1568</td>

1569<td>

157025 </td>

1571<td>

157276.5&#8211;78</td>

1573</tr>

1574</tbody>

1575</table>

1576</section>

1577<section id="_1890">

1578<h4 id="_1890_toc">

1579Tumor size</h4>

1580<p id="_1891" tabindex="-1">

1581 Children with

1582tumors 5 cm or smaller have improved survival, compared with children with

1583tumors larger than 5 cm.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

15846</a>

1585] Both tumor volume and maximum tumor diameter are associated with outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.52">

158652</a>

1587][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1588Level of evidence C1</a>

1589] </p>

1590<p id="_616" tabindex="-1">

1591A retrospective review of soft tissue sarcomas in children and adolescents suggests that the 5-cm cutoff used for adults with soft tissue sarcoma may not be ideal for smaller children, especially infants. The review identified an interaction between tumor diameter and BSA.[<a href="#cit/section_1.53">

159253</a>

1593] This was not confirmed by a COG study of patients with intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.54">

159454</a>

1595] This relationship requires prospective study to determine the therapeutic implications of the observation. </p>

1596</section>

1597<section id="_1892">

1598<h4 id="_1892_toc">

1599Resectability</h4>

1600<p id="_1893" tabindex="-1">

1601The extent of disease after the primary surgical procedure (i.e., the Surgical-pathologic Group, also called the Clinical Group) is correlated with outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

16026</a>

1603] In the IRS-III study, patients with localized, gross residual disease after

1604initial surgery (Surgical-pathologic Group III) had a 5-year survival rate of

1605approximately 70%, compared with a rate of more than 90% for

1606patients without residual tumor after surgery (Group I) and a

1607rate of approximately 80% for patients with microscopic residual

1608tumor after surgery (Group II).[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

16096</a>

1610,<a href="#cit/section_1.55">

161155</a>

1612] Groups I and II represent a minority of patients; approximately 50% of patients have unresectable Group III disease at time of diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

16136</a>

1614]</p>

1615<p id="_790" tabindex="-1">

1616Resectability without functional impairment is related to the tumor's initial size and site and does not account for the biology of the disease. Outcome is optimized with the use of multimodality therapy. All patients require chemotherapy, and at least 85% of patients also benefit from radiation therapy, with favorable outcomes even for patients with nonresectable disease. In the IRS-IV study, the Group III patients with localized unresectable disease who were treated with chemotherapy and radiation therapy had a 5-year FFS rate of about 75% and a local control rate of 87%.[<a href="#cit/section_1.56">

161756</a>

1618] Two intermediate-risk COG rhabdomyosarcoma studies (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

1619D9803</a>

1620 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00354835">

1621ARST0531 [NCT00354835]</a>

1622) were pooled to assess the benefit of delayed primary excision. In the D9803 study, local control with radiation therapy after either a partial or complete excision was completed at week 12. In the ARST0531 study, radiation was administered upfront at week 4. Patients with bladder or prostate rhabdomyosarcoma who received a delayed primary excision had no difference in survival, whereas patients with extremity rhabdomyosarcoma or nonbladder/nonprostate nonextremity rhabdomyosarcoma had an improved OS with delayed primary excision. Delayed primary excision strategy with a reduction in radiation dose resulted in superior OS for those sites.[<a href="#cit/section_1.57">

162357</a>

1624,<a href="#cit/section_1.58">

162558</a>

1626]</p>

1627</section>

1628<section id="_1894">

1629<h4 id="_1894_toc">

1630Histopathological subtype</h4>

1631<p id="_1895" tabindex="-1">

1632The alveolar subtype of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma is more prevalent among patients with less favorable

1633clinical features (e.g., younger than 1 year or older than 10 years,

1634extremity and truncal primary tumors, and metastatic disease at diagnosis). It is generally associated with

1635a worse outcome than in similar patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. </p>

1636<div class="pdq-content-list">

1637<ul id="_791">

1638<li>

1639In the IRS-I and IRS-II studies, the alveolar subtype was

1640associated with a less favorable outcome, even in patients whose primary

1641 tumor was completely resected (Group I).[<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

164259</a>

1643]</li>

1644<li>

1645A statistically significant

1646difference in 5-year survival by histopathological subtype (82% for embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma vs. 65% for alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma) was noted

1647when 1,258 IRS-III and IRS-IV patients with rhabdomyosarcoma were analyzed.[<a href="#cit/section_1.60">

164860</a>

1649]</li>

1650<li>

1651In the IRS-III study, the outcome for patients with Group I alveolar subtype tumors was similar to that for other patients with

1652Group I tumors, but the alveolar patients received more

1653intensive therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

16546</a>

1655]</li>

1656<li>

1657Patients with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma who have regional lymph node involvement have significantly worse outcomes than patients who do not have regional lymph node involvement (5-year FFS rates, 43% vs. 73%).[<a href="#cit/section_1.61">

165861</a>

1659]</li>

1660<li>

1661Local-control rates after radiation therapy are similar among patients with alveolar and embryonal tumors. However, patients who present with tumors 5 cm or larger have a significantly higher local failure rate.[<a href="#cit/section_1.62">

166262</a>

1663]</li>

1664</ul>

1665</div>

1666<p id="_618" tabindex="-1">

1667Anaplasia has been observed in 13% of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma cases, with some studies suggesting the presence of anaplasia adversely influenced clinical outcome in patients with intermediate-risk disease. However, anaplasia has not been shown to be an independent prognostic variable.[<a href="#cit/section_1.63">

166863</a>

1669,<a href="#cit/section_1.64">

167064</a>

1671]</p>

1672</section>

1673<section id="_1897">

1674<h4 id="_1897_toc">

1675<em class="gene-name">

1676PAX3</em>

1677::<em class="gene-name">

1678FOXO1</em>

1679 or <em class="gene-name">

1680PAX7</em>

1681::<em class="gene-name">

1682FOXO1</em>

1683 gene fusion status</h4>

1684<p id="_1898" tabindex="-1">

1685Approximately 80% of rhabdomyosarcoma cases morphologically defined as alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma express a <em class="gene-name">

1686FOXO1</em>

1687 fusion. <em class="gene-name">

1688FOXO1</em>

1689 gene fusions occur only in alveolar histology tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.65">

169065</a>

1691] Several retrospective studies found that fusion status is an independent prognostic factor. Patients with translocation-negative alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma have tumors with genetic and molecular profiles and outcomes similar to patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, and they fare better than patients with fusion-positive alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.66">

169266</a>

1693,<a href="#cit/section_1.67">

169467</a>

1695] Early retrospective studies relied on convenience samples of available tumor tissue.[<a href="#cit/section_1.66">

169666</a>

1697,<a href="#cit/section_1.67">

169867</a>

1699] A subsequent prospective study from the Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee of the COG that examined 434 cases of intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma treated on a single intermediate protocol (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

1700D9803</a>

1701) confirmed these observations.[<a href="#cit/section_1.68">

170268</a>

1703] Analysis of 38 patients enrolled in the COG D9802 low-risk study determined that fusion-positive, low-risk patients should be treated as intermediate risk.[<a href="#cit/section_1.69">

170469</a>

1705]</p>

1706<p id="_1937" tabindex="-1">

1707The specific fusion partner may have prognostic impact. In a COG study, fusion-positive patients with Stage 2 or 3, Group III, and <em class="gene-name">

1708PAX3</em>

1709-positive tumors had a lower EFS rate (54%) than those with <em class="gene-name">

1710PAX7</em>

1711-positive tumors (65%). Both fusion-positive groups did worse than those with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (EFS rate, 77%; <em>

1712P</em>

1713 &lt; .001). Patients with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma and <em class="gene-name">

1714PAX3</em>

1715 fusions had a poorer OS rate (64%) than patients with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma and <em class="gene-name">

1716PAX7</em>

1717 fusions (87%), patients with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma who were fusion negative (89%), and patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (82%; <em>

1718P</em>

1719 = .006).[<a href="#cit/section_1.68">

172068</a>

1721] Comparable results were observed in the U.K. study; patients with <em class="gene-name">

1722PAX7</em>

1723-positive tumors and patients with fusion-negative tumors had similar outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_1.70">

172470</a>

1725] </p>

1726<p id="_2054" tabindex="-1">

1727Using data from six consecutive COG studies, a retrospective analysis of 1,727 patients with rhabdomyosarcoma refined the risk stratification for childhood rhabdomyosarcoma. The study reported that after metastatic status,

1728<em class="gene-name">

1729FOXO1</em>

1730 status was the most important prognostic factor and improved the risk stratification of patients with localized rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.67">

173167</a>

1732]</p>

1733<p id="_2010" tabindex="-1">

1734The COG performed a retrospective analysis of 269 patients with confirmed <em class="gene-name">

1735FOXO1</em>

1736 fusion&#8211;positive rhabdomyosarcoma who were enrolled in three completed clinical trials for localized rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.71">

173771</a>

1738] The estimated 4-year EFS rate was 53% (95% CI, 47%&#8211;59%), and the OS rate was 69% (95% CI, 63%&#8211;74%). Multivariate analysis identified older age (&#8805;10 years) and larger tumor size (&gt;5 cm) as independent, adverse prognostic factors for EFS within this population. Patients who had both of these adverse features experienced substantially inferior outcomes.</p>

1739<p id="_1938" tabindex="-1">

1740 These studies demonstrated that fusion status was a better predictor of outcome than histology. Fusion status has now been incorporated into the risk stratification of patients in the current COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02567435">

1741ARST1431 (NCT02567435)</a>

1742 study for patients with intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma and for subsequent COG trials. Similar conclusions were reached in a retrospective study of three consecutive trials in the United Kingdom. The authors underscored the probable value of treating fusion-negative patients whose tumors have alveolar histology with therapy that is stage appropriate for embryonal histology tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.72">

174372</a>

1744][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1745Level of evidence C1</a>

1746]</p>

1747</section>

1748<section id="_1899">

1749<h4 id="_1899_toc">

1750Metastases at diagnosis</h4>

1751<p id="_1900" tabindex="-1">

1752Children with metastatic disease at diagnosis have the

1753worst prognosis.

1754

1755</p>

1756<p id="_893" tabindex="-1">

1757The prognostic significance of metastatic disease

1758is modified by the following:</p>

1759<div class="pdq-content-list">

1760<ul id="_793">

1761<li>

1762Tumor histology (embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma is more favorable than alveolar). Patients with localized alveolar histology and regional node disease have a similar prognosis as patients with a single site of metastatic disease, provided that the regional disease is treated with radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.61">

176361</a>

1764]</li>

1765<li>

1766Age at diagnosis (&lt;10 years for children with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma).</li>

1767<li>

1768The site of primary disease. Patients with metastatic genitourinary (nonbladder, nonprostate)

1769primary tumors have a more favorable outcome than patients with

1770metastatic disease from other primary sites.[<a href="#cit/section_1.73">

177173</a>

1772]</li>

1773<li>

1774The number of metastatic sites.[<a href="#cit/section_1.74">

177574</a>

1776-<a href="#cit/section_1.77">

177777</a>

1778]

1779 </li>

1780</ul>

1781</div>

1782<p id="_934" tabindex="-1">

1783The COG performed a retrospective review of patients enrolled in high-risk protocols for rhabdomyosarcoma. <em class="gene-name">

1784FOXO1</em>

1785 fusion status correlated with clinical characteristics at diagnosis, including age, stage, histology, and extent of metastatic disease (Oberlin status). Among patients with metastatic disease, <em class="gene-name">

1786PAX</em>

1787::<em class="gene-name">

1788FOXO1</em>

1789 fusion status was not an independent predictor of outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_1.78">

179078</a>

1791][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1792Level of evidence B1</a>

1793]</p>

1794</section>

1795<section id="_1901">

1796<h4 id="_1901_toc">

1797Lymph node involvement at diagnosis</h4>

1798<p id="_1902" tabindex="-1">

1799Lymph node involvement at diagnosis is seen in about 23% of patients with rhabdomyosarcoma and is associated with an inferior prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.60">

180060</a>

1801,<a href="#cit/section_1.79">

180279</a>

1803] Clinical and/or imaging evaluation is performed before treatment and preoperatively. These findings are incorporated into the initial staging and grouping of a patient with rhabdomyosarcoma. The updated TNM staging defines clinical node involvement as larger than 1 cm.[<a href="#cit/section_1.80">

180480</a>

1805]</p>

1806<p id="_2055" tabindex="-1">

1807Pathological assessment of nodal disease is determined by biopsy and incorporated in the Surgical/Pathologic Clinical Group classification. Core-needle or open biopsy of clinically enlarged nodes is appropriate to confirm the presence of disease. Approximately 25% of enlarged nodes will be pathologically negative. Suspicious nodes are sampled surgically with open biopsy, preferred to needle aspiration, although needle aspiration may occasionally be appropriate. Pathological evaluation of clinically uninvolved nodes is site specific. In COG studies, it is required for extremity sites and for boys older than 10 years with paratesticular primary tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.81">

180881</a>

1809] Given the poorer outcomes, pathological node evaluation is required for patients with fusion-positive disease in current European and North American clinical trials.</p>

1810<p id="_794" tabindex="-1">

1811Data on the frequency of lymph node involvement in various sites are useful for making clinical decisions. For example, up to 40% of patients with rhabdomyosarcoma in genitourinary sites have lymph node involvement, while patients with certain head and neck sites have a much lower likelihood (&lt;10%). Patients with nongenitourinary pelvic sites (e.g., anus/perineum) have an intermediate frequency of lymph node involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_1.82">

181282</a>

1813]</p>

1814<p id="_889" tabindex="-1">

1815In the extremities and select truncal sites, sentinel lymph node evaluation is a more accurate form of diagnosis than random regional lymph node sampling. In clinically negative lymph nodes of the extremity or trunk, sentinel lymph node biopsy is the preferred form of node sampling by the COG. Technical considerations are obtained from surgical experts. Needle or open biopsy of clinically enlarged nodes is appropriate.[<a href="#cit/section_1.83">

181683</a>

1817-<a href="#cit/section_1.86">

181886</a>

1819] Lymph node removal does not improve outcome, and it is useful for staging but not treatment.</p>

1820<p id="_2091" tabindex="-1">

1821The EpSSG performed a retrospective analysis of 109 patients with rhabdomyosarcoma with extremity primary tumors distal to the elbow or knee who were treated in the EpSSG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379457">

1822RMS-2005 (NCT00379457)</a>

1823 trial (2005&#8211;2016).[<a href="#cit/section_1.87">

182487</a>

1825] Thirty-seven of 109 patients (34%) had lymph node metastases at diagnosis. Of the 37 patients, 19 (51%) had in-transit metastases (ITM), especially in lower extremity rhabdomyosarcoma. The 5-year EFS rates were 88.9% for patients with ITM, 21.4% for patients with proximal lymph node involvement, and 20% for combined proximal lymph node involvement and ITM (<em>

1826P</em>

1827 = .01). The 5-year OS rates were 100% for patients with ITM, 25.2% for patients with proximal lymph node involvement, and 15% for patients with combined proximal lymph node involvement and ITM (<em>

1828P</em>

1829 =. 003). The authors concluded that popliteal and epitrochlear nodes should be considered as true (distal) regional nodes, instead of ITM. The authors recommended biopsy of these nodes, especially for distal extremity rhabdomyosarcoma of the lower limb.</p>

1830<p id="_2093" tabindex="-1">

1831The EpSSG reported a retrospective analysis of 1,294 children with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma enrolled in the RMS-2005 protocol.[<a href="#cit/section_1.88">

183288</a>

1833] Of these patients, 143 had nodal involvement (N1). Patients with N1 disease were older and presented with tumors of unfavorable size, invasiveness, site, and resectability. Unlike alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, nodal involvement was more frequent in the head and neck area and rare in extremity sites. The 5-year EFS rate was 75.5%, and the OS rate was 86.3% for patients with N0 disease. The 5-year EFS rate was 65.2%, and the OS rate was 70.7% for patients with N1 disease. Nodal involvement and the result of surgery at diagnosis (Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study group) were independent prognostic factors on multivariate analysis. Investigators concluded that regional nodal involvement is an independent prognostic factor in patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma; therefore, it is appropriate to include this population in the high-risk category.

1834</p>

1835</section>

1836<section id="_1904">

1837<h4 id="_1904_toc">

1838Biological characteristics</h4>

1839<p id="_1905" tabindex="-1">

1840For more information, see the <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_788">

1841Molecular Characteristics of Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

1842 section.</p>

1843</section>

1844<section id="_1906">

1845<h4 id="_1906_toc">

1846Response to therapy</h4>

1847<p id="_768" tabindex="-1">

1848It is unlikely that response to induction chemotherapy or best tumor response during therapy, assessed by anatomic imaging, correlates with the likelihood of survival in patients with rhabdomyosarcoma. This finding was based on the IRSG, COG, and International Society of Pediatric Oncology (SIOP) studies that found no association.[<a href="#cit/section_1.89">

184989</a>

1850,<a href="#cit/section_1.90">

185190</a>

1852]; [<a href="#cit/section_1.91">

185391</a>

1854][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1855Level of evidence C2</a>

1856]; [<a href="#cit/section_1.92">

185792</a>

1858][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1859Level of evidence C1</a>

1860] However, an Italian study did find that patient response correlated with likelihood of survival.[<a href="#cit/section_1.52">

186152</a>

1862][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1863Level of evidence C1</a>

1864] In patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma who had metastases only in the lungs, the CWS assessed the relationship between complete response of the lung metastases at weeks 7 to 10 after chemotherapy and outcome in 53 patients.[<a href="#cit/section_1.93">

186593</a>

1866][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1867Level of evidence C1</a>

1868] The 5-year survival rate was 68% for 26 complete responders at weeks 7 to 10 versus 36% for 27 patients who achieved complete responses at later time points (<em>

1869P</em>

1870 = .004).</p>

1871<p id="_1802" tabindex="-1">

1872Other studies have investigated response to induction therapy, showing benefit to response. These data are somewhat flawed because therapy is usually tailored on the basis of response. Thus the situation is not as clear as the COG data suggest.[<a href="#cit/section_1.94">

187394</a>

1874-<a href="#cit/section_1.99">

187599</a>

1876]</p>

1877<p id="_769" tabindex="-1">

1878Response as judged by sequential functional imaging studies with fluorine F 18-fludeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (18F-FDG PET) may be an early indicator of outcome [<a href="#cit/section_1.100">

1879100</a>

1880] and is under investigation by several pediatric cooperative groups. A retrospective analysis of 107 patients from a single institution examined PET scans performed at baseline, after induction chemotherapy, and after local therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.100">

1881100</a>

1882] Standardized uptake value measured at baseline predicted PFS and OS, but not local control. A negative scan after induction chemotherapy correlated with statistically significantly better PFS. A positive scan after local therapy predicted worse PFS, OS, and local control. The COG evaluated the relationship between complete metabolic response, as assessed by 18F-FDG PET imaging, and EFS in patients with intermediate- or high-risk rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.101">

1883101</a>

1884][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1885Level of evidence B4</a>

1886] The maximum standard uptake values (SUVmax) at study entry did not correlate with EFS for intermediate-risk (<em>

1887P</em>

1888 = .32) or high-risk (<em>

1889P</em>

1890 = .86) patients. Compared with patients who did not achieve a complete metabolic response, EFS was not superior for intermediate-risk patients who achieved a complete metabolic response at weeks 4 (<em>

1891P</em>

1892 = .66) or 15 (<em>

1893P</em>

1894 = .46), or for high-risk patients who achieved a complete metabolic response at weeks 6 (<em>

1895P</em>

1896 = .75) or 19 (<em>

1897P</em>

1898 = .28). Change in SUVmax at weeks 4 (<em>

1899P</em>

1900 = .21) or 15 (<em>

1901P</em>

1902 = .91) for intermediate-risk patients and at weeks 6 (<em>

1903P</em>

1904 = .75) or 19 (<em>

1905P</em>

1906 = .61) for high-risk patients did not correlate with EFS.</p>

1907<p id="_2032" tabindex="-1">

1908PET scans have been shown to be useful in understanding patterns of spread, particularly in patients with extremity disease.[<a href="#cit/section_1.102">

1909102</a>

1910][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1911Level of evidence C2</a>

1912]</p>

1913</section>

1914<section id="_2098">

1915<h4 id="_2098_toc">

1916Circulating tumor DNA and RNA</h4>

1917<p id="_2089" tabindex="-1">

1918A retrospective study of 99 children with rhabdomyosarcoma used reverse transcription&#8211;polymerase chain reaction to analyze an 11-gene panel in peripheral blood and bone marrow samples at the time of initial diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.103">

1919103</a>

1920] The 5-year EFS rate was 35.5% (95% CI, 17.5%&#8211;53.5%) for the 33 patients who were RNA positive, compared with 88.0% (95% CI, 78.9%&#8211;97.2%) for the 66 patients who were RNA negative (<em>

1921P</em>

1922 &lt; .0001). The predictive power of the assay was maintained in a multivariate analysis, which included the usual clinical characteristics that correlate with prognosis such as the presence of metastatic disease.</p>

1923</section>

1924</section>

1925<h6 do-not-show="toc">

1952[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1953</li>

1954<li id="section_1.8">

1955Casanova M, Meazza C, Favini F, et al.: Rhabdomyosarcoma of the extremities: a focus on tumors arising in the hand and foot. Pediatr Hematol Oncol 26 (5): 321-31, 2009 Jul-Aug.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19579078&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19579078&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1956[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1960[PUBMED Abstract]</a>
