2279<li id="section_1.89">

2280Burke M, Anderson JR, Kao SC, et al.: Assessment of response to induction therapy and its influence on 5-year failure-free survival in group III rhabdomyosarcoma: the Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study-IV experience--a report from the Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee of the Children's Oncology Group. J Clin Oncol 25 (31): 4909-13, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17971587&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17971587&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2281[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2282</li>

2283<li id="section_1.90">

2284Lautz TB, Chi YY, Tian J, et al.: Relationship between tumor response at therapy completion and prognosis in patients with Group III rhabdomyosarcoma: A report from the Children's Oncology Group. Int J Cancer 147 (5): 1419-1426, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32012255&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32012255&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2285[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2286</li>

2287<li id="section_1.91">

2288Rosenberg AR, Anderson JR, Lyden E, et al.: Early response as assessed by anatomic imaging does not predict failure-free survival among patients with Group III rhabdomyosarcoma: a report from the Children's Oncology Group. Eur J Cancer 50 (4): 816-23, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24361229&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24361229&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2289[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2290</li>

2291<li id="section_1.92">

2292Vaarwerk B, van der Lee JH, Breunis WB, et al.: Prognostic relevance of early radiologic response to induction chemotherapy in pediatric rhabdomyosarcoma: A report from the International Society of Pediatric Oncology Malignant Mesenchymal Tumor 95 study. Cancer 124 (5): 1016-1024, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29211298&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29211298&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2293[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2294</li>

2295<li id="section_1.93">

2296Sparber-Sauer M, von Kalle T, Seitz G, et al.: The prognostic value of early radiographic response in children and adolescents with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma stage IV, metastases confined to the lungs: A report from the Cooperative Weichteilsarkom Studiengruppe (CWS). Pediatr Blood Cancer 64 (10): , 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28306214&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28306214&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2297[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2298</li>

2299<li id="section_1.94">

2300Koscielniak E, Harms D, Henze G, et al.: Results of treatment for soft tissue sarcoma in childhood and adolescence: a final report of the German Cooperative Soft Tissue Sarcoma Study CWS-86. J Clin Oncol 17 (12): 3706-19, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10577842&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10577842&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2301[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2302</li>

2303<li id="section_1.95">

2304Koscielniak E, J&#252;rgens H, Winkler K, et al.: Treatment of soft tissue sarcoma in childhood and adolescence. A report of the German Cooperative Soft Tissue Sarcoma Study. Cancer 70 (10): 2557-67, 1992.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1482503&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1482503&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2305[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2306</li>

2307<li id="section_1.96">

2308Dantonello TM, Int-Veen C, Harms D, et al.: Cooperative trial CWS-91 for localized soft tissue sarcoma in children, adolescents, and young adults. J Clin Oncol 27 (9): 1446-55, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19224858&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19224858&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2309[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2310</li>

2311<li id="section_1.97">

2312Oberlin O, Rey A, Sanchez de Toledo J, et al.: Randomized comparison of intensified six-drug versus standard three-drug chemotherapy for high-risk nonmetastatic rhabdomyosarcoma and other chemotherapy-sensitive childhood soft tissue sarcomas: long-term results from the International Society of Pediatric Oncology MMT95 study. J Clin Oncol 30 (20): 2457-65, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22665534&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22665534&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2313[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2314</li>

2315<li id="section_1.98">

2316Stevens MC, Rey A, Bouvet N, et al.: Treatment of nonmetastatic rhabdomyosarcoma in childhood and adolescence: third study of the International Society of Paediatric Oncology--SIOP Malignant Mesenchymal Tumor 89. J Clin Oncol 23 (12): 2618-28, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15728225&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15728225&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2317[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2318</li>

2319<li id="section_1.99">

2320Dantonello TM, Stark M, Timmermann B, et al.: Tumour volume reduction after neoadjuvant chemotherapy impacts outcome in localised embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. Pediatr Blood Cancer 62 (1): 16-23, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25263634&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25263634&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2321[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2322</li>

2323<li id="section_1.100">

2324Casey DL, Wexler LH, Fox JJ, et al.: Predicting outcome in patients with rhabdomyosarcoma: role of [(18)f]fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 90 (5): 1136-42, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25539372&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25539372&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2325[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2326</li>

2327<li id="section_1.101">

2328Harrison DJ, Chi YY, Tian J, et al.: Metabolic response as assessed by 18 F-fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography-computed tomography does not predict outcome in patients with intermediate- or high-risk rhabdomyosarcoma: A report from the Children's Oncology Group Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee. Cancer Med 10 (3): 857-866, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33340280&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33340280&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2329[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2330</li>

2331<li id="section_1.102">

2332La TH, Wolden SL, Rodeberg DA, et al.: Regional nodal involvement and patterns of spread along in-transit pathways in children with rhabdomyosarcoma of the extremity: a report from the Children's Oncology Group. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 80 (4): 1151-7, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20542386&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20542386&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2333[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2334</li>

2335<li id="section_1.103">

2336Lak NSM, Voormanns TL, Zappeij-Kannegieter L, et al.: Improving Risk Stratification for Pediatric Patients with Rhabdomyosarcoma by Molecular Detection of Disseminated Disease. Clin Cancer Res 27 (20): 5576-5585, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34285060&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34285060&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2337[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2338</li>

2339</ol>

2340</div>

2341

2342 </section>

2343

2344

2345

2346 <section id="_13">

2347

2348 <h2>

2349Cellular Classification for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</h2>

2350

2351 <div id="_section_13" class="pdq-sections">

2352<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

2353<h6>

2354In This Section</h6>

2355<ul>

2356<li>

2357<a href="#_796_toc">

2358Histological Subtypes<ul>

2359<li>

2360<a href="#_224_toc">

2361Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

2362</li>

2363<li>

2364<a href="#_228_toc">

2365Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

2366</li>

2367<li>

2368<a href="#_1867_toc">

2369Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

2370</li>

2371<li>

2372<a href="#_230_toc">

2373Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

2374</li>

2375</ul>

2376</a>

2377</li>

2378<li>

2379<a href="#_788_toc">

2380Molecular Characteristics of Rhabdomyosarcoma<ul>

2381<li>

2382<a href="#_sm_CDR0000777839_13_toc">

2383Genomics of rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

2384</li>

2385</ul>

2386</a>

2387</li>

2388</ul>

2389</nav>

2390<section id="_796">

2391<h3 id="_796_toc">

2392Histological Subtypes</h3>

2393<p id="_14" tabindex="-1">

2394The 5th edition of the World Health Organization (WHO) Classification of Tumors of Soft Tissue and Bone recognizes the following four categories of rhabdomyosarcoma:[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

23951</a>

2396]</p>

2397<div class="pdq-content-list">

2398<ul id="_797">

2399<li>

2400<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_224">

2401Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

2402.</li>

2403<li>

2404<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_228">

2405Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

2406.</li>

2407<li>

2408<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1867">

2409Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

2410.</li>

2411<li>

2412<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_230">

2413Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

2414.</li>

2415</ul>

2416</div>

2417<section id="_224">

2418<h4 id="_224_toc">

2419Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma</h4>

2420<p id="_225" tabindex="-1">

2421The embryonal subtype, which includes classic, dense, and botryoid variants, is the most frequently observed

2422subtype in children, accounting for 70% to 75% of childhood

2423rhabdomyosarcomas.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

24241</a>

2425,<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

24262</a>

2427] Tumors with embryonal histology typically

2428arise in the head and neck region or in the genitourinary tract, although they

2429may occur at any primary site. </p>

2430<p id="_899" tabindex="-1">

2431Anaplasia has been observed in 13% of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma cases, with some studies suggesting the presence of anaplasia adversely influenced clinical outcome in patients with intermediate-risk disease. However, anaplasia has not been shown to be an independent prognostic variable.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

24323</a>

2433,<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

24344</a>

2435]</p>

2436<p id="_787" tabindex="-1">

2437Botryoid tumors, which represent about 10% of all

2438rhabdomyosarcoma cases, are embryonal tumors that arise under the mucosal

2439surface of body orifices such as the vagina, bladder, nasopharynx, and biliary tract.

2440The WHO Classification of Tumors of Soft Tissue and Bone (4th and 5th editions) and the Children's Oncology Group (COG) eliminated botryoid rhabdomyosarcoma as a separate entity, with these cases classified as typical embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

24411</a>

2442,<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

24435</a>

2444] </p>

2445<p id="_800" tabindex="-1">

2446A COG study of 2,192 children with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (including botryoid and spindle cell variants) enrolled in clinical trials showed improved event-free survival (EFS) rates for patients with botryoid tumors (80%; 95% confidence interval [CI], 74%&#8211;84%), compared with typical embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (73%; 95% CI, 71%&#8211;75%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

24476</a>

2448] However, after adjusting for primary site, resection, and metastatic status, there was no difference in EFS by histological subtype. In this COG report, botryoid tumors accounted for 14% of intermediate-risk patients and 15% of low-risk patients. The botryoid histology retained prognostic significance in only a small proportion of patients with low-risk head and neck tumors, who are known to have excellent outcomes. For these reasons, the COG concluded that the addition of this histological classification of rhabdomyosarcoma has limited clinical utility and endorsed the recommendations of the WHO to remove this subtype from the current COG pathology classification.</p>

2449<p id="_638" tabindex="-1">

2450One study analyzed the clinical and mutational spectrum of 24 pediatric fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma tumors with high levels of myogenic differentiation. The analysis revealed that most tumors arose in the head and neck or genitourinary region. The overall survival rate was 100% for these patients (median follow-up, 4.6 years).[<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

24517</a>

2452]</p>

2453</section>

2454<section id="_228">

2455<h4 id="_228_toc">

2456Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma</h4>

2457<p id="_229" tabindex="-1">

2458Approximately 20% to 25% of

2459children with rhabdomyosarcoma have the alveolar subtype, when histology alone is used to determine subtype.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

24601</a>

2461] An increased

2462frequency of this subtype is noted in adolescents and in patients with primary

2463sites involving the extremities, trunk, and perineum/perianal region.[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

24642</a>

2465] Eighty percent of patients with alveolar histology tumors will have one of two gene fusions, <em class="gene-name">

2466PAX3</em>

2467 on chromosome 2 or <em class="gene-name">

2468PAX7</em>

2469 on chromosome 1, with the <em class="gene-name">

2470FOXO1</em>

2471 gene on chromosome 13.[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

24728</a>

2473-<a href="#cit/section_2.10">

247410</a>

2475] Patients without a fusion have outcomes that are similar to those for patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.11">

247611</a>

2477-<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

247813</a>

2479]</p>

2480<p id="_469" tabindex="-1">

2481The current trial for intermediate-risk patients from the Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee of the COG (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02567435">

2482ARST1431 [NCT02567435]</a>

2483) and all future trials will use fusion status rather than histology to determine eligibility. Fusion-negative patients with alveolar histology will undergo the same treatments as patients with embryonal histology.</p>

2484</section>

2485<section id="_1867">

2486<h4 id="_1867_toc">

2487Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma</h4>

2488<p id="_1868" tabindex="-1">

2489The 4th edition of the WHO Classification of Tumors of Soft Tissue and Bone added spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma as a separate subtype of rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

24905</a>

2491] The 5th edition of the WHO Classification of Tumors of Soft Tissue and Bone continues to identify this separate subtype.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

24921</a>

2493] The spindle cell variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma is most frequently

2494observed at the paratesticular site.[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

24956</a>

2496,<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

249714</a>

2498] </p>

2499<p id="_1869" tabindex="-1">

2500A COG study of 2,192 children with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (including botryoid and spindle cell variants) and enrolled in clinical trials showed improved EFS rates for patients with spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma (83%; 95% CI, 77%&#8211;87%) compared with typical embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (73%; 95% CI, 71%&#8211;75%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

25016</a>

2502] Patients with spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma with parameningeal primary tumors (n = 18) were the exception to the overall favorable prognosis for this subtype, with a 5-year EFS rate of 28% (compared with &gt;70% for parameningeal nonspindle cell embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma).</p>

2503<p id="_1877" tabindex="-1">

2504In the WHO classification, sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma is considered a variant pattern of spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma, as descriptions note increasing degrees of hyalinization and matrix formation in spindle cell tumors. There are at least two distinct molecular subtypes of spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma in children: </p>

2505<div class="pdq-content-list">

2506<ul id="_1984">

2507<li>

2508One subtype affects patients in their first year of life, with a median age at presentation of 3 months. The tumors usually arise in the trunk and morphologically resemble infantile fibrosarcoma. This variant is characterized by fusions involving the <em class="gene-name">

2509VGLL2</em>

2510 gene with the <em class="gene-name">

2511CITED2</em>

2512 or <em class="gene-name">

2513NCOA2</em>

2514 genes. In a series of six patients with long-term follow-up data, two patients developed a local recurrence, but all were alive at a median of 7 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

251515</a>

2516,<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

251716</a>

2518] For more information on spindle cell/sclerosing histology, see the <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_788">

2519Molecular Characteristics of Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

2520 section.</li>

2521<li>

2522Another subtype is characterized by <em class="gene-name">

2523MYOD1</em>

2524 (p.L122R) mutations, and about one-third of this subset have coexistent <em class="gene-name">

2525PIK3CA</em>

2526 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

252717</a>

2528] These tumors can affect children, adolescents, and adults. They more frequently arise in the head and neck region and are characterized by an aggressive clinical course. In one series, 10 of 12 pediatric patients with follow-up data died of disease.[<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

252917</a>

2530]</li>

2531</ul>

2532</div>

2533</section>

2534<section id="_230">

2535<h4 id="_230_toc">

2536Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma</h4>

2537<p id="_231" tabindex="-1">

2538Pleomorphic

2539rhabdomyosarcoma occurs in adults in their sixth and seventh decades, most commonly involves the extremities, and is associated with a poor prognosis. This histological variant is extremely rare and not well characterized in the pediatric population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

254018</a>

2541,<a href="#cit/section_2.19">

254219</a>

2543] In children, tumors with extensive pleomorphism are considered anaplastic embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

25441</a>

2545]</p>

2546</section>

2547</section>

2548<section id="_788">

2549<h3 id="_788_toc">

2550Molecular Characteristics of Rhabdomyosarcoma</h3>

2551<section id="_sm_CDR0000777839_13">

2552<h4 id="_sm_CDR0000777839_13_toc">

2553Genomics of rhabdomyosarcoma</h4>

2554<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_644" tabindex="-1">

2555The four histological categories recognized in the 5th edition of the World Health Organization (WHO) Classification of Tumors of Soft Tissue and Bone have distinctive genomic alterations and are briefly summarized below.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

25561</a>

2557,<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

25582</a>

2559,<a href="#cit/section_2.20">

256020</a>

2561] </p>

2562<div class="pdq-content-list">

2563<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777839_645">

2564<li>

2565<strong>

2566Embryonal rhabdosarcoma:</strong>

2567 Characterized by loss of heterozygosity at 11p15 and by a high frequency of mutations in genes in the RAS pathway. For the purposes of this section, patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma are considered negative for <em class="gene-name">

2568PAX3</em>

2569::<em class="gene-name">

2570FOXO1</em>

2571 and <em class="gene-name">

2572PAX7</em>

2573::<em class="gene-name">

2574FOXO1</em>

2575 gene fusions (i.e., fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma).</li>

2576<li>

2577<strong>

2578Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma:</strong>

2579 Characterized by gene fusions involving <em class="gene-name">

2580FOXO1</em>

2581 with either <em class="gene-name">

2582PAX3</em>

2583 or <em class="gene-name">

2584PAX7</em>

2585 (i.e., <em class="gene-name">

2586FOXO1</em>

2587 fusion&#8211;positive rhabdomyosarcoma). Cases with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma histology without <em class="gene-name">

2588FOXO1</em>

2589 gene fusions have clinical behavior, gene alteration patterns, and transcriptomic profiles like cases with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. Therefore, the discussion below focuses only on alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma with <em class="gene-name">

2590FOXO1</em>

2591 gene fusions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

259212</a>

2593,<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

259413</a>

2595,<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

259621</a>

2597-<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

259823</a>

2599]</li>

2600<li>

2601<strong>

2602Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma:</strong>

2603 Characterized by mutations of <em class="gene-name">

2604MYOD1</em>

2605 in older patients and by <em class="gene-name">

2606VGLL2</em>

2607 and <em class="gene-name">

2608NCOA2</em>

2609 gene rearrangements in young children.</li>

2610<li>

2611<strong>

2612Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma:</strong>

2613 Characterized by complex karyotypes with numerical and unbalanced structural changes that are indistinguishable from those of undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcomas.</li>

2614</ul>

2615</div>

2616<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_646" tabindex="-1">

2617The distribution of gene mutations and gene amplifications (for <em class="gene-name">

2618CDK4</em>

2619 and <em class="gene-name">

2620MYCN</em>

2621) differs between patients with embryonal histology lacking a <em class="gene-name">

2622PAX</em>

2623::<em class="gene-name">

2624FOXO1</em>

2625 gene fusion (fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma) and patients with <em class="gene-name">

2626PAX</em>

2627::<em class="gene-name">

2628FOXO1</em>

2629 gene fusions (fusion-positive rhabdomyosarcoma). See Table 2 below and the text that follows. These frequencies are derived from a combined cohort of the Children's Oncology Group (COG) and United Kingdom rhabdomyosarcoma patients (n = 641).[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

263024</a>

2631]</p>

2632<table id="_sm_CDR0000777839_656" class="table-default expandable-container">

2633<caption>

2634Table 2. Frequency of Gene Alterations in Patients With Fusion-Negative (FN) and Fusion-Positive (FP) Rhabdomyosarcoma<span class="sup">

2635a</span>

2636</caption>

2637<colgroup>

2638<col width="33.33%">

2639<col width="33.33%">

2640<col width="33.33%">

2641</colgroup>

2642<THead>

2643<tr>

2644<th>

2645Gene</th>

2646<th>

2647% FN Cases With Gene Alteration</th>

2648<th>

2649% FP Cases With Gene Alteration</th>

2650</tr>

2651</THead>

2652<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2653<tr>

2654<td colspan="3">

2655<span class="sup">

2656a</span>

2657Adapted from Shern et al.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

265824</a>

2659]</td>

2660</tr>

2661</TFoot>

2662<tbody>

2663<tr>

2664<td>

2665<em class="gene-name">

2666NRAS</em>

2667</td>

2668<td>

266917%</td>

2670<td>

26711%</td>

2672</tr>

2673<tr>

2674<td>

2675<em class="gene-name">

2676KRAS</em>

2677</td>

2678<td>

26799%</td>

2680<td>

26811%</td>

2682</tr>

2683<tr>

2684<td>

2685<em class="gene-name">

2686HRAS</em>

2687</td>

2688<td>

26898%</td>

2690<td>

26912%</td>

2692</tr>

2693<tr>

2694<td>

2695<em class="gene-name">

2696FGFR4</em>

2697</td>

2698<td>

269913%</td>

2700<td>

27010%</td>

2702</tr>

2703<tr>

2704<td>

2705<em class="gene-name">

2706NF1</em>

2707</td>

2708<td>

270915%</td>

2710<td>

27114%</td>

2712</tr>

2713<tr>

2714<td>

2715<em class="gene-name">

2716BCOR</em>

2717</td>

2718<td>

271915%</td>

2720<td>

27216%</td>

2722</tr>

2723<tr>

2724<td>

2725<em class="gene-name">

2726TP53</em>

2727</td>

2728<td>

272913%</td>

2730<td>

27314%</td>

2732</tr>

2733<tr>

2734<td>

2735<em class="gene-name">

2736CTNNB1</em>

2737</td>

2738<td>

27396%</td>

2740<td>

27410%</td>

2742</tr>

2743<tr>

2744<td>

2745<em class="gene-name">

2746CDK4</em>

2747</td>

2748<td>

27490%</td>

2750<td>

275113%</td>

2752</tr>

2753<tr>

2754<td>

2755<em class="gene-name">

2756MYCN</em>

2757</td>

2758<td>

27590%</td>

2760<td>

276110%</td>

2762</tr>

2763</tbody>

2764</table>

2765<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_657" tabindex="-1">

2766Details of the genomic alterations that predominate within each of the WHO histological categories are as follows.</p>

2767<div class="pdq-content-list">

2768<ol id="_sm_CDR0000777839_629">

2769<li>

2770<strong>

2771Fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma (embryonal histology):</strong>

2772 Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma tumors often show loss of heterozygosity at 11p15 and gains on chromosome 8.[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

27739</a>

2774,<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

277525</a>

2776-<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

277727</a>

2778] Embryonal tumors have a higher background mutation rate and a higher single-nucleotide variant rate than do alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma tumors, and the number of somatic mutations increases with older age at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

277927</a>

2780,<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

278128</a>

2782] The most common recurring mutations include those in the RAS pathway (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

2783NRAS</em>

2784, <em class="gene-name">

2785KRAS</em>

2786, <em class="gene-name">

2787HRAS</em>

2788, and <em class="gene-name">

2789NF1</em>

2790), which together are observed in approximately one-half of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

279124</a>

2792] Mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2793NRAS</em>

2794 are the most frequent RAS pathway gene mutations beyond infancy, while mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2795HRAS</em>

2796 predominate during infancy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

279724</a>

2798] The presence of a <em class="gene-name">

2799RAS</em>

2800 mutation does not confer prognostic significance. <p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_647" tabindex="-1">

2801Among the RAS pathway genes, germline mutations in <em class="gene-name">

2802NF1</em>

2803 and <em class="gene-name">

2804HRAS</em>

2805 predispose to rhabdomyosarcoma. In a study of 615 children with rhabdomyosarcoma, 347 had tumors with embryonal histology. Of these, nine patients had <em class="gene-name">

2806NF1</em>

2807 germline mutations, and five patients had <em class="gene-name">

2808HRAS</em>

2809 germline mutations, representing 2.6% and 1.4% of embryonal histology cases, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_2.29">

281029</a>

2811]</p>

2812<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_648" tabindex="-1">

2813Other genes with recurring mutations in fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma tumors include <em class="gene-name">

2814FGFR4</em>

2815, <em class="gene-name">

2816PIK3CA</em>

2817, <em class="gene-name">

2818CTNNB1</em>

2819, <em class="gene-name">

2820FBXW7</em>

2821, and <em class="gene-name">

2822BCOR</em>

2823, all of which are present in fewer than 15% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

282424</a>

2825,<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

282627</a>

2827,<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

282828</a>

2829]</p>

2830<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_649" tabindex="-1">

2831<strong>

2832<em class="gene-name">

2833TP53</em>

2834 mutations:</strong>

2835 <em class="gene-name">

2836TP53</em>

2837 mutations are observed in 10% to 15% of patients with fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma and occur less commonly (about 4%) in patients with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

283824</a>

2839] In other childhood cancers (e.g., Wilms tumor), <em class="gene-name">

2840TP53</em>

2841 mutations are associated with anaplastic histology,[<a href="#cit/section_2.30">

284230</a>

2843] and the same is true for embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. In a study of 146 rhabdomyosarcoma patients with known <em class="gene-name">

2844TP53</em>

2845 status, approximately two-thirds of tumors with <em class="gene-name">

2846TP53</em>

2847 mutations showed anaplasia (69%), but only one-quarter of tumors with anaplasia had <em class="gene-name">

2848TP53</em>

2849 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

28504</a>

2851]</p>

2852<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_650" tabindex="-1">

2853The presence of <em class="gene-name">

2854TP53</em>

2855 mutations was associated with reduced EFS in both nonrisk-stratified and risk-stratified analyses for both a COG and a U.K. rhabdomyosarcoma cohort.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

285624</a>

2857] The poor prognosis associated with <em class="gene-name">

2858TP53</em>

2859 mutations was observed for both embryonal and alveolar patients. Based on these results, the COG plans to consider <em class="gene-name">

2860TP53</em>

2861 mutation as a high-risk defining characteristic in its upcoming trials.[<a href="#cit/section_2.31">

286231</a>

2863]</p>

2864<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_631" tabindex="-1">

2865Rhabdomyosarcoma is one of the childhood cancers associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome. In a study of 614 pediatric patients with rhabdomyosarcoma, 11 patients (1.7%) had <em class="gene-name">

2866TP53</em>

2867 germline mutations. Mutations were less common in patients with alveolar histology (0.6%), compared with patients with nonalveolar histologies (2.2%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.29">

286829</a>

2869] Rhabdomyosarcoma with nonalveolar anaplastic morphology may be a presenting feature for children with Li-Fraumeni syndrome and germline <em class="gene-name">

2870TP53</em>

2871 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.32">

287232</a>

2873] </p>

2874<div class="pdq-content-list">

2875<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777839_651">

2876<li>

2877Among eight consecutively presenting children with rhabdomyosarcoma and <em class="gene-name">

2878TP53</em>

2879 germline mutations, all showed anaplastic morphology. Among an additional seven children with anaplastic rhabdomyosarcoma and unknown <em class="gene-name">

2880TP53</em>

2881 germline mutation status, three of the seven children had functionally relevant <em class="gene-name">

2882TP53</em>

2883 germline mutations. The median age at diagnosis of the 11 children with <em class="gene-name">

2884TP53</em>

2885 germline mutation status was 40 months (range, 19&#8211;67 months).[<a href="#cit/section_2.32">

288632</a>

2887] </li>

2888<li>

2889In another series, 26 of 31 patients with germline <em class="gene-name">

2890TP53</em>

2891 mutations had tumors with embryonal histology. Of the 16 tumors that were submitted for central pathology review, 12 had focal or diffuse anaplasia. The median age of patients in this group was 2.3 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

289233</a>

2893]</li>

2894</ul>

2895</div>

2896<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_652" tabindex="-1">

2897<strong>

2898<em class="gene-name">

2899DICER1</em>

2900 mutations in embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma:</strong>

2901 <em class="gene-name">

2902DICER1</em>

2903 mutations are observed in a small subset of patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, most commonly arising in tumors of the female genitourinary tract.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

290424</a>

2905] More specifically, most cases of cervical embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma,[<a href="#cit/section_2.34">

290634</a>

2907-<a href="#cit/section_2.36">

290836</a>

2909] which most commonly occurs in adolescents and young adults,[<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

291037</a>

2911,<a href="#cit/section_2.38">

291238</a>

2913] have <em class="gene-name">

2914DICER1</em>

2915 mutations. In contrast, <em class="gene-name">

2916DICER1</em>

2917 mutations are rarely observed in patients with vaginal primary sites, an entity occurring primarily in girls younger than 2 or 3 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.35">

291835</a>

2919,<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

292037</a>

2921] <em class="gene-name">

2922DICER1</em>

2923 mutations are also common in embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma arising in the uterine corpus, but this presentation is primarily observed in adults.[<a href="#cit/section_2.35">

292435</a>

2925,<a href="#cit/section_2.39">

292639</a>

2927] Cervical rhabdomyosarcoma generally shows a sarcoma botryoides histological pattern, and many cases show areas of cartilaginous differentiation, a feature also observed in other tumor types with <em class="gene-name">

2928DICER1</em>

2929 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

293037</a>

2931,<a href="#cit/section_2.38">

293238</a>

2933,<a href="#cit/section_2.40">

293440</a>

2935] In support of the distinctive biology of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma with <em class="gene-name">

2936DICER1</em>

2937 mutations, these cases have a DNA methylation pattern that is distinctive from that of other embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.36">

293836</a>

2939] A diagnosis of cervical rhabdomyosarcoma is an indication for genetic testing for <em class="gene-name">

2940DICER1</em>

2941 syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.35">

294235</a>

2943,<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

294441</a>

2945]</p>

2946</li>

2947<li>

2948<strong>

2949Fusion-positive rhabdomyosarcoma (alveolar histology):</strong>

2950 About 70% to 80% of alveolar tumors are characterized by translocations between

2951the <em class="gene-name">

2952FOXO1</em>

2953 gene on chromosome 13 and either the <em class="gene-name">

2954PAX3</em>

2955 gene on chromosome 2 (t(2;13)(q35;q14)) or the

2956<em class="gene-name">

2957PAX7</em>

2958 gene on chromosome 1 (t(1;13)(p36;q14)).[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

29598</a>

2960-<a href="#cit/section_2.10">

296110</a>

2962] Other rare fusions include <em class="gene-name">

2963PAX3</em>

2964::<em class="gene-name">

2965NCOA1</em>

2966 and <em class="gene-name">

2967PAX3</em>

2968::<em class="gene-name">

2969INO80D</em>

2970.[<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

297127</a>

2972]

2973Translocations involving the <em class="gene-name">

2974PAX3</em>

2975 gene occur in approximately 60% of alveolar

2976rhabdomyosarcoma cases, while the <em class="gene-name">

2977PAX7</em>

2978 gene appears to be involved in about 20% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

29798</a>

2980] Patients with solid-variant alveolar histology have a lower incidence of <em class="gene-name">

2981PAX</em>

2982::<em class="gene-name">

2983FOXO1</em>

2984 gene fusions than do patients showing classical alveolar histology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.42">

298542</a>

2986] The alveolar histology that is associated with the <em class="gene-name">

2987PAX7</em>

2988 gene in patients with or without metastatic disease appears to occur at a younger age and may be associated with longer EFS rates than those associated with <em class="gene-name">

2989PAX3</em>

2990 gene rearrangements.[<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

299143</a>

2992-<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

299348</a>

2994] Patients with alveolar histology and the <em class="gene-name">

2995PAX3</em>

2996 gene are older and have a higher incidence of invasive tumor (T2). Around 20% of cases showing alveolar histology have no detectable <em class="gene-name">

2997PAX</em>

2998 gene translocation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.22">

299922</a>

3000,<a href="#cit/section_2.42">

300142</a>

3002] These patients have clinical behaviors, gene alteration patterns, and transcriptomic profiles that align with patients who have embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma and are now classified together with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, as fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

300312</a>

3004,<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

300513</a>

3006,<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

300721</a>

3008-<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

300923</a>

3010]<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_634" tabindex="-1">

3011For the diagnosis of alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, a <em class="gene-name">

3012FOXO1</em>

3013 gene rearrangement may be detected with good sensitivity and specificity using either fluorescence <em>

3014in situ</em>

3015 hybridization or reverse transcription&#8211;polymerase chain reaction.[<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

301649</a>

3017]</p>

3018<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_635" tabindex="-1">

3019 In addition to <em class="gene-name">

3020FOXO1</em>

3021 rearrangements, alveolar tumors are characterized by a lower mutational burden than are fusion-negative tumors, with fewer genes having recurring mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

302227</a>

3023,<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

302428</a>

3025] The most frequently observed alterations in fusion-positive tumors are focal amplification of <em class="gene-name">

3026CDK4</em>

3027 (13%) or <em class="gene-name">

3028MYCN</em>

3029 (10%), with small numbers of patients having recurring mutations in other genes (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

3030BCOR</em>

3031, 6%; <em class="gene-name">

3032NF1</em>

3033, 4%; <em class="gene-name">

3034TP53</em>

3035, 4%; and <em class="gene-name">

3036PIK3CA</em>

3037, 2%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

303824</a>

3039] <em class="gene-name">

3040TP53</em>

3041 mutations in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma appear to connote a high risk of treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

304224</a>

3043]</p>

3044</li>

3045<li>

3046<strong>

3047Spindle cell/sclerosing histology:</strong>

3048 Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma has been proposed as a separate entity in the WHO Classification of Tumors of Soft Tissue and Bone.[<a href="#cit/section_2.50">

304950</a>

3050] Within the spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma category, several entities have distinctive molecular and clinical characteristics, described below.<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_653" tabindex="-1">

3051<strong>

3052Congenital/infantile spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma:</strong>

3053 Several reports have described cases of congenital or infantile spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma with gene fusions involving <em class="gene-name">

3054VGLL2</em>

3055 and <em class="gene-name">

3056NCOA2</em>

3057 (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

3058VGLL2</em>

3059::<em class="gene-name">

3060CITED2</em>

3061, <em class="gene-name">

3062TEAD1</em>

3063::<em class="gene-name">

3064NCOA2</em>

3065, <em class="gene-name">

3066VGLL2</em>

3067::<em class="gene-name">

3068NCOA2</em>

3069, <em class="gene-name">

3070SRF</em>

3071::<em class="gene-name">

3072NCOA2</em>

3073).[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

307415</a>

3075,<a href="#cit/section_2.51">

307651</a>

3077]</p>

3078<div class="pdq-content-list">

3079<ul id="_sm_CDR0000777839_654">

3080<li>

3081For congenital/infantile spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma, a study reported that 10 of 11 patients showed recurrent fusion genes. Most of these patients had truncal primary tumors, and there were no paratesticular tumors. Novel <em class="gene-name">

3082VGLL2</em>

3083 rearrangements were observed in seven patients (63%), including the <em class="gene-name">

3084VGLL2</em>

3085::<em class="gene-name">

3086CITED2</em>

3087 fusion in four patients and the <em class="gene-name">

3088VGLL2</em>

3089::<em class="gene-name">

3090NCOA2</em>

3091 fusion in two patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

309215</a>

3093] Three patients (27%) harbored different <em class="gene-name">

3094NCOA2</em>

3095 gene fusions, including <em class="gene-name">

3096TEAD1</em>

3097::<em class="gene-name">

3098NCOA2</em>

3099 in two patients and <em class="gene-name">

3100SRF</em>

3101::<em class="gene-name">

3102NCOA2</em>

3103 in one patient. In this report, all fusion-positive congenital/infantile spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma patients with long-term follow-up data were alive and well, and no patients developed distant metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

310415</a>

3105]</li>

3106<li>

3107While most studies of congenital/infantile spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma have shown favorable outcomes, it was reported that four patients developed metastatic disease and two patients had fatal outcomes. Disease progression occurred a median of 3.5 years from diagnosis (range, 1&#8211;8 years).[<a href="#cit/section_2.52">

310852</a>

3109] All four patients had unresectable tumors and were treated with chemotherapy. However, most literature reported cases in which surgical resection was achieved. At disease progression, a tumor from one patient had a <em class="gene-name">

3110TP53</em>

3111 mutation, and a tumor from another patient showed a homozygous <em class="gene-name">

3112CDKN2A</em>

3113 and <em class="gene-name">

3114CDKN2B</em>

3115 deletion.</li>

3116<li>

3117A study of 40 patients with congenital/infantile spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma (defined by diagnosis at age &#8804;12 months) found that almost all patients had localized disease (n = 39) and that one-half of patients who underwent molecular testing (13 of 26) had rearrangements of <em class="gene-name">

3118NCOA2</em>

3119 and/or <em class="gene-name">

3120VGLL2</em>

3121.[<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

312216</a>

3123] Because testing was limited to <em class="gene-name">

3124NCOA2</em>

3125 and <em class="gene-name">

3126VGLL2</em>

3127, it is possible that more comprehensive genomic analysis would identify a higher proportion of patients with relevant gene fusions. The 5-year EFS rate for the 13 patients with either a <em class="gene-name">

3128VGLL2</em>

3129 and/or a <em class="gene-name">

3130NCOA2</em>

3131 fusion was 90% (95% CI, &#177;19%), and the overall survival (OS) rate was 100% (95% CI, &#177;9%). </li>

3132<li>

3133Further study is needed to better define the prevalence and prognostic significance of gene rearrangements in <em class="gene-name">

3134VGLL2</em>

3135, <em class="gene-name">

3136NCOA2</em>

3137, and other relevant genes in young children with congenital/infantile spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma.</li>

3138</ul>

3139</div>

3140<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_628" tabindex="-1">

3141<strong>

3142<em class="gene-name">

3143MYOD1</em>

3144-mutant spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma:</strong>

3145 In older children and adults with spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma, a specific <em class="gene-name">

3146MYOD1</em>

3147 mutation (p.L122R) has been observed in a large proportion of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

314815</a>

3149,<a href="#cit/section_2.53">

315053</a>

3151-<a href="#cit/section_2.55">

315255</a>

3153] In the combined cohort of COG and U.K. rhabdomyosarcoma patients (n = 641), mutations in <em class="gene-name">

3154MYOD1</em>

3155 were found in 3% (17 of 515) of all fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma cases and in no fusion-positive cases. The presenting age of patients with <em class="gene-name">

3156MYOD1</em>

3157 mutations was 10.8 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

315824</a>

3159] Most cases in this cohort showed spindle or sclerosing features, but cases with densely packed cells that mimicked the dense pattern of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma were also observed. Most cases in this cohort (15 of 17, 88%) had either head and neck or parameningeal region primary sites. Activating <em class="gene-name">

3160PIK3CA</em>

3161 mutations are seen in about one-half of cases with <em class="gene-name">

3162MYOD1</em>

3163 mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

316417</a>

3165,<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

316624</a>

3167] The presence of the <em class="gene-name">

3168MYOD1</em>

3169 mutation is associated with a markedly increased risk of local and distant failure.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

317015</a>

3171,<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

317224</a>

3173,<a href="#cit/section_2.53">

317453</a>

3175,<a href="#cit/section_2.54">

317654</a>

3177] </p>

3178<p id="_sm_CDR0000777839_655" tabindex="-1">

3179<strong>

3180Intraosseous spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma:</strong>

3181 Primary intraosseous rhabdomyosarcoma is a very uncommon presentation for rhabdomyosarcoma. Most cases present with gene rearrangements involving <em class="gene-name">

3182TFCP2</em>

3183, with either <em class="gene-name">

3184FUS</em>

3185 or <em class="gene-name">

3186EWSR1</em>

3187.[<a href="#cit/section_2.56">

318856</a>

3189-<a href="#cit/section_2.60">

319060</a>

3191] Rhabdomyosarcoma with a <em class="gene-name">

3192FUS</em>

3193::<em class="gene-name">

3194TFCP2</em>

3195 or <em class="gene-name">

3196EWSR1</em>

3197::<em class="gene-name">

3198TFCP2</em>

3199 gene fusion most commonly presents in young adults, although cases in older children and adolescents have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_2.56">

320056</a>

3201,<a href="#cit/section_2.59">

320259</a>

3203,<a href="#cit/section_2.60">

320460</a>

3205] Craniofacial bones are the most common primary tumor location, and positivity for <em class="gene-name">

3206ALK</em>

3207 and cytokeratins by immunohistochemistry is commonly observed. Other characteristics of this entity include a complex genomic profile, with most cases showing deletion of the <em class="gene-name">

3208CDKN2A</em>

3209 tumor suppressor gene.[<a href="#cit/section_2.59">

321059</a>

3211] Intraosseous spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma with a <em class="gene-name">

3212FUS</em>

3213::<em class="gene-name">

3214TFCP2</em>

3215 or <em class="gene-name">

3216EWSR1</em>

3217::<em class="gene-name">

3218TFCP2</em>

3219 gene fusion shows an aggressive clinical course. In one study, the median OS was only 8 months.[<a href="#cit/section_2.59">

322059</a>

3221]</p>

3222</li>

3223</ol>

3224</div>

3225</section>

3226</section>

Mod Pathol 34 (9): 1750-1762, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34017064&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34017064&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3380[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3381</li>

3382<li id="section_2.40">

3383McCluggage WG, Foulkes WD: DICER1-associated sarcomas: towards a unified nomenclature. Mod Pathol 34 (6): 1226-1228, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32572152&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32572152&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3384[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3385</li>

Clin Cancer Res 24 (10): 2251-2261, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29343557&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29343557&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3388[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3389</li>

3390<li id="section_2.42">

3391Parham DM, Qualman SJ, Teot L, et al.: Correlation between histology and PAX/FKHR fusion status in alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: a report from the Children's Oncology Group. Am J Surg Pathol 31 (6): 895-901, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17527077&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17527077&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3465</div>

3466

3467 </section>

3468

3469

3470

3471 <section id="_128">

3472

3473 <h2>

3474Stage Information for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</h2>

3475

3476 <div id="_section_128" class="pdq-sections">

3477<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

3478<h6>

3479In This Section</h6>

3480<ul>

3481<li>

3482<a href="#_804_toc">

3483Staging Evaluation</a>

3484</li>

3485<li>

3486<a href="#_806_toc">

3487Assessment of Extent of Disease<ul>

3488<li>

3489<a href="#_807_toc">

3490Assignment of clinical Stage</a>

3491</li>

3492<li>

3493<a href="#_808_toc">

3494Assignment of Group</a>

3495</li>

3496<li>

3497<a href="#_809_toc">

3498Assignment of Risk Group</a>

3499</li>

3500</ul>

3501</a>

3502</li>

3503</ul>

3504</nav>

3505<section id="_804">

3506<h3 id="_804_toc">

3507Staging Evaluation</h3>

3508<p id="_376" tabindex="-1">

3509Before a suspected tumor mass is biopsied, imaging studies of the mass and baseline laboratory studies should be obtained. After the patient is diagnosed with rhabdomyosarcoma, an extensive evaluation to determine the extent of the disease should be performed before instituting therapy. This evaluation typically includes the following:</p>

3510<div class="pdq-content-list">

3511<ol id="_1907">

3512<li>

3513Chest x-ray.</li>

3514<li>

3515Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest.<p id="_1849" tabindex="-1">

3516The European Paediatric Soft Tissue Sarcoma Study Group reviewed 367 patients enrolled in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379457">

3517CCLG-EPSSG-RMS-2005 (NCT00379457)</a>

3518 study.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

35191</a>

3520][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3521Level of evidence B4</a>

3522] By prospective study design, patients with indeterminate pulmonary nodules identified on baseline CT scan of the chest (defined as &#8804;4 pulmonary nodules measuring &lt;5 mm or 1 nodule measuring &#8805;5 mm and &lt;10 mm) received the same treatment as did patients with no pulmonary nodules identified on baseline CT of the chest. Rates of event-free survival and overall survival for both groups were the same. The authors concluded that indeterminate pulmonary nodules at diagnosis, as defined in this summary, do not affect outcome in patients with localized rhabdomyosarcoma.</p>

3523</li>

3524<li>

3525CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis (for lower extremity or genitourinary primary tumors).</li>

3526<li>

3527Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the base of the skull and brain (for parameningeal primary tumors) and of the primary site of other nonparameningeal primary tumors, as appropriate.</li>

3528<li>

3529Regional lymph node evaluation.<div class="pdq-content-list">

3530<ul id="_1908">

3531<li>

3532CT or MRI: Cross-sectional imaging (CT or MRI scan) of regional lymph nodes should be obtained. </li>

3533<li>

3534Lymph node evaluation: Clearly enlarged lymph nodes should be biopsied when possible. Sentinel lymph node biopsy is more accurate than random lymph node sampling and is preferred in patients with extremity and trunk rhabdomyosarcoma, in which enlarged lymph nodes are not revealed on imaging or by physical examination.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

35352</a>

3536] Many studies have demonstrated that sentinel lymph node biopsies can be safely performed in children with rhabdomyosarcoma, and tumor-positive biopsies alter the treatment plan.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

35372</a>

3538-<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

35397</a>

3540]<p id="_915" tabindex="-1">

3541Pathological evaluation of normal-appearing regional nodes is currently required for all Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee of the Children's Oncology Group (COG-STS) study participants with extremity and trunk primary rhabdomyosarcoma. In boys aged 10 years and older with paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma, retroperitoneal node sampling (ipsilateral nerve sparing) is currently required for normal-appearing lymph nodes because microscopic tumor is often documented, even when the nodes are not enlarged.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

35428</a>

3543] The International Society of Paediatric Oncology Malignant Mesenchymal Tumour Group has confirmed this is a necessary approach.[<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

35449</a>

3545] For more information, see the <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_552">

3546Regional and in-transit lymph nodes for extremity tumors</a>

3547 section.</p>

3548</li>

3549<li>

3550Positron emission tomography (PET): PET with fluorine F 18-fludeoxyglucose scans can identify areas of possible metastatic disease not seen by other imaging modalities.[<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

355110</a>

3552-<a href="#cit/section_3.12">

355312</a>

3554]</li>

3555</ul>

3556</div>

3557<p id="_396" tabindex="-1">

3558 The efficacy of these imaging studies for identifying involved lymph nodes or other sites of disease is important for staging, and PET imaging is recommended on current COG-STS treatment protocols.</p>

3559</li>

3560<li>

3561Bilateral bone marrow aspirates and biopsies <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_718">

3562for selected patients</a>

3563.</li>

3564<li>

3565Bone scan <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_718">

3566for selected patients</a>

3567.</li>

3568</ol>

3569</div>

3570<p id="_718" tabindex="-1">

3571A retrospective study of 1,687 children with rhabdomyosarcoma enrolled in Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma

3572Study Group (IRSG) and COG studies from 1991 to 2004 suggests those with localized negative regional lymph nodes, noninvasive embryonal tumors, and Group I alveolar tumors (about one-third of patients) can have limited staging procedures that eliminate bone marrow and bone scan examinations at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.13">

357313</a>

3574] </p>

3575</section>

3576<section id="_806">

3577<h3 id="_806_toc">

3578Assessment of Extent of Disease</h3>

3579<p id="_255" tabindex="-1">

3580Assessing extent of disease of rhabdomyosarcoma is complex. The process includes the following steps: </p>

3581<div class="pdq-content-list">

3582<ol id="_256">

3583<li>

3584<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_807">

3585Assignment of Stage</a>

3586: Stage is a clinical assessment determined by primary site, tumor size (longest diameter), and clinical (imaging) presence or absence of regional lymph node and/or distant metastases (TNM criteria).</li>

3587<li>

3588<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_808">

3589Assignment of Group</a>

3590: Group is determined by status of the initial surgical procedure (resection/biopsy), with pathological assessment of the tumor margin and of lymph node involvement, before the initiation of therapy.</li>

3591<li>

3592<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_809">

3593Assignment of Risk Group</a>

3594: Determined by Stage, Group, and fusion status.</li>

3595</ol>

3596</div>

3597<p id="_18" tabindex="-1">

3598Prognosis for children with rhabdomyosarcoma depends

3599predominantly on the primary tumor site, tumor size, surgical-pathological Group, presence or absence of nodal disease and distant metastasis, and fusion status. Favorable

3600prognostic groups were identified in previous IRSG studies, and treatment plans were designed on the basis of patient assignment to different treatment protocols according to prognosis.</p>

3601<section id="_807">

3602<h4 id="_807_toc">

3603Assignment of clinical Stage</h4>

3604<p id="_397" tabindex="-1">

3605Current COG-STS protocols for rhabdomyosarcoma use the TNM-based pretreatment staging system that incorporates the primary tumor site, presence or absence of tumor invasion of surrounding tissues, tumor size, clinical (imaging) assessment of regional lymph node status, and the presence or absence of metastases. This staging system is described in <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_612">

3606Table 4</a>

3607 below.[<a href="#cit/section_3.14">

360814</a>

3609-<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

361016</a>

3611]</p>

3612<p id="_275" tabindex="-1">

3613Terms defining the TNM criteria are described in <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_276">

3614Table 3</a>

3615.</p>

3616<table id="_276" class="table-default expandable-container">

3617<caption>

3618Table 3. Definition of Terms<span class="sup">

3619a</span>

3620</caption>

3621<colgroup>

3622<col width="50.00%">

3623<col width="50.00%">

3624</colgroup>

3625<THead>

3626<tr>

3627<th>

3628Term</th>

3629<th>

3630Definition</th>

3631</tr>

3632</THead>

3633<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

3634<tr>

3635<td colspan="2">

3636CSF = cerebrospinal fluid; CT = computed tomography; MRI = magnetic resonance imaging.</td>

3637</tr>

3638<tr>

3639<td colspan="2">

3640<span class="sup">

3641a</span>

3642Adapted from Crane et al.[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

364316</a>

3644]</td>

3645</tr>

3646</TFoot>

3647<tbody>

3648<tr>

3649<td>

3650Favorable site</td>

3651<td>

3652Orbit; head and neck (excluding parameningeal); genitourinary tract (nonbladder/nonprostate).</td>

3653</tr>

3654<tr>

3655<td>

3656Unfavorable site</td>

3657<td>

3658Any site other than a favorable site.</td>

3659</tr>

3660<tr>

3661<td>

3662T1</td>

3663<td>

3664Tumor confined to anatomical site of origin.</td>

3665</tr>

3666<tr>

3667<td>

3668T2</td>

3669<td>

3670Extension and/or fixative to surrounding tissue.</td>

3671</tr>

3672<tr>

3673<td>

3674a</td>

3675<td>

3676Tumor &#8804;5 cm in longest diameter.</td>

3677</tr>

3678<tr>

3679<td>

3680b</td>

3681<td>

3682Tumor &gt;5 cm in longest diameter.</td>

3683</tr>

3684<tr>

3685<td>

3686N0</td>

3687<td>

3688Regional nodes not clinically involved.</td>

3689</tr>

3690<tr>

3691<td>

3692N1</td>

3693<td>

3694Regional nodes clinically involved as defined as &gt;1 cm measured in short axis on CT or MRI.</td>

3695</tr>

3696<tr>

3697<td>

3698NX</td>

3699<td>

3700Clinical status of regional nodes unknown (especially sites that preclude lymph node evaluation).</td>

3701</tr>

3702<tr>

3703<td>

3704M0</td>

3705<td>

3706No distant metastases.</td>

3707</tr>

3708<tr>

3709<td>

3710M1</td>

3711<td>

3712Distant metastases present (Note: the presence of positive cytology in pleural fluid, abdominal fluid, or CSF and the presence of pleural or peritoneal implants are considered evidence of metastases).</td>

3713</tr>

3714</tbody>

3715</table>

3716<table id="_612" class="table-default expandable-container">

3717<caption>

3718Table 4. Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee of the Children's Oncology Group: Pretreatment Staging System</caption>

3719<colgroup>

3720<col width="20.00%">

3721<col width="20.00%">

3722<col width="20.00%">

3723<col width="20.00%">

3724<col width="20.00%">

3725</colgroup>

3726<THead>

3727<tr>

3728<th>

3729Stage </th>

3730<th>

3731Sites of Primary Tumor</th>

3732<th>

3733Tumor Size<span class="sup">

3734c</span>

3743</th>

3749<span class="sup">

3750c</span>

3751Tumor size: (a) &lt;5 cm in longest diameter; (b) &gt;5 cm in longest diameter.</td>

3752</tr>

3754<td colspan="5">

3755<span class="sup">

3756d</span>

3758Table 3</a>

3759.</td>

3801b</td>

3804</tr>

3806<td>

38074</td>

3808<td>

3809Any site</td>

3810<td>

3811a or b</td>

3812<td>

3813N0 or N1 or NX</td>

3814<td>

3815M1</td>

3816</tr>

3817</tbody>

3818</table>

3819</section>

3820<section id="_808">

3821<h4 id="_808_toc">

3822Assignment of Group</h4>

3823<p id="_391" tabindex="-1">

3824The IRS-I, IRS-II, IRS-III, and IRS-IV studies prescribed treatment plans on the basis of the surgical-pathological Group system. In this system, Groups are defined by the

3825extent of disease and by the completeness or extent of initial surgical resection after

3826pathological review of the tumor specimen(s). The definitions for these

3827Groups are shown in <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_257">

3828Table 5</a>

3829 below.[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

383016</a>

3831-<a href="#cit/section_3.19">

383219</a>

3833]</p>

3834<table id="_257" class="table-default expandable-container">

3835<caption>

3836Table 5. Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee of the Children's Oncology Group: Surgical-Pathological Group System<span class="sup">

3837a</span>

3838</caption>

3839<colgroup>

3840<col width="15.92%">

3841<col width="28.82%">

3842<col width="55.25%">

3843</colgroup>

3844<THead>

3845<tr>

3846<th>

3847Group</th>

3848<th>

3849Incidence</th>

3850<th>

3851Definition</th>

3852</tr>

3853</THead>

3854<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

3855<tr>

3856<td colspan="3">

3857CSF = cerebrospinal fluid.</td>

3858</tr>

3859<tr>

3860<td colspan="3">

3861<span class="sup">

3862a</span>

3863Adapted from Crane et al.[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

386416</a>

3865]</td>

3866</tr>

3867</TFoot>

3868<tbody>

3869<tr>

3870<td>

3871I</td>

3872<td>

3873Approximately 15%</td>

3874<td>

3875Localized disease, completely resected (regional lymph nodes not involved).</td>

3876</tr>

3877<tr>

3878<td>

3879II</td>

3880<td>

3881Approximately 16%</td>

3882<td>

3883Localized disease, grossly resected with microscopic residual disease or regional disease, grossly resected with or without microscopic residual disease. (a) Localized disease, grossly resected tumor with microscopic residual disease, regional nodes not involved. (b) Regional disease with involved nodes, completely resected with no microscopic residual disease (including most distal node is histologically negative). (c) Regional disease with involved nodes, grossly resected with evidence of microscopic residual and/or histological involvement of the most distal regional node in the dissection.</td>

3884</tr>

3885<tr>

3886<td>

3887III</td>

3888<td>

3889Approximately 50%</td>

3890<td>

3891Localized or regional disease, biopsy only or incomplete resection with gross residual disease.</td>

3892</tr>

3893<tr>

3894<td>

3895IV</td>

3896<td>

3897Approximately 20%</td>

3898<td>

3899Distant metastatic disease present at onset. Although not limited to these, the following are considered evidence of metastatic disease: (a) presence of positive cytology in CSF, (b) positive cytology in pleural or abdominal fluids, (c) presence of implants on pleural or peritoneal surfaces. (Note: Regional lymph node involvement and adjacent organ infiltration are not considered metastatic disease. Presence of a pleural effusion or ascites, without positive cytological evaluation, is not considered evidence of metastatic disease.)</td>

3900</tr>

3901</tbody>

3902</table>

3903</section>

3904<section id="_809">

3905<h4 id="_809_toc">

3906Assignment of Risk Group</h4>

3907<p id="_398" tabindex="-1">

3908After patients are categorized by Stage and surgical-pathological Group, a Risk Group is assigned on the basis of the Stage, Group, and <em class="gene-name">

3909FOXO1</em>

3910 fusion status. The planned COG low-risk study will also use <em class="gene-name">

3911TP53</em>

3912 and <em class="gene-name">

3913MYOD1</em>

3914 mutation status to assign risk group. Patients are classified for protocol purposes as having a low risk, intermediate risk, or high risk of disease recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_3.20">

391520</a>

3916-<a href="#cit/section_3.22">

391722</a>

3918] Treatment assignment is based on Risk Group, as shown in <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_348">

3919Table 6</a>

3920.</p>

3921<table id="_348" class="table-default expandable-container">

3922<caption>

3923Table 6. Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee of the Children's Oncology Group: Rhabdomyosarcoma Risk Group Classification<span class="sup">

3924a</span>

3925 </caption>

3926<colgroup>

3927<col width="25.00%">

3928<col width="25.00%">

3929<col width="25.00%">

3930<col width="25.00%">

3931</colgroup>

3932<THead>

3933<tr>

3934<th>

3935Risk Group </th>

3936<th>

3937Fusion Status/Molecular Profile</th>

3938<th>

3939Stage</th>

3940<th>

3941Group</th>

3942</tr>

3943</THead>

3944<tbody>

3945<tr>

3946<td>

3947Very low risk</td>

3948<td>

3949Fusion negative: <em class="gene-name">

3950MYOD1</em>

3951 wild-type, <em class="gene-name">

3952TP53</em>

3953 wild-type</td>

3954<td>

39551</td>

3956<td>

3957I</td>

3958</tr>

3959<tr>

3960<td rowspan="2">

3961Low risk </td>

3962<td rowspan="2">

3963Fusion negative: <em class="gene-name">

3964MYOD1</em>

3965 wild-type, <em class="gene-name">

3966TP53</em>

3967 wild-type</td>

3968<td>

39691</td>

3970<td>

3971II, III (orbit only)</td>

3972</tr>

3973<tr>

3974<td>

39752</td>

3976<td>

3977I, II</td>

3978</tr>

3979<tr>

3980<td rowspan="5">

3981Intermediate risk</td>

3982<td rowspan="4">

3983Fusion negative</td>

3984<td>

39851</td>

3986<td>

3987III (nonorbit)</td>

3988</tr>

3989<tr>

3990<td>

39912, 3</td>

3992<td>

3993III</td>

3994</tr>

3995<tr>

3996<td>

39973</td>

3998<td>

3999I, II</td>

4000</tr>

4001<tr>

4002<td>

40034</td>

4004<td>

4005IV (age &lt;10 years)</td>

4006</tr>

4007<tr>

4008<td>

4009Fusion positive</td>

4010<td>

40111, 2, 3</td>

4012<td>

4013I, II, III</td>

4014</tr>

4015<tr>

4016<td rowspan="2">

4017High risk </td>

4018<td>

4019Fusion positive</td>

4020<td>

40214</td>

4022<td>

4023IV</td>

4024</tr>

4025<tr>

4026<td>

4027Fusion negative</td>

4028<td>

40294</td>

4030<td>

4031IV (age &#8805;10 years)</td>

4032</tr>

4033<tr>

4034<td colspan="4">

4035<span class="sup">

4036a</span>

4037Adapted from Crane et al.[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

403816</a>

4039]</td>

4040</tr>

4041</tbody>

4042</table>

4043<p id="_1876" tabindex="-1">

4044The most recent COG protocols use fusion status and molecular findings, as opposed to histology, to define Risk Groups.</p>

4045</section>

4046</section>

4141 </section>

4142

4143

4144

4145 <section id="_129">

4146

4147 <h2>

4148Treatment Option Overview for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</h2>

4149

4150 <div id="_section_129" class="pdq-sections">

4151<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

4152<h6>

4153In This Section</h6>

4154<ul>

4155<li>

4156<a href="#_810_toc">

4157Multimodality Therapy</a>

4158</li>

4159</ul>

4160</nav>

4161<section id="_810">

4162<h3 id="_810_toc">

4163Multimodality Therapy</h3>

4164<p id="_39" tabindex="-1">

4165All children with rhabdomyosarcoma require multimodality therapy with systemic chemotherapy, in conjunction with either surgery, radiation therapy (RT), or both modalities to maximize local tumor control.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

41661</a>

4167-<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

41683</a>

4169] Surgical resection is performed before chemotherapy if it will not result in disfigurement, functional compromise, or organ dysfunction. If this is not possible, only an initial biopsy is performed.</p>

4170<p id="_811" tabindex="-1">

4171Low-risk Group I (complete tumor resection, about 15% of patients) patients are treated with multiagent chemotherapy after surgical resection. Group II patients typically require chemotherapy and local tumor bed irradiation (about 20% of patients). Most patients (about 50%) have Group III (gross residual) disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

41724</a>

4173] After initial chemotherapy, Group III patients receive definitive RT for local control of the primary tumor. Some patients with initially unresected tumors may undergo delayed primary excision after induction chemotherapy to remove residual tumor before the initiation of RT. This is appropriate only if the delayed excision is deemed feasible with acceptable functional and cosmetic outcome and if a grossly complete resection is anticipated. If a delayed primary excision results in complete resection or microscopic residual disease, a modest (15%&#8211;30%) reduction in RT could be utilized.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

41745</a>

4175] Patients with Group IV disease (about 15%) receive chemotherapy and RT to the primary tumor and metastatic disease sites when feasible.</p>

4176<p id="_1909" tabindex="-1">

4177RT is given to clinically suspicious lymph nodes (detected by palpation or imaging) unless the suspicious lymph nodes are biopsied and shown to be free of rhabdomyosarcoma. RT is also administered to lymph node basins where a sentinel lymph node biopsy has identified microscopic disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

41785</a>

4179]</p>

4180<p id="_528" tabindex="-1">

4181The discussion of treatment options for children

4182with rhabdomyosarcoma is divided into the following sections:</p>

4183<div class="pdq-content-list">

4184<ul id="_594">

4185<li>

4186<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_529">

4187Surgery (local control management)</a>

4188.</li>

4189<li>

4190<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_532">

4191RT (local control management)</a>

4192.</li>

4193<li>

4194<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_544">

4195Surgery and RT by primary site of disease (local control management)</a>

4196.</li>

4197<li>

4198<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_133">

4199Chemotherapy</a>

4200.</li>

4201</ul>

4202</div>

4203<p id="_212" tabindex="-1">

4204Rhabdomyosarcoma treatment options used by the Children's Oncology Group (COG) and by groups in Europe (as exemplified by trials from the Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee of the COG [COG-STS], the Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study Group [IRSG], and the International Society of Pediatric Oncology Malignant Mesenchymal Tumor [MMT] Group) differ in management and overall treatment philosophy, as noted below:[<a href="#cit/section_4.2">

42052</a>

4206]</p>

4207<div class="pdq-content-list">

4208<ul id="_780">

4209<li>

4210The primary objective of the COG-STS, after the initial surgical resection or biopsy and induction chemotherapy, has been to use additional local control therapy, predominantly with RT or surgical resection when appropriate . Event-free survival is the target end point, attempting to avoid relapse and subsequent salvage therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

42113</a>

4212] </li>

4213<li>

4214 In the MMT trials, the main objective has been to reduce the use of local therapies using initial front-line chemotherapy, followed by second-line therapy in the presence of poor response. Subsequent surgical resection is preferred over RT, which is used only after incomplete resection, documented regional lymph node involvement, or a poor clinical response to initial chemotherapy. This approach is designed to avoid major surgical procedures and long-term damaging effects from RT. Some patients have been spared aggressive local therapy, which may reduce the potential for morbidities associated with such therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

42151</a>

4216-<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

42173</a>

4218]</li>

4219</ul>

4220</div>

4221<p id="_781" tabindex="-1">

4222The MMT Group approach led to an overall survival (OS) rate of 71% in the European MMT89 study, compared with an OS rate of 84% in the IRS-IV study. Similarly, EFS rates at 5 years were 57% in the MMT89 study versus 78% in the IRS-IV study. Differences in outcome were most striking for patients with extremity and head and neck nonparameningeal tumors. Failure-free survival was lower for patients with bladder/prostate primary tumors who did not receive RT as part of their initial treatment, but there was no difference in OS between the two strategies for these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

42236</a>

4224] The overall impression is that survival for most patient subsets is superior with the use of early local therapy, including RT.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

42251</a>

4226-<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

42273</a>

4228]</p>

4229</section>

4230<h6 do-not-show="toc">

4231References</h6>

4232<ol>

4233<li id="section_4.1">

4234Donaldson SS, Meza J, Breneman JC, et al.: Results from the IRS-IV randomized trial of hyperfractionated radiotherapy in children with rhabdomyosarcoma--a report from the IRSG. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 51 (3): 718-28, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11597814&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11597814&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4235[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4236</li>

4237<li id="section_4.2">

4238Stevens MC, Rey A, Bouvet N, et al.: Treatment of nonmetastatic rhabdomyosarcoma in childhood and adolescence: third study of the International Society of Paediatric Oncology--SIOP Malignant Mesenchymal Tumor 89. J Clin Oncol 23 (12): 2618-28, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15728225&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15728225&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4243[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4244</li>

4245<li id="section_4.4">

4247<li id="section_4.5">

4248Wolden SL, Lyden ER, Arndt CA, et al.: Local Control for Intermediate-Risk Rhabdomyosarcoma: Results From D9803 According to Histology, Group, Site, and Size: A Report From the Children's Oncology Group. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 93 (5): 1071-6, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26581144&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26581144&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4249[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4250</li>

4251<li id="section_4.6">

4252Rodeberg DA, Anderson JR, Arndt CA, et al.: Comparison of outcomes based on treatment algorithms for rhabdomyosarcoma of the bladder/prostate: combined results from the Children's Oncology Group, German Cooperative Soft Tissue Sarcoma Study, Italian Cooperative Group, and International Society of Pediatric Oncology Malignant Mesenchymal Tumors Committee. Int J Cancer 128 (5): 1232-9, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20473932&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20473932&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4253[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4254</li>

4255</ol>

4256</div>

4257

4258 </section>

4259

4260

4261

4262 <section id="_802">

4263

4264 <h2>

4265Special Considerations for the Treatment of Children With Cancer</h2>

4266

4267 <div id="_section_802" class="pdq-sections">

4268<p id="_3" tabindex="-1">

4269Cancer in children and adolescents is rare, although the overall incidence has been slowly increasing since 1975.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

42701</a>

4271] Children and adolescents with

4272cancer should be referred to medical centers that have a multidisciplinary team

4273of cancer specialists with experience treating the cancers that occur during

4274childhood and adolescence. This multidisciplinary team approach incorporates the skills

4275of the following individuals to ensure that

4276children receive treatment, supportive care, and rehabilitation that will

4277achieve optimal survival and quality of life: </p>

4278<div class="pdq-content-list">

4279<ul id="_803">

4280<li>

4281Primary care physician.</li>

4282<li>

4283Pediatric surgeon.</li>

4284<li>

4285Radiation

4286oncologist.</li>

4287<li>

4288Pediatric oncologist and hematologist.</li>

4289<li>

4290Pediatric radiologist.</li>

4291<li>

4292Rehabilitation specialist.</li>

4293<li>

4294Pediatric nurse specialist.</li>

4295<li>

4296Social workers.</li>

4297<li>

4298Psychologist.</li>

4299</ul>

4300</div>

4301<p id="_156" tabindex="-1">

4302The American Academy of Pediatrics has outlined guidelines for pediatric cancer

4303centers and their role in the treatment of pediatric patients with cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

43042</a>

4305] At these pediatric

4306cancer centers, clinical trials are available for most types of cancer

4307that occur in children and adolescents, and the opportunity to participate is offered to most patients/families. Clinical trials for

4308children and adolescents with cancer are generally designed to compare

4309potentially better therapy with current standard therapy.

4310Most of the progress made in identifying curative therapies for

4311childhood cancers has been achieved through clinical trials. Information about

4312ongoing clinical trials is available from the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials">

4313NCI website</a>

4314.</p>

4315<h6 do-not-show="toc">

4316References</h6>

4317<ol>

4318<li id="section_5.1">

4319Smith MA, Altekruse SF, Adamson PC, et al.: Declining childhood and adolescent cancer mortality. Cancer 120 (16): 2497-506, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24853691&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24853691&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4320[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4321</li>

4322<li id="section_5.2">

4323American Academy of Pediatrics: Standards for pediatric cancer centers. Pediatrics 134 (2): 410-4, 2014. <a href="https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/410" title="https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/134/2/410">

4324Also available online</a>

4325. Last accessed May 19, 2023.</li>

4326</ol>

4327</div>

4328

4329 </section>

4330

4331

4332

4333 <section id="_130">

4334

4335 <h2>

4336Treatment of Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</h2>

4337

4338 <div id="_section_130" class="pdq-sections">

4339<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

4340<h6>

4341In This Section</h6>

4342<ul>

4343<li>

4344<a href="#_529_toc">

4345Surgery (Local Control Management) </a>

4346</li>

4347<li>

4348<a href="#_532_toc">

4349RT (Local Control Management)<ul>

4350<li>

4351<a href="#_821_toc">

4352External-beam RT</a>

4353</li>

4354<li>

4355<a href="#_824_toc">

4356Brachytherapy</a>

4357</li>

4358<li>

4359<a href="#_825_toc">

4360Local control treatment of children aged 3 years and younger</a>

4361</li>

4362</ul>

4363</a>

4364</li>

4365<li>

4366<a href="#_544_toc">

4367Surgery and RT by Primary Site of Disease (Local Control Management)<ul>

4368<li>

4369<a href="#_546_toc">

4370Head and neck sites</a>

4371</li>

4372<li>

4373<a href="#_550_toc">

4374Extremity sites</a>

4375</li>

4376<li>

4377<a href="#_556_toc">

4378Truncal sites</a>

4379</li>

4380<li>

4381<a href="#_561_toc">

4382Genitourinary system sites</a>

4383</li>

4384<li>

4385<a href="#_568_toc">

4386Unusual primary sites</a>

4387</li>

4388<li>

4389<a href="#_2099_toc">

4390Unknown primary sites</a>

4391</li>

4392<li>

4393<a href="#_574_toc">

4394Metastatic disease</a>

4395</li>

4396</ul>

4397</a>

4398</li>

4399<li>

4400<a href="#_133_toc">

4401Chemotherapy<ul>

4402<li>

4403<a href="#_137_toc">

4404 Low-risk Group</a>

4405</li>

4406<li>

4407<a href="#_234_toc">

4408Intermediate-risk Group</a>

4409</li>

4410<li>

4411<a href="#_239_toc">

4412High-risk Group</a>

4413</li>

4414</ul>

4415</a>

4416</li>

4417<li>

4418<a href="#_349_toc">

4419Other Therapeutic Approaches</a>

4420</li>

4421<li>

4422<a href="#_1871_toc">

4423Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

4424</li>

4425<li>

4426<a href="#_TrialSearch_130_sid_6_toc">

4427Current Clinical Trials</a>

4428</li>

4429</ul>

4430</nav>
