4431<p id="_531" tabindex="-1">

4432Optimizing care for patients with rhabdomyosarcoma requires a multidisciplinary team approach. All patients require chemotherapy and effective local tumor control. Because rhabdomyosarcoma can arise from multiple sites, surgical care decisions and radiotherapeutic options must be tailored to the specific aspects of each site and should be discussed with a multidisciplinary team, including representatives of those specialties and pediatric oncologists.

4433These multidisciplinary discussions ideally occur at the time of diagnosis, either before or after the diagnostic biopsy and before the initiation of therapy. </p>

4434<p id="_2056" tabindex="-1">

4435Local control remains a significant problem in children with rhabdomyosarcoma. The predominant site of treatment failure in patients with initially localized rhabdomyosarcoma has been local recurrence. In the Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study Group (IRS)-II trial, of patients who achieved a complete remission with chemotherapy and surgery, almost 20% of patients with Groups I to III disease relapsed locally or regionally, and 30% of patients with Group IV disease relapsed locally or regionally. Local or regional relapses accounted for 70% to 80% of all relapses in children with Groups I to III disease and 46% of all relapses in patients with Group IV disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

44361</a>

4437]</p>

4438<p id="_2057" tabindex="-1">

4439Both surgery and radiation therapy (RT) are procedures primarily focused on local tumor control, but each treatment has risks and benefits.</p>

4440<p id="_1910" tabindex="-1">

4441For more information about surgical and radiotherapeutic management of the more common primary sites, see the <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_544">

4442Surgery and RT by Primary Site of Disease (Local Control Management)</a>

4443 section.</p>

4444<p id="_1947" tabindex="-1">

4445Treatment options for childhood rhabdomyosarcoma include the following:</p>

4446<div class="pdq-content-list">

4447<ol id="_1948">

4448<li>

4449<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_529">

4450Surgery (local control management)</a>

4451.</li>

4452<li>

4453<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_532">

4454RT (local control management)</a>

4455.</li>

4456<li>

4457<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_544">

4458Surgery and RT by primary site of disease (local control management)</a>

4459.</li>

4460<li>

4461<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_133">

4462Chemotherapy</a>

4463.</li>

4464</ol>

4465</div>

4466<section id="_529">

4467<h3 id="_529_toc">

4468Surgery (Local Control Management) </h3>

4469<p id="_1911" tabindex="-1">

4470Surgical removal of the entire tumor should be considered initially, but only if functional and cosmetic impairment will not result.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

44712</a>

4472] With that stipulation, complete gross resection of the primary tumor, with a surrounding margin of normal tissue, and biopsy are recommended by the authors of one study. For some tumor sites, sampling of regional draining lymph nodes is necessary. Children's Oncology Group (COG) protocols require regional draining node sampling in extremity tumors and paratesticular tumors in patients older than 10 years. Important exceptions to achieving an R0 resection (negative margins) are in tumors of the orbit and the genitourinary region.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

44733</a>

4474,<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

44754</a>

4476] Additionally, the principle of wide and

4477complete resection of the primary tumor is less applicable for patients known to

4478have metastatic disease at the initial operation, but it is an appropriate approach

4479if easily accomplished without loss of form (cosmesis) and function. </p>

4480<p id="_635" tabindex="-1">

4481Patients with microscopic residual tumor after

4482their initial surgery appear to have improved prognoses if a

4483second operation (primary re-excision) to resect the primary tumor bed

4484before beginning chemotherapy can completely remove the tumor without loss of form and function.[<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

44855</a>

4486] </p>

4487<p id="_637" tabindex="-1">

4488There is no evidence that debulking surgery (i.e., surgery that is expected to leave macroscopic residual tumor) improves outcomes, compared with biopsy alone; therefore, debulking surgery is not recommended for patients with rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

44896</a>

4490][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4491Level of evidence B4</a>

4492] Rather than debulking a tumor at the time of initial biopsy, it is preferable to delay definitive surgery until after induction chemotherapy (delayed primary excision). In a retrospective study of 73 selected patients, delayed primary excision allowed for the identification of viable tumor that remained after initial chemotherapy. Of the 73 patients, 65 also received RT. Patients with viable tumor had shorter event-free survival (EFS) rates than did patients without viable tumor, but there was no effect on overall survival (OS).[<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

44937</a>

4494] There is also no evidence that performing surgical resection on residual masses detected by imaging at completion of all planned therapy improves outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

44958</a>

4496] Thus, residual masses can be monitored without therapeutic intervention.</p>

4497<p id="_2088" tabindex="-1">

4498For children with low-risk rhabdomyosarcoma, local control was not diminished with reduced doses of RT after surgical resection.[<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

44999</a>

4500] Subsequently, delayed primary excision was evaluated by the Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee of the COG (COG-STS) in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002995">

4501D9602</a>

4502 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

4503D9803</a>

4504 studies.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

45058</a>

4506] Delayed primary excision at week 12 after induction chemotherapy was completed in 45% to 54% of patients with Group III rhabdomyosarcoma tumors when appropriate (anticipated complete resection with no loss of form or function at select sites such as bladder, prostrate, extremity, trunk, retroperitoneum, intrathoracic, perineum, or perianal). Of these patients, 81% to 84% were eligible for modest RT dose reduction. Approximately 50% of these patients had an R0 resection (negative margins) and received a reduced RT dose of 36 Gy, and 30% of patients had an R1 resection (margins were microscopically involved) and received a reduced RT dose of 41.4 Gy (from the standard 50.4-Gy dose). Local control and survival outcomes were similar to those of patients who received full-dose RT alone in the IRS-IV study.[<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

45077</a>

4508]</p>

4509<p id="_783" tabindex="-1">

4510 A retrospective analysis compared patients with clinical Group III rhabdomyosarcoma treated on consecutive COG protocols <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

4511D9803</a>

4512 (encouraged delayed primary excision) and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00354835">

4513ARST0531 (NCT00354835)</a>

4514 (discouraged delayed primary excision).[<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

451510</a>

4516] Among 369 patients in an adjusted-regression analysis, the risk of death (hazard ratio [HR], 0.71; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.43&#8211;1.16) was similar for patients who did or did not undergo delayed primary excision. A subset of patients who had tumors of the trunk and retroperitoneum did have a reduced risk of death with delayed primary excision (HR, 0.44; 95% CI, 0.20&#8211;0.97).</p>

4517</section>

4518<section id="_532">

4519<h3 id="_532_toc">

4520RT (Local Control Management)</h3>

4521<p id="_1912" tabindex="-1">

4522RT is an effective method for achieving local control of the tumor for patients with microscopic or gross residual disease after biopsy, initial surgical resection, or chemotherapy. </p>

4523<div class="pdq-content-list">

4524<ul id="_812">

4525<li>

4526<strong>

4527Group I:</strong>

4528 Patients with completely resected <strong>

4529embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma</strong>

4530 at diagnosis before initiation of chemotherapy do well without RT. However, because approximately 75% of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma patients are Groups II to IV, RT is used in most patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.11">

453111</a>

4532]<p id="_1913" tabindex="-1">

4533A study of Group I patients with <strong>

4534alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma</strong>

4535 and undifferentiated soft tissue sarcoma found that omission of RT was followed by decreased local control.[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

453612</a>

4537] A subsequent review of patients with only alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma found that the improvement in outcome with RT did not reach statistical significance for patients with Stage 1 and Stage 2 tumors. There were very few patients (n = 4) with large tumors (Stage 3, &gt;5 cm) who did not receive RT, but their outcome was poor.[<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

453813</a>

4539][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4540Level of evidence C2</a>

4541] COG recommends the use of RT for all patients with <em class="gene-name">

4542FOXO1</em>

4543 fusion&#8211;positive disease (previously called alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma).</p>

4544</li>

4545<li>

4546<strong>

4547Group II:</strong>

4548 In more than 50% of Group II rhabdomyosarcoma patients, local recurrence was the result of noncompliance with guidelines or omission of RT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

454914</a>

4550] <p id="_1914" tabindex="-1">

4551The German Cooperative Weichteilsarkom Studiengruppe (CWS) conducted a review of European trials between 1981 and 1998, in which RT was omitted for some Group II patients. This review demonstrated a benefit to using RT as a component of local tumor control for all Group II patient subsets, as defined by tumor histology, tumor size, and tumor site.[<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

455215</a>

4553]</p>

4554</li>

4555<li>

4556<strong>

4557Group III:</strong>

4558 The predominant type of relapse for patients with Group III disease is local failure. Approximately 35% of patients with Group III disease either fail to achieve a complete remission or relapse locally. Patients with tumor-involved regional lymph nodes at diagnosis also have a higher risk of local and distant failure than do patients whose lymph nodes are uninvolved.[<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

455916</a>

4560]</li>

4561</ul>

4562</div>

4563<section id="_821">

4564<h4 id="_821_toc">

4565External-beam RT</h4>

4566<p id="_813" tabindex="-1">

4567As with the surgical management of patients with rhabdomyosarcoma, recommendations for RT depend on the following:</p>

4568<div class="pdq-content-list">

4569<ul id="_814">

4570<li>

4571Site of primary tumor.</li>

4572<li>

4573Histological subtype/fusion status.</li>

4574<li>

4575Postsurgical amount of residual disease (none vs. microscopic vs. macroscopic), if surgery was performed.</li>

4576<li>

4577Presence of involved lymph nodes.</li>

4578</ul>

4579</div>

4580<p id="_596" tabindex="-1">

4581For optimal care of pediatric patients undergoing radiation treatments, it is imperative that radiation oncologists, radiation therapists, and nurses who are experienced in treating children are available. An anesthesiologist may be necessary to sedate young patients. Computerized treatment planning with a 3-dimensional planning system is essential. Techniques to deliver radiation specifically to the tumor while sparing normal tissue (e.g., <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=270731&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=NotSet" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000270731&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=NotSet'); return(false);">

4582conformal radiation therapy</a>

4583, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=335073&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=NotSet" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000335073&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=NotSet'); return(false);">

4584intensity-modulated radiation therapy</a>

4585 [IMRT], volumetrical modulated arc therapy, proton-beam therapy [<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=534234&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=NotSet" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000534234&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=NotSet'); return(false);">

4586charged-particle radiation therapy</a>

4587], or brachytherapy) are appropriate.[<a href="#cit/section_6.17">

458817</a>

4589-<a href="#cit/section_6.22">

459022</a>

4591]</p>

4592<p id="_1915" tabindex="-1">

4593Dosimetric comparison of proton-beam RT and photon IMRT treatment plans has shown that proton-beam treatment plans may spare more normal tissue adjacent to the targeted volume than IMRT plans, but with no difference in local control using photon RT. Late effects data are lacking.[<a href="#cit/section_6.23">

459423</a>

4595,<a href="#cit/section_6.24">

459624</a>

4597] </p>

4598<p id="_815" tabindex="-1">

4599Evidence (radiation delivery techniques):</p>

4600<div class="pdq-content-list">

4601<ol id="_816">

4602<li>

4603A prospective, phase II trial compared proton-beam therapy with IMRT in pediatric rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.25">

460425</a>

4605] <div class="pdq-content-list">

4606<ul id="_817">

4607<li>

4608Target coverage was comparable between proton-beam therapy and IMRT plans. However, the mean integral dose for IMRT was 1.8 to 3.5 times higher than with proton therapy, depending on the site. Proton radiation may lower the radiation dose in the uninvolved tissue surrounding the tumor and, thus, improves normal tissue sparing when compared with IMRT.</li>

4609<li>

4610Follow-up of treated patients remains short, and there are no data available to determine whether the reduction in dose to adjacent tissue will result in improved functional outcomes or reduce the risk of secondary malignancy or other toxicities.</li>

4611</ul>

4612</div>

4613</li>

4614<li>

4615A retrospective review of patients with intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma compared 3-dimensional conformal RT with IMRT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.26">

461626</a>

4617][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4618Level of evidence B4</a>

4619] <div class="pdq-content-list">

4620<ul id="_818">

4621<li>

4622IMRT improved the target coverage but did not show a difference in local failure rate or EFS.</li>

4623</ul>

4624</div>

4625</li>

4626<li>

4627In a study on the patterns of failure in 11 of 66 children with nonmetastatic rhabdomyosarcoma who were treated with proton RT, the following results were observed:[<a href="#cit/section_6.27">

462827</a>

4629]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4630<ul id="_1818">

4631<li>

4632The 2-year local control rate was 88%.</li>

4633<li>

4634All 11 children with local recurrences were Group III (gross residual disease) and experienced relapse in the radiation field, suggesting that the conformality of the proton field did not lead to out-of-field failures. The radiation dose was 41.4 Gy (relative biological effectiveness [RBE]) to the prechemotherapy tumor volume and 50.4 Gy (RBE) to the visible disease at the time of RT.</li>

4635<li>

4636Eight patients with local recurrences had tumors larger than 5 cm at diagnosis. The COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02567435">

4637ARST1431 (NCT02567435)</a>

4638 protocol is testing escalated doses to 59.4 Gy for these patients.</li>

4639<li>

4640This study did not delineate whether the recurrence was in the 41.4 Gy or 50.4 Gy irradiated volumes.</li>

4641</ul>

4642</div>

4643</li>

4644<li>

4645In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00354835">

4646ARST0531 (NCT00354835)</a>

4647 trial, local failure rates were similar among patients who were treated with proton and photon radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

464828</a>

4649]</li>

4650</ol>

4651</div>

4652<p id="_597" tabindex="-1">

4653The radiation doses according to Group, histology, and disease site for children with rhabdomyosarcoma are described in <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_643">

4654Table 7</a>

4655: </p>

4656<table id="_643" class="table-default expandable-container">

4657<caption>

4658Table 7. Radiation Therapy (RT) Dose According to Rhabdomyosarcoma Group, Histology, and Site of Disease (Children's Oncology Group [COG])</caption>

4659<colgroup>

4660<col width="50.00%">

4661<col width="50.00%">

4662</colgroup>

4663<THead>

4664<tr>

4665<th>

4666Group</th>

4667<th>

4668Treatment</th>

4669</tr>

4670</THead>

4671<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

4672<tr>

4673<td colspan="2">

4674N = regional lymph node.</td>

4675</tr>

4676</TFoot>

4677<tbody>

4678<tr>

4679<td>

4680<strong>

4681Group I</strong>

4682</td>

4683<td>

4684&#160;</td>

4685</tr>

4686<tr>

4687<td>

4688Fusion negative (embryonal)</td>

4689<td>

4690No RT required. </td>

4691</tr>

4692<tr>

4693<td>

4694<em class="gene-name">

4695FOXO1</em>

4696 fusion positive</td>

4697<td>

469836 Gy to involved (prechemotherapy) site. </td>

4699</tr>

4700<tr>

4701<td>

4702<strong>

4703Group II</strong>

4704</td>

4705<td>

4706&#160;</td>

4707</tr>

4708<tr>

4709<td>

4710N0 (microscopic residual disease after surgery) </td>

4711<td>

471236 Gy to involved (prechemotherapy) site.</td>

4713</tr>

4714<tr>

4715<td>

4716N1 (resected regional lymph node involvement)</td>

4717<td>

471836 Gy to involved (prechemotherapy) site and 41.4 Gy to nodes.</td>

4719</tr>

4720<tr>

4721<td>

4722<strong>

4723Group III</strong>

4724</td>

4725<td>

4726&#160;</td>

4727</tr>

4728<tr>

4729<td>

4730Orbital and nonorbital tumors </td>

4731<td>

473245 Gy for orbital tumors with complete response to chemotherapy. For other sites and orbital tumors in partial remission, 50.4 Gy with volume reduction after 36 Gy if excellent response to chemotherapy (or complete remission after delayed re-excision) and noninvasive pushing tumors; no volume reduction for invasive tumors. 59.4 Gy boost to residual disease at 9 weeks for tumors &gt;5 cm at diagnosis (if enrolled on the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02567435">

4733ARST1431 [NCT02567435]</a>

4734) protocol.</td>

4735</tr>

4736<tr>

4737<td>

4738N1 with gross residual disease after surgery/chemotherapy</td>

4739<td>

474050.4 Gy</td>

4741</tr>

4742<tr>

4743<td>

4744<strong>

4745Group IV</strong>

4746</td>

4747<td>

4748&#160;</td>

4749</tr>

4750<tr>

4751<td>

4752&#160;</td>

4753<td>

4754As for other Groups and including all metastatic sites, if safe and possible. <em>

4755Exception:</em>

4756 lung (pulmonary metastases) treated with 12 Gy to 15 Gy depending on age.</td>

4757</tr>

4758</tbody>

4759</table>

4760<p id="_819" tabindex="-1">

4761In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02567435">

4762ARST1431 (NCT02567435)</a>

4763 study, risk group is in part determined by fusion status. The recommended dose of RT depends on the amount of residual disease, if any, after the initial primary surgical procedure and fusion status. For patients with fusion-positive rhabdomyosarcoma who have had an initial complete resection (Group I), radiation therapy with 36 Gy is recommended.</p>

4764<div class="pdq-content-list">

4765<ul id="_598">

4766<li>

4767<strong>

4768Group II.</strong>

4769 In general, patients with

4770microscopic residual disease (Group II) receive

477136 Gy of RT if they do not have involved lymph nodes and 41.4 Gy in the presence of involved nodes.[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

477212</a>

4773,<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

477429</a>

4775] Low-risk patients (embryonal histology and favorable sites with microscopic residual disease) treated in a COG study had excellent local control with 36 Gy, which was comparable to historical controls who received 41.4 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

47769</a>

4777] For Group II patients, 36 Gy of RT is recommended to the prechemotherapy involved site, and 41.4 Gy to involved nodes. </li>

4778<li>

4779<strong>

4780Group III.</strong>

4781 IRS-II patients with gross residual disease (Group III) who received 40 Gy to

4782 more than 50 Gy had locoregional relapse rates greater than 30%, but higher

4783doses of radiation (&gt;60 Gy) were associated with unacceptable

4784long-term toxic effects.[<a href="#cit/section_6.30">

478530</a>

4786,<a href="#cit/section_6.31">

478731</a>

4788] Group III patients on the standard treatment

4789arm of the IRS-IV study received 50.4 Gy to 59.4 Gy, with 5-year progression-free survival (PFS) rates of 55% to 75% and local control rates of 85% to 88%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.32">

479032</a>

4791] <p id="_1916" tabindex="-1">

4792Select COG subgroups with Group III disease received somewhat reduced radiation doses of 36 Gy after delayed gross-total resection with negative margins (R0 resection), and 41.4 Gy if the margins were microscopically involved (R1 resection) or the nodes were positive. In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002995">

4793COG-D9602</a>

4794 study, a limited number of low-risk patients had a greater than 85% likelihood of local control with 36 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

47959</a>

4796] Similarly, the intermediate-risk studies for patients with Group III disease investigated the paradigm of delayed resection in amenable patients (anticipated complete resection with no loss of form or function at select sites such as bladder, prostate, extremity, trunk, peritoneum, intrathoracic, perineum, and perianal), with a subsequent reduced dose of RT (36 Gy for R0 resections or 41.4 Gy for R1 resections). The study demonstrated that patients who received reduced doses of RT had outcomes equivalent to patients who were treated with full-dose RT of 50.4 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

47978</a>

4798,<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

479910</a>

4800]</p>

4801</li>

4802<li>

4803<strong>

4804Group IV.</strong>

4805 Radiation therapy is appropriate treatment for sites of metastatic disease (technique, timing, and volume discussed below). The European Paediatric Soft Tissue Sarcoma Study Group (EpSSG) examined 102 patients with metastatic rhabdomyosarcoma (97 analyzed). Patients received radical RT (all metastatic sites except those completely resected), partial RT, or no RT. The OS was superior in patients treated with radical RT than partial RT (HR, 0.245; <em>

4806P</em>

4807 = .039); however, it should be noted that some component of the difference in survival likely relates to the patients selected to receive radical versus partial RT rather than the type of RT administered. The 3-year OS rate was 84% for patients who received radical RT, 54% for patients who received partial RT, and 23% for patients who received no RT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.33">

480833</a>

4809]</li>

4810</ul>

4811</div>

4812<p id="_765" tabindex="-1">

4813In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

4814D9803</a>

4815 study of patients with intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma, local control was 90% in 41 patients with Groups I and II alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma but lower in 280 patients with Group III embryonal (80%) and alveolar (83%) rhabdomyosarcoma. Histology, regional lymph node status, and primary site were not related to the likelihood of local failure; however, the local failure rate for 47 patients with retroperitoneal tumors was 33% (probably caused by tumors &#8805;5 cm in diameter), compared with 14% to 19% for patients with bladder/prostate, extremity, and parameningeal tumors. Tumor size was the strongest predictor of local failure (10% for patients with primary tumors &lt;5 cm vs. 25% for larger tumors; <em>

4816P</em>

4817 = .0004).[<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

481834</a>

4819][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4820Level of evidence C2</a>

4821]</p>

4822<section id="_2058">

4823<h5 id="_2058_toc">

4824Treatment volume</h5>

4825<p id="_2083" tabindex="-1">

4826The treated radiation volume should be determined by the extent of tumor at diagnosis

4827before surgical resection and before chemotherapy, including clinically involved regional lymph nodes. With conformal plans and image-guided RT, a margin of 1 cm to 1.3 cm to a clinical target volume or planning target volume may be used.[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

482812</a>

4829] This clinical tumor volume can be modified on the basis of anatomical constraints, especially in situations where the tumor was pushing, rather than invading, the adjacent normal tissues, or when adjacent normal tissues are functionally critical (e.g., head and neck rhabdomyosarcoma). Thus, while the volume

4830irradiated may be modified because of considerations for normal tissue tolerance,

4831gross residual disease at the time of RT should receive full-dose

4832RT.

4833A reduction in volume after 36 Gy is appropriate in chemoresponsive disease for patients with noninvasive displacement (T1) that has regressed in size, but not for invasive tumors (T2). Gross residual disease still receives the full RT dose (50.4&#8211;59.4 Gy, the higher dose if &gt;5 cm at diagnosis).</p>

4834<p id="_2084" tabindex="-1">

4835For involved nodal sites, the treated volume is defined as the extent of nodal involvement at diagnosis, factoring in changes in anatomy, plus a 3-cm margin superiorly and inferiorly in the direction of lymphatic drainage, or inclusion of the entire nodal chain where there is uncertainty.</p>

4836<p id="_2085" tabindex="-1">

4837For metastatic disease, the treated volume is the extent of metastases at diagnosis, with the exception of the lung or extensive brain metastases where the whole organ is irradiated, or diffuse peritoneal metastases where the entire peritoneal cavity is included. The use of novel techniques, such as stereotactic body RT to appropriate sites (e.g., bone or small volume soft tissue metastases), can be considered.</p>

4838</section>

4839<section id="_2060">

4840<h5 id="_2060_toc">

4841Timing of RT</h5>

4842<p id="_2061" tabindex="-1">

4843The timing of RT generally allows for chemotherapy to be given for up to 3 months before RT is initiated. RT is usually administered over 5 to 6 weeks (e.g., 1.8 Gy once per day, 5 days per week), during which time chemotherapy is usually modified to avoid the radiosensitizing agents dactinomycin, doxorubicin, and temsirolimus. Another consideration is the administration of RT before a planned second surgical excision that will be R0 or R1, particularly if RT might facilitate surgical resection to decrease the chances of loss of form or function. This approach is protocol dependent.</p>

4844<div class="pdq-content-list">

4845<ul id="_822">

4846<li>

4847The randomized IRS-IV trial reported that the administration of RT twice a day, using 6-hour interfractional intervals at 1.1 Gy per fraction (hyperfractionated schedule), 5 days per week, was feasible, did not improve local control, and was associated with increased acute toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

484835</a>

4849] The 5-year local control rate was 87% for all patients on this study.</li>

4850</ul>

4851</div>

4852<p id="_2062" tabindex="-1">

4853For metastatic sites, RT is usually given after 16 to 20 weeks of chemotherapy or, rarely, as consolidation at the completion of planned chemotherapy.</p>

4854<p id="_823" tabindex="-1">

4855Thus, conventional RT remains the standard for treating patients who have rhabdomyosarcoma with gross residual disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.36">

485636</a>

4857]</p>

4858</section>

4859</section>

4860<section id="_824">

4861<h4 id="_824_toc">

4862Brachytherapy</h4>

4863<p id="_600" tabindex="-1">

4864Brachytherapy, using either intracavitary or interstitial implants, is another

4865method of local control that has been used in selected situations for children

4866with rhabdomyosarcoma, especially for patients with primary tumors at a vaginal site [<a href="#cit/section_6.37">

486737</a>

4868-<a href="#cit/section_6.42">

486942</a>

4870] and selected bladder/prostate sites.[<a href="#cit/section_6.43">

487143</a>

4872][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4873Level of evidence C1</a>

4874] This technique requires specialized technical skill and expertise and is limited to only a few institutions. In small series from one or two institutions, this treatment

4875approach was associated with a high survival rate and retention of a

4876functional organ or tissue in most patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.38">

487738</a>

4878,<a href="#cit/section_6.44">

487944</a>

4880]; [<a href="#cit/section_6.45">

488145</a>

4882][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4883Level of evidence C2</a>

4884] Other sites, especially

4885head and neck, have also been treated with brachytherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.46">

488646</a>

4887]</p>

4888</section>

4889<section id="_825">

4890<h4 id="_825_toc">

4891Local control treatment of children aged 3 years and younger</h4>

4892<p id="_601" tabindex="-1">

4893Very young children (aged &#8804;36 months) diagnosed with rhabdomyosarcoma pose a therapeutic challenge because of their increased risk of treatment-related morbidity.[<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

48949</a>

4895] Reduced radiation doses have been used when delayed surgery can provide negative margins. However, for most patients and those in whom surgical resection is not appropriate, higher doses of RT are given.[<a href="#cit/section_6.47">

489647</a>

4897] Radiation techniques are designed to maximize normal tissue sparing and should include conformal approaches, often with intensity-modulation or protons. When radiation is omitted, even in those with Stage 1 disease, there is a high risk of recurrence, with local recurrence being the most common, confirming the need for RT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.48">

489848</a>

4899-<a href="#cit/section_6.50">

490050</a>

4901]</p>

4902<p id="_826" tabindex="-1">

4903Delayed primary excision may allow for a radiation dose reduction and has been studied in select patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

49048</a>

4905] However, the youngest patients frequently do not get appropriate RT because of concerns about normal tissue toxicity, and these are the best patients for whom surgical resection by delayed primary excision is a particularly important consideration. Local control can be achieved by both RT and surgery. Both treatments are optimal, but at least one approach is necessary in addition to chemotherapy. Local control rates from delayed primary excision and reduced-dose RT are equivalent to that from RT alone.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

49068</a>

4907]</p>

4908<p id="_827" tabindex="-1">

4909In studies of infants younger than 1 or 2 years, 77 patients with nonmetastatic rhabdomyosarcoma were included. These studies showed 5-year failure-free survival (FFS) rates of 57% to 68% and OS rates of 76% to 82%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.51">

491051</a>

4911] Most failures were local, often because RT was withheld in violation of protocol guidelines. In contrast, for infants treated according to guidelines, both FFS and OS were clearly superior.[<a href="#cit/section_6.52">

491252</a>

4913] This experience has been confirmed for children up to age 2 years.[<a href="#cit/section_6.51">

491451</a>

4915] Consequently, the COG recommends treating children aged 2 years or younger with the same guidelines as recommended for children older than 2 years.</p>

4916</section>

4917</section>

4918<section id="_544">

4919<h3 id="_544_toc">

4920Surgery and RT by Primary Site of Disease (Local Control Management)</h3>

4921<p id="_2045" tabindex="-1">

4922Local control of primary disease in rhabdomyosarcoma has evolved with the use of more effective chemotherapy protocols, improved surgical approaches and techniques, and improvements in RT, including better definition of therapy fields, tailored dosing, and new techniques such as IMRT, brachytherapy, and proton therapy. Data are predominantly derived from retrospective reviews of primary tumor sites from cooperative group studies, including the IRSG, COG, EpSSG, CWS, Gesellschaft f&#252;r P&#228;diatrische Onkologie und H&#228;matologie, International Society for Pediatric Oncology (SIOP) Malignant Mesenchymal Tumour (MMT), and the Associazione Italiana di Ematologia e Oncologia Pediatrica Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee. These groups created the International Soft Tissue Sarcoma Consortium (INSTRuCT) and agreed to form a single data commons by merging multiple cooperative group databases. Leaders of INSTRuCT have initiated efforts to define international consensus statements for approaches to several primary tumor sites, predominantly through their expert review of published data, sometimes enhanced with new analyses of merged data.</p>

4923<section id="_546">

4924<h4 id="_546_toc">

4925Head and neck sites</h4>

4926<p id="_828" tabindex="-1">

4927Primary sites for childhood rhabdomyosarcoma within the head and neck

4928include the orbit; nonorbital head and neck and cranial parameningeal; and nonparameningeal, nonorbital head and neck.

4929Specific considerations for the surgical and radiotherapeutic management of tumors arising at each

4930of these sites are discussed below.</p>

4931<p id="_549" tabindex="-1">

4932For

4933patients with head and neck primary tumors that are considered unresectable,

4934chemotherapy and RT with organ preservation are the mainstay of primary

4935management.[<a href="#cit/section_6.53">

493653</a>

4937-<a href="#cit/section_6.58">

493858</a>

4939] Several studies have reported excellent local control in patients with rhabdomyosarcoma of the head and neck treated with IMRT, fractionated <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44464&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=NotSet" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044464&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=NotSet'); return(false);">

4940stereotactic radiation therapy</a>

4941, or proton RT, and chemotherapy. Further study is needed, but the use of IMRT and chemotherapy in patients with head and neck rhabdomyosarcoma may result in less-severe late effects.[<a href="#cit/section_6.59">

494259</a>

4943-<a href="#cit/section_6.61">

494461</a>

4945]; [<a href="#cit/section_6.62">

494662</a>

4947][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4948Level of evidence C1</a>

4949]</p>

4950<div class="pdq-content-list">

4951<ol id="_829">

4952<li>

4953<strong>

4954Orbit.</strong>

4955 <p id="_591" tabindex="-1">

4956Rhabdomyosarcomas of the orbit should not undergo exenteration, but biopsy is needed for diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.63">

495763</a>

4958,<a href="#cit/section_6.64">

495964</a>

4960] Biopsy is followed by chemotherapy and RT, with orbital

4961exenteration reserved for the small number of patients with locally persistent

4962or recurrent disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.55">

496355</a>

4964,<a href="#cit/section_6.65">

496565</a>

4966] RT and chemotherapy are the standard of care, with survival rates exceeding 90% to 95%. When RT is omitted, there is risk of local relapse. For patients with orbital tumors, precaution should be taken to limit the RT dose to the lens, conjunctiva, and cornea.</p>

4967<p id="_1878" tabindex="-1">

4968The COG investigators have shown that patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma of the orbit who achieve a complete response to induction chemotherapy have improved local control after radiation therapy of 45 Gy, compared with patients who fail to achieve a complete response.[<a href="#cit/section_6.66">

496966</a>

4970][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4971Level of evidence B4</a>

4972] For patients in whom a complete response has not been achieved with induction chemotherapy, 50.4 Gy of RT is recommended by the investigators.</p>

4973<p id="_935" tabindex="-1">

4974The COG studied a lower dose of cyclophosphamide to reduce the risk of infertility. In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075582">

4975ARST0331 (NCT00075582)</a>

4976 trial, only four cycles of therapy contained cyclophosphamide, for a total cyclophosphamide exposure of 4.8 g/m<span class="sup">

49772</span>

4978. Sixty-two patients with Group III orbital embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma were treated. None of the 15 patients with radiographic complete response (CR) had local recurrences, compared with 6 of the 38 patients who had less than a CR after 12 weeks of vincristine, dactinomycin, and cyclophosphamide (VAC) chemotherapy (<em>

4979P</em>

4980 = .11). The authors concluded that for patients with Group III orbital embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma achieving a CR after VAC chemotherapy that includes modest-dose cyclophosphamide, 45 Gy of RT may be sufficient for durable FFS. However, for patients with less than a CR who were treated with the ARST0331 systemic therapy, a radiation dose of 50.4 Gy or a higher dose of cyclophosphamide may be needed to achieve the control rate reported in the IRS-IV trial.[<a href="#cit/section_6.66">

498166</a>

4982][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4983Level of evidence B4</a>

4984] </p>

4985</li>

4986<li>

4987<strong>

4988Nonorbital and cranial parameningeal.</strong>

4989<p id="_547" tabindex="-1">

4990If the tumors are nonorbital and cranial parameningeal (arising in the middle ear/mastoid, nasopharynx/nasal cavity, paranasal sinus, parapharyngeal region, or pterygopalatine/infratemporal fossa), a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan with contrast of the primary site and brain should be obtained to check for presence of base-of-skull erosion and possible extension onto or through the dura.[<a href="#cit/section_6.56">

499156</a>

4992,<a href="#cit/section_6.67">

499367</a>

4994,<a href="#cit/section_6.68">

499568</a>

4996] If skull erosion and/or transdural extension is equivocal, a computed tomography (CT) scan with contrast of the same regions is indicated. Also, if there is any suspicion of extension down the spinal cord, an MRI scan with contrast of the entire cord should be obtained. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) should be examined for malignant cells in patients with high-risk parameningeal tumors. Because complete removal of these tumors is not feasible, owing to their location, the initial surgical procedure for these patients is usually only a biopsy for diagnosis.</p>

4997<p id="_577" tabindex="-1">

4998Nonorbital head and neck rhabdomyosarcomas, including cranial parameningeal tumors, are optimally managed by conformal RT and chemotherapy. Patients with parameningeal disease with intracranial extension bordering the primary tumor and/or signs of meningeal impingement (i.e., cranial base bone erosion and/or cranial nerve palsy) do not require whole-brain irradiation or intrathecal therapy, unless tumor cells are present in the CSF at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.67">

499967</a>

5000] Patients should receive RT to the site of primary tumor with a 1.5-cm margin to include the meninges adjacent to the primary tumor and the region of intracranial extension, if present, with a 1.5-cm margin.[<a href="#cit/section_6.68">

500168</a>

5002]</p>

5003<p id="_1918" tabindex="-1">

5004Evidence (timing of RT for nonorbital and cranial parameningeal tumors):</p>

5005<div class="pdq-content-list">

5006<ol id="_895">

5007<li>

5008In a retrospective trial, starting RT within 2 weeks of diagnosis for patients with signs of meningeal impingement was associated with lower rates of local failure but was of borderline significance.[<a href="#cit/section_6.68">

500968</a>

5010]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5011<ul id="_1919">

5012<li>

5013When no signs of meningeal impingement were present, delay of RT for more than 10 weeks did not impact local failure rates.</li>

5014</ul>

5015</div>

5016</li>

5017<li>

5018A comparison of local control, FFS, and OS rates showed no statistical difference between early irradiation (day 0) for Group III patients in the IRS-IV study with cranial nerve palsy and/or cranial base erosion versus later initiation of RT (week 12) for Group III patients in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

5019D9803</a>

5020 study who had similar evidence of meningeal involvement. This suggested that early RT for this group of patients is not necessary.[<a href="#cit/section_6.69">

502169</a>

5022][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5023Level of evidence B4</a>

5024]</li>

5025<li>

5026A retrospective analysis of 47 patients with parameningeal primary sites suggested that the subgroup of adolescent patients with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma (n = 13) might benefit from the addition of prophylactic irradiation (36 Gy) to bilateral cervical nodes.[<a href="#cit/section_6.70">

502770</a>

5028][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5029Level of evidence C2</a>

5030]</li>

5031<li>

5032A single-institution retrospective review identified 14 patients with head and neck alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma. All patients were treated with multiagent chemotherapy and RT to the primary site and clinically involved nodes.[<a href="#cit/section_6.71">

503371</a>

5034][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5035Level of evidence C2</a>

5036] <div class="pdq-content-list">

5037<ul id="_1840">

5038<li>

5039 There were ten relapses in the cohort: seven regional nodal, one combination local and regional nodal, and two leptomeningeal.</li>

5040<li>

5041In six of eight patients (75%) with no nodal disease at diagnosis, isolated regional nodal relapse developed.</li>

5042<li>

5043The authors recommended elective nodal irradiation to treat at-risk draining lymph node stations relative to the primary tumor site for patients who present with head and neck alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma.</li>

5044</ul>

5045</div>

5046</li>

5047<li>

5048An analysis of 1,105 patients with localized parameningeal rhabdomyosarcoma treated from 1984 to 2004 in North America and Europe found that several prognostic factors could be used to define subgroups of patients with significantly different survival rates.[<a href="#cit/section_6.72">

504972</a>

5050][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5051Level of evidence C1</a>

5052]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5053<ul id="_1920">

5054<li>

5055The OS rate at 10 years for the entire cohort was 66%.</li>

5056<li>

5057 Patients with zero or one adverse factor (age &lt;3 or &gt;10 years at diagnosis, presence of meningeal involvement, tumor diameter &gt;5 cm, unfavorable primary parameningeal site) had a 10-year OS rate of 80.7%.</li>

5058<li>

5059Patients with two adverse factors had a 10-year OS rate of 68.4%.</li>

5060<li>

5061Patients with three or four adverse factors had a 10-year OS rate of 52.2%. </li>

5062<li>

5063 Patients who did not receive RT as a component of their initial therapy had a poor prognosis, and their tumors were not salvaged with introduction of RT after relapse. This finding establishes RT as a necessary component of initial treatment.</li>

5064</ul>

5065</div>

5066</li>

5067<li>

5068A single-institution prospective registry identified 25 patients with head and neck parameningeal rhabdomyosarcoma who were treated with proton-beam RT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.73">

506973</a>

5070]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5071<ul id="_2022">

5072<li>

5073Of 25 total patients, 11 had intracranial extension at baseline, 6 of whom experienced a local recurrence.</li>

5074<li>

5075This recurrence rate is similar to the rate reported in the IRS-IV and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

5076D9803</a>

5077 trials for patients with high-risk parameningeal rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.69">

507869</a>

5079]</li>

5080</ul>

5081</div>

5082 </li>

5083</ol>

5084</div>

5085<p id="_639" tabindex="-1">

5086Children who present with tumor cells in the CSF (Stage 4) may or may not have other evidence of diffuse meningeal disease and/or distant metastases. In a review of experience from IRSG protocols II though IV, eight patients had tumor cells in the CSF at diagnosis. Three of four patients without other distant metastases were alive at 6 to 16 years after diagnosis, as was one of the four patients who had concomitant metastases elsewhere.[<a href="#cit/section_6.74">

508774</a>

5088] </p>

5089<p id="_1921" tabindex="-1">

5090Patients may also have multiple intraparenchymal brain metastases from a distant primary tumor. They may be treated with central nervous system&#8211;directed RT in addition to treatment with chemotherapy and RT for the primary tumor. Craniospinal axis RT may also be indicated.[<a href="#cit/section_6.75">

509175</a>

5092,<a href="#cit/section_6.76">

509376</a>

5094]</p>

5095</li>

5096<li>

5097<strong>

5098Nonparameningeal, nonorbital head and neck.</strong>

5099<p id="_611" tabindex="-1">

5100For nonparameningeal, nonorbital head and neck tumors, wide excision of

5101the primary tumor (when feasible without functional impairment) and ipsilateral neck lymph node sampling of

5102clinically involved nodes may be appropriate but requires postoperative RT if margins or nodes are positive.[<a href="#cit/section_6.77">

510377</a>

5104]; [<a href="#cit/section_6.78">

510578</a>

5106][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5107Level of evidence C1</a>

5108] Narrow resection margins (&lt;1 mm)

5109are acceptable because of anatomical restrictions. Cosmetic and functional

5110factors should always be considered, but with modern techniques, complete

5111resection in patients with superficial tumors is consistent with

5112good cosmetic and functional results. </p>

5113<p id="_2048" tabindex="-1">

5114The EpSSG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379457">

5115RMS-2005 (NCT00379457)</a>

5116 study prospectively enrolled 165 patients with localized head and neck, nonparameningeal rhabdomyosarcoma. Local therapy included surgery (58%) and/or RT (72%). Chemotherapy was given according to the patient&#8217;s risk group. Low-risk patients received vincristine and dactinomycin (VA) therapy. High-risk patients were randomly assigned to receive either neoadjuvant therapy with ifosfamide, vincristine, and dactinomycin (IVA) or IVA and doxorubicin for four courses followed by five courses of IVA. The 5-year EFS rate was 75% (95% CI, 67.3%&#8211;81.2%), and the OS rate was 84.9% (95% CI, 77.5%&#8211;89.7%). Favorable histology was associated with a better EFS rate (82.3% vs. 64.6%, <em>

5117P</em>

5118 = .02), and nodal spread was associated with a worse OS rate (88.6% vs. 76.1%, <em>

5119P</em>

5120 = .04). Locoregional relapse/progression was the main tumor failure event (84% of events).[<a href="#cit/section_6.79">

512179</a>

5122][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5123Level of evidence B4</a>

5124]</p>

5125<p id="_1922" tabindex="-1">

5126Specialized, multidisciplinary surgical

5127teams also have performed resections of anterior skull-based tumors in areas

5128previously considered inaccessible to definitive surgical management, including

5129the nasal areas, paranasal sinuses, and temporal fossa. However, these procedures

5130should be considered only in children with recurrent locoregional

5131disease or residual disease after chemotherapy and RT.</p>

5132</li>

5133</ol>

5134</div>

5135</section>

5136<section id="_550">

5137<h4 id="_550_toc">

5138Extremity sites</h4>

5139<p id="_782" tabindex="-1">

5140A pooled analysis of 642 patients from four international cooperative groups in Europe and North America was performed to identify prognostic factors in patients with localized extremity rhabdomyosarcoma. Regional lymph node involvement was approximately 2.5 times higher with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma than with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. The 5-year OS rate was 67%. Multivariate analysis showed that decreased OS was correlated with age older than 3 years, T2 invasive disease and N1 nodal status, incomplete initial surgery, treatment before 1995, and treatment by European groups. This analysis also suggested that duration of chemotherapy might have an impact on outcome in these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.80">

514180</a>

5142]</p>

5143<p id="_640" tabindex="-1">

5144Primary re-excision before initiation of chemotherapy (i.e., not delayed) may be appropriate in patients whose initial surgical procedure leaves microscopic residual disease that is deemed resectable by a second procedure without loss of cosmesis or function.[<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

51455</a>

5146] Chemotherapy or delayed primary excision does not improve outcome over chemotherapy and RT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

51478</a>

5148]</p>

5149<p id="_784" tabindex="-1">

5150Delayed primary excision has been studied in patients with extremity tumors enrolled in the COG intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma trials. Two COG studies (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

5151D9803</a>

5152 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00354835">

5153ARST0531 [NCT00354835]</a>

5154) were pooled to assess the benefit of delayed primary excision. In the D9803 study, local control with RT after a partial or complete excision was completed at week 12. In the ARST0531 study, RT was done upfront at week 4. Patients with bladder or prostate rhabdomyosarcoma who received a delayed primary excision had no difference in survival, whereas patients with extremity rhabdomyosarcoma had an improved OS with delayed primary excision. The delayed primary excision strategy with a reduction in RT dose resulted in superior OS for those sites.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

51558</a>

5156,<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

515710</a>

5158] Delayed primary excision may be most appropriate for infants because the late effects of RT are more severe than in older patients; thus, even a moderate reduction in radiation dose is desirable. For more information, see the <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_529">

5159Surgery (Local Control Management)</a>

5160 section.</p>

5161<p id="_578" tabindex="-1">

5162IMRT can be used to spare the bone yet provide optimal soft tissue coverage in extremity rhabdomyosarcoma. Complete primary tumor removal from the hand or foot is not feasible in most cases because of functional impairment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.81">

516381</a>

5164][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5165Level of evidence C1</a>

5166] For children presenting with a primary tumor of the hands or feet, COG studies have shown a 10-year local control rate of 100% using RT along with chemotherapy, avoiding amputation in these children.[<a href="#cit/section_6.82">

516782</a>

5168][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5169Level of evidence C1</a>

5170] Definitive RT and chemotherapy for Group III tumors resulted in a local control rate of 90% to 95% in the IRS-IV trial.[<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

517135</a>

5172]</p>

5173<section id="_552">

5174<h5 id="_552_toc">

5175Regional and in-transit lymph nodes for extremity tumors</h5>

5176<p id="_592" tabindex="-1">

5177Because of the significant incidence of regional nodal spread in patients with extremity primary tumors (often without clinical evidence of involvement) and because of the prognostic and therapeutic implications of nodal involvement, extensive pretreatment assessment of regional and in-transit nodes is warranted.[<a href="#cit/section_6.83">

517883</a>

5179-<a href="#cit/section_6.87">

518087</a>

5181]; [<a href="#cit/section_6.88">

518288</a>

5183][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5184Level of evidence C2</a>

5185] In-transit nodes are defined as epitrochlear and brachial for upper-extremity tumors and popliteal for lower-extremity tumors. Regional lymph nodes are defined as axillary/infraclavicular nodes for upper-extremity tumors and inguinal/femoral nodes for lower-extremity tumors. </p>

5186<div class="pdq-content-list">

5187<ul id="_831">

5188<li>

5189In a review of 226 patients with primary extremity rhabdomyosarcoma, 5% had tumor-involved in-transit nodes. Over 5 years, the rate of in-transit node recurrence was 12%. Very few patients (n = 11) underwent in-transit node examination at diagnosis, but five of them, all with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, had tumor-involved nodes. However, the EFS rates were not significantly different among those evaluated initially and those not evaluated initially for in-transit nodal disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.88">

519088</a>

5191] </li>

5192</ul>

5193</div>

5194<p id="_1923" tabindex="-1">

5195Positron emission tomography (PET) scanning is recommended for evaluation and staging of extremity primary tumors before initiation of therapy [<a href="#cit/section_6.88">

519688</a>

5197] and is useful in RT treatment planning.[<a href="#cit/section_6.89">

519889</a>

5199]</p>

5200<p id="_554" tabindex="-1">

5201For patients enrolled in clinical trials, the COG-STS recommends biopsy of all enlarged or clinically suspicious lymph nodes, if possible, without delay in therapy or adverse functional outcome. If biopsy is not feasible, clinically abnormal nodes need to be included in the RT treatment plan.</p>

5202<p id="_1924" tabindex="-1">

5203In the trunk and extremity, if no enlarged lymph nodes are identified in the draining nodal basin, a sentinel lymph node biopsy is recommended. This type of biopsy is a more accurate way of assessing regional lymph nodes than random lymph node sampling. Techniques for sentinel lymph node biopsy are standardized and should be completed by an experienced surgeon.[<a href="#cit/section_6.86">

520486</a>

5205,<a href="#cit/section_6.90">

520690</a>

5207-<a href="#cit/section_6.96">

520896</a>

5209]</p>

5210<p id="_1820" tabindex="-1">

5211In a single-institution study of 28 patients aged 6 months to 32 years with soft tissue sarcomas, but not confined to rhabdomyosarcoma, sentinel lymph node biopsy was prospectively compared with PET-CT scan for detection of lymph node metastases. Forty-three percent of patients (3 of 7) with proven malignant sentinel lymph nodes had negative cross-sectional and functional imaging (PET-CT). Also, PET-CT suggested nodal involvement in 14 patients, whereas only 4 of those were proven to have metastatic disease. The study does not address relapse rate or follow-up in these patients. Therefore, the use of PET-CT staging to diagnose lymph node disease in soft tissue sarcomas is of uncertain utility.[<a href="#cit/section_6.97">

521297</a>

5213]</p>

5214</section>

5215</section>

5216<section id="_556">

5217<h4 id="_556_toc">

5218Truncal sites</h4>

5219<p id="_833" tabindex="-1">

5220Primary sites for childhood rhabdomyosarcoma within the trunk

5221include the chest wall or abdominal wall, intrathoracic or intra-abdominal area, biliary tree, and perineum or anus.

5222Specific considerations for the surgical and radiotherapeutic management of tumors arising at each

5223of these sites are discussed below.</p>

5224<div class="pdq-content-list">

5225<ol id="_834">

5226<li>

5227<strong>

5228Chest wall or abdominal

5229wall.</strong>

5230<p id="_557" tabindex="-1">

5231The surgical management of patients with lesions of the chest wall or abdominal

5232wall follows the same guidelines as those used for lesions of the extremities (i.e., wide local excision and an attempt to achieve negative microscopic

5233margins if cosmetic and functional outcomes are acceptable).[<a href="#cit/section_6.98">

523498</a>

5235] These resections may require use of prosthetic materials for subsequent reconstruction.</p>

5236<p id="_1925" tabindex="-1">

5237 Initial primary resection is performed if there is a realistic expectation of achieving negative margins (R0 resection). However, most patients who present with large tumors in these

5238sites have localized disease that is unresectable at diagnosis but may become amenable to resection with

5239negative margins after preoperative chemoradiation therapy. These patients may have excellent long-term

5240survival.[<a href="#cit/section_6.98">

524198</a>

5242-<a href="#cit/section_6.101">

5243101</a>

5244] </p>

5245<p id="_916" tabindex="-1">

5246Chest wall rhabdomyosarcoma, which is usually Group III, does not require R0 resection (no microresidual disease) at delayed primary resection. The COG data show equivalent survival for R0 and R1 (microresidual disease at the margin) resections in chest wall rhabdomyosarcoma, likely because of the addition of postoperative RT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.101">

5247101</a>

5248] Aggressive resections at diagnosis before chemotherapy are not necessary because rhabdomyosarcoma is chemosensitive and radiosensitive.</p>

5249</li>

5250<li>

5251<strong>

5252Intrathoracic or intra-abdominal sarcomas.</strong>

5253<p id="_890" tabindex="-1">

5254Intrathoracic or intra-abdominal sarcomas may not be resectable at diagnosis because of the

5255massive size of the tumor and extension into vital

5256organs or vessels.[<a href="#cit/section_6.102">

5257102</a>

5258]</p>

5259 <p id="_836" tabindex="-1">

5260For patients with initially unresectable <strong>

5261retroperitoneal/pelvic</strong>

5262 tumors, complete surgical removal after induction chemotherapy, with or without RT, offers a significant survival advantage (73% vs. 34%&#8211;44% without removal).[<a href="#cit/section_6.102">

5263102</a>

5264] </p>

5265<p id="_1926" tabindex="-1">

5266Evidence (chemotherapy with or without RT followed by surgery):</p>

5267<div class="pdq-content-list">

5268<ol id="_1927">

5269<li>

5270The SIOP-MMT Group found that RT improved local control in patients with localized pelvic rhabdomyosarcoma whose initial surgical procedure was biopsy only, leaving macroscopic residual tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_6.103">

5271103</a>

5272][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5273Level of evidence B4</a>

5274]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5275<ul id="_1939">

5276<li>

5277Age older than 10 years and lymph node involvement were unfavorable prognostic factors.</li>

5278</ul>

5279</div>

5280</li>

5281<li>

5282A German study reported on 100 patients with intra-abdominal nonmetastatic embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma larger than 5 cm in dimension; 61% had tumors larger than 10 cm and 88% were T2. Eighty-one patients were treated with chemotherapy and delayed primary excision, while 19 patients with emergency presentations (tumor rupture, ileus, hydronephrosis, oliguria, and venous congestion) underwent initial debulking surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_6.104">

5283104</a>

5284][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5285Level of evidence C1</a>

5286]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5287<ul id="_1928">

5288<li>

5289 The EFS rate was 52% (&#177; 10%), and the OS rate was 65% (&#177; 9%).</li>

5290<li>

5291 Unfavorable factors were initial diagnosis at age older than 10 years, lack of complete remission, and inadequate local control (incomplete secondary resection or no RT).</li>

5292</ul>

5293</div>

5294</li>

5295<li>

5296A small series of seven patients with rhabdomyosarcoma who had peritoneal dissemination and/or malignant ascites achieved good outcomes with whole-abdomen irradiation using IMRT with dose painting.[<a href="#cit/section_6.105">

5297105</a>

5298][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5299Level of evidence C1</a>

5300] This technique involves simultaneously irradiating the whole abdomen with a lower dose than that used for the primary tumor (or resection-bed). The larger volume receives a lower (fractional) daily dose than the high-dose target receives.</li>

5301</ol>

5302</div>

5303</li>

5304<li>

5305<strong>

5306Biliary tree.</strong>

5307<p id="_559" tabindex="-1">

5308With rhabdomyosarcoma of the

5309biliary tree, total resection at diagnosis is rarely feasible. The standard treatment includes chemotherapy and RT. Outcomes for patients with this primary tumor site were considered favorable despite residual disease after surgery;[<a href="#cit/section_6.106">

5310106</a>

5311] however, an analysis of COG low-risk studies found that patients with this site had suboptimal outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_6.107">

5312107</a>

5313] The CWS also reported poorer outcomes,[<a href="#cit/section_6.108">

5314108</a>

5315] confirmed by a systematic review and meta-analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.109">

5316109</a>

5317] The COG now recommends that this site be classified as unfavorable. External biliary drains

5318significantly increase the risk of postoperative infectious complications.

5319Thus, external biliary drainage is not warranted.[<a href="#cit/section_6.106">

5320106</a>

5321]</p>

5322<p id="_1983" tabindex="-1">

5323Evidence (chemotherapy, surgery, and RT): </p>

5324<div class="pdq-content-list">

5325<ol id="_1985">

5326<li>

5327A retrospective review by the CWS identified 17 patients with rhabdomyosarcoma of the biliary tree.[<a href="#cit/section_6.108">

5328108</a>

5329]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5330<ul id="_1986">

5331<li>

5332The 5-year OS rate was 58% (45%&#8211;71%), and the EFS rate was 47% (34%&#8211;50%).</li>

5333<li>

5334Patients older than 10 years and those with alveolar histology had the worst prognosis (OS rate, 0%).</li>

5335<li>

5336Patients with botryoid histology had an excellent survival (OS rate, 100%) compared with those with nonbotryoid histology (OS rate, 38%; 22%&#8211;54%; <em>

5337P</em>

5338 = .047).</li>

5339<li>

5340Microscopic complete tumor resection was achieved in five of six patients who received initial tumor biopsy followed by chemotherapy and delayed surgery.</li>

5341</ul>

5342</div>

5343</li>

5344<li>

5345A COG analysis of 17 patients enrolled in two consecutive low-risk studies (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002995">

5346D9602</a>

5347 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075582">

5348ARST0331</a>

5349) reported the following results:[<a href="#cit/section_6.107">

5350107</a>

5351]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5352<ul id="_2063">

5353<li>

5354The 5-year EFS rate was 76.5% (95% CI, 54.6%&#8211;98.4%), and the OS rate was 70.6% (95% CI, 46.9%&#8211;94.3%).</li>

5355<li>

5356Most patients (80%) who received RT did not have disease recurrence.</li>

5357<li>

5358Of 14 patients with Group III disease, 5 underwent delayed primary excision, 2 of whom had local relapses.</li>

5359<li>

5360Of the nine patients without delayed primary excision, two developed local relapses.</li>

5361</ul>

5362</div>

5363</li>

5364</ol>

5365</div>

5366</li>

5367<li>

5368<strong>

5369Perineum or anus.</strong>

5370<p id="_560" tabindex="-1">

5371Patients with rhabdomyosarcoma arising from tissue around the perineum or anus often present with advanced disease. These patients have a high likelihood of regional lymph node involvement, and about half of the tumors have alveolar histology.[<a href="#cit/section_6.110">

5372110</a>

5373] The high frequency of nodal involvement and the prognostic association between nodal involvement and poorer outcome support the recommendation to sample the regional lymph nodes.[<a href="#cit/section_6.111">

5374111</a>

5375] When feasible and without unacceptable morbidity, removing all gross tumor before chemotherapy may improve the likelihood of cure; however, chemotherapy and RT remain the standard of care. With the goal of organ preservation, patients with tumors of the perineum or anus are preferentially managed with chemotherapy and RT without aggressive surgery, as aggressive surgery may result in the loss of sphincter control. Very aggressive surgery is not indicated because of multiple critical structures that limit the ability to achieve negative margins near the anus and urethra.[<a href="#cit/section_6.111">

5376111</a>

5377] </p>

5378<div class="pdq-content-list">

5379<ul id="_838">

5380<li>

5381In IRSG protocols I through IV, the OS rate after aggressive therapy for 71 patients with tumors in this location was 49%, best for patients with Stage 2 disease (small tumors, negative regional nodes), intermediate for those with Stage 3 disease, and worst for those with Stage 4 disease at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.111">

5382111</a>

5383]</li>

5384<li>

5385In a subsequent report from the German CWS trials, 32 patients had an EFS and OS rate of 47% at 5 years. In addition, patients with embryonal histology fared significantly better than did patients with alveolar histology.[<a href="#cit/section_6.112">

5386112</a>

5387][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5388Level of evidence C1</a>

5389] </li>

5390<li>

5391A retrospective review examined 50 patients with nonmetastatic perianal/perineal rhabdomyosarcoma treated in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002898">

5392SIOP-MMT-95 (NCT00002898)</a>

5393, Italian RMS-96, and EpSSG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379457">

5394RMS-2005</a>

5395 trials. The study found a 5-year EFS rate of 47.8% and an OS rate of 52.6%. Eighty-seven percent of patients with relapse or disease progression died. Older patients and those with large tumors had the worst outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_6.113">

5396113</a>

5397][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5398Level of evidence C1</a>

5399]</li>

5400</ul>

5401</div>

5402</li>

5403</ol>

5404</div>

5405</section>

5406<section id="_561">

5407<h4 id="_561_toc">

5408Genitourinary system sites</h4>

5409<p id="_562" tabindex="-1">

5410Primary sites for childhood rhabdomyosarcoma within the genitourinary system

5411include the paratesticular area, bladder, prostate, kidney, vulva, vagina, and uterus.

5412Specific considerations for the surgical and radiotherapeutic management of tumors arising at each

5413of these sites are discussed below.[<a href="#cit/section_6.114">

5414114</a>

5415]</p>

5416<div class="pdq-content-list">

5417<ol id="_891">

5418<li>

5419<strong>

5420Testis or spermatic cord (paratesticular).</strong>

5421<p id="_2064" tabindex="-1">

5422Recommendations for paratesticular primary tumors are primarily based on the results from cooperative group trials and a recent INSTRuCT consensus opinion.[<a href="#cit/section_6.115">

5423115</a>

5424]</p>

5425<p id="_563" tabindex="-1">

5426Lesions occurring adjacent to the testis or spermatic cord and up to the internal inguinal ring should be removed by

5427orchiectomy with resection of the spermatic cord, using an inguinal

5428incision with proximal vascular control (i.e., radical orchiectomy).[<a href="#cit/section_6.116">

5429116</a>

5430] Resection of hemiscrotal skin is required when there is tumor fixation or

5431invasion. </p>

5432<p id="_840" tabindex="-1">

5433Hemiscrotectomy had been recommended by the COG, German groups, and Italian groups when a previous transscrotal biopsy had been performed. A retrospective German CWS study of 28 patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma found a 5-year EFS rate of 91.7% in 12 patients with an initial transscrotal excision followed by hemiscrotectomy, while the 5-year EFS rate was 93.8% in 16 patients without subsequent hemiscrotectomy. All of these patients also received chemotherapy with vincristine, dactinomycin, an alkylating agent, and other agents.[<a href="#cit/section_6.117">

5434117</a>

5435][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5436Level of evidence C2</a>

5437] </p>

5438<p id="_1929" tabindex="-1">

5439A retrospective study examined 842 patients with localized paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma who were enrolled in COG, CWS, EpSSG, Italian Cooperative Group, and MMT studies from 1988 to 2013. Of all patients, 7.7% had a transscrotal resection; however, this surgical factor did not contribute to an inferior EFS in stratified univariable and multivariable analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.118">

5440118</a>

5441] A COG study evaluated 279 patients with paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma. The study also found that hemiscrotectomy did not improve outcome after transscrotal violation.[<a href="#cit/section_6.119">

5442119</a>

5443][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5444Level of evidence C1</a>

5445] These findings support the consensus statement from INSTRuCT that hemiscrotectomy is no longer recommended for scrotal violation.[<a href="#cit/section_6.115">

5446115</a>

5447]</p>

5448<p id="_2008" tabindex="-1">

5449The EpSSG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379457">

5450RMS-2005 (NCT00379457)</a>

5451 study enrolled 237 patients with paratesticular tumors. Seventy-five patients (32%) had an inappropriate first surgery, defined as tumorectomy without orchidectomy, transscrotal orchidectomy without an inguinal approach, or biopsy in a resectable tumor. These patients required intensified therapy to maintain excellent OS and EFS. Ten patients required additional local surgery and intensified chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.120">

5452120</a>

5453]</p>

5454<p id="_841" tabindex="-1">

5455For patients with incompletely removed paratesticular tumors that require RT, temporarily repositioning the contralateral testicle into the adjacent thigh before scrotal radiation may preserve hormone production; however, more data are needed.[<a href="#cit/section_6.121">

5456121</a>

5457][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5458Level of evidence C1</a>

5459] A retrospective review of 49 patients with paratestis rhabdomyosarcoma referred to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center found that 20 patients had scrotal violation as a part of their original surgery. Fifteen of these patients underwent salvage surgery or RT. Eleven of these patients had continuous PFS, whereas four of the five patients who were treated without a salvage procedure developed recurrent disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.122">

5460122</a>

5461][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5462Level of evidence C2</a>

5463]</p>

5464<p id="_564" tabindex="-1">

5465Paratesticular tumors have a relatively high incidence of

5466lymphatic spread (26% in IRS-I and IRS-II).[<a href="#cit/section_6.83">

546783</a>

5468] All patients with paratesticular primary tumors should have

5469thin-cut abdominal and pelvic CT scans with intravenous contrast

5470to evaluate nodal involvement. For patients who have Group I disease, are younger than 10 years, and in whom CT scans show no evidence of lymph node enlargement,

5471retroperitoneal node biopsy/sampling is unnecessary, but a repeat CT scan

5472every 3 months is recommended.[<a href="#cit/section_6.123">

5473123</a>

5474,<a href="#cit/section_6.124">

5475124</a>

5476] For patients with suggestive or

5477positive CT scans, retroperitoneal, ipsilateral, infra-renal vein lymph node sampling of 10 to 12 nodes (but not formal node

5478dissection) is recommended, and treatment is based on the findings of this

5479procedure.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

54804</a>

5481,<a href="#cit/section_6.36">

548236</a>

5483,<a href="#cit/section_6.125">

5484125</a>

5485] Patients with suspicious or documented retroperitoneal/pelvic lymph nodes require nodal RT.</p>

5486<p id="_842" tabindex="-1">

5487In patients aged 10 years and older, only 9% will have clinical or radiological evidence of retroperitoneal node enlargement. However, pathological evaluation has shown that imaging alone will miss 50% of nodal disease. Therefore, patients aged 10 years and older should have an ipsilateral, nerve-sparing retroperitoneal node dissection, regardless of imaging findings.[<a href="#cit/section_6.126">

5488126</a>

5489] Staging ipsilateral retroperitoneal lymph

5490node sampling is currently required for all children aged 10 years and older with paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma on COG-STS studies.</p>

5491<p id="_2065" tabindex="-1">

5492Many European investigators

5493relied on radiographic, rather than surgical-pathological assessment, for retroperitoneal

5494lymph node involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_6.116">

5495116</a>

5496,<a href="#cit/section_6.123">

5497123</a>

5498] European studies, as well as an international pooled data analysis, demonstrated worse outcomes in this patient population when surgical lymph node evaluation was not performed.[<a href="#cit/section_6.118">

5499118</a>

5500,<a href="#cit/section_6.120">

5501120</a>

5502,<a href="#cit/section_6.127">

5503127</a>

5504] On the basis of these results and with the high relapse rate and worse EFS in Stage N0 patients, investigators from SIOP, EpSSG, and COG recommended surgical resection, in the form of ipsilateral retroperitoneal lymph node sampling of clinically normal nodes (not enlarged by CT or MRI), in patients aged 10 years and older with paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.118">

5505118</a>

5506] A consensus document regarding paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma from all North American and European cooperative groups concurred that all patients aged 10 years or older should undergo ipsilateral, infra-renal vein, retroperitoneal surgical lymph node evaluation by sampling 7 to 12 nodes or a nerve-sparing dissection.[<a href="#cit/section_6.115">

5507115</a>

5508]</p>

5509<p id="_1930" tabindex="-1">

5510Evidence (lymph node sampling):</p>

5511<div class="pdq-content-list">

5512<ol id="_1931">

5513<li>

5514 In the SIOP-MMT-89 and -95 studies, patients with paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma were evaluated with imaging but did not undergo routine ipsilateral lymph node sampling.[<a href="#cit/section_6.128">

5515128</a>

5516][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5517Level of evidence B4</a>

5518] <div class="pdq-content-list">

5519<ul id="_1940">

5520<li>

5521Thirty-one percent of Stage N0 patients aged 10 years and older developed node relapse, compared with 8% of Stage N0 patients younger than 10 years (<em>

5522P</em>

5523 = .0005).</li>

5524<li>

5525The SIOP-MMT group subsequently recommended ipsilateral lymph node sampling for all patients aged 10 years and older.</li>

5526</ul>

5527</div>

5528 </li>

5529<li>
