5530 The North American and European cooperative groups performed a pooled analysis of 12 studies from five cooperative groups.[<a href="#cit/section_6.118">

5531118</a>

5532][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5533Level of evidence C1</a>

5534] <div class="pdq-content-list">

5535<ul id="_1941">

5536<li>

5537For patients with paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma (N = 842), age 10 years and older at diagnosis and tumor size larger than 5 cm were unfavorable prognostic features.</li>

5538<li>

5539At 7.5 years of median follow-up, the EFS rate was 87.7%, and the OS rate was 94.8% at 5 years.</li>

5540<li>

5541The only treatment variable that was associated with EFS in patients aged 10 years or older was surgical assessment of regional nodes, which may most accurately identify patients who can benefit from RT.</li>

5542</ul>

5543</div>

5544 </li>

5545<li>

5546In the EpSSG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379457">

5547RMS-2005 (NCT00379457)</a>

5548 cooperative group study (n = 237) of patients with paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma, retroperitoneal lymph node staging was based on conventional imaging with ultrasonography, CT, or MRI, not systematic surgical staging.[<a href="#cit/section_6.120">

5549120</a>

5550][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5551Level of evidence B4</a>

5552]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5553<ul id="_2009">

5554<li>

5555Twenty-one of 26 recurrences were in patients older than 10 years and were mainly locoregional in 16 of the 26 patients.</li>

5556<li>

5557The 5-year OS and EFS rates were both significantly worse in patients older than 10 years, compared with those younger than 10 years (OS rates, 86.7% vs. 98.1%, respectively; <em>

5558P</em>

5559 = .0013; EFS rates, 79.6% vs. 95.8%, respectively; <em>

5560P</em>

5561 = .0004).</li>

5562<li>

5563Eight of ten nodal relapses were in patients older than 10 years.</li>

5564<li>

5565The EpSSG group advocates surgical staging for patients aged 10 years and older.</li>

5566</ul>

5567</div>

5568</li>

5569<li>

5570The COG reviewed 279 patients with localized paratesticular rhabdomyosarcoma enrolled in one of four COG studies (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002995">

5571D9602</a>

5572, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075582">

5573ARST0331</a>

5574, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

5575D9803</a>

5576, or <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00354835">

5577ARST0531 [NCT00354835]</a>

5578). Surgical resection of the primary tumor before chemotherapy and RT was encouraged, when possible, with retroperitoneal lymph node dissection (RPLND) recommended for patients aged 10 years and older. Most tumors were resected with negative margins (78.5%), and most patients did not have radiographic enlargement of regional lymph nodes (90.3%). Of 270 analyzed patients, 121 were older than 10 years. Of these patients, 25 (20.9%) underwent template RPLND, 35 (28.9%) had RPLN sampling, and for 12 of the patients (9.9%), the RPLN technique was unknown.[<a href="#cit/section_6.119">

5579119</a>

5580][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5581Level of evidence B4</a>

5582]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5583<ul id="_2028">

5584<li>

5585In patients older than 10 years, imaging alone will miss over 51.5% of nodal disease.</li>

5586<li>

5587Sampling of &#8805;7 to 12 nodes appeared optimal.</li>

5588<li>

5589The 5-year EFS rate was 92%.</li>

5590<li>

5591There was a trend toward improved EFS among those who underwent template RPLND (<em>

5592P</em>

5593 = .068).</li>

5594<li>

5595Reliance on imaging alone to detect nodal involvement will miss pathological node involvement and may result in undertreatment.</li>

5596</ul>

5597</div>

5598</li>

5599</ol>

5600</div>

5601<p id="_1932" tabindex="-1">

5602RT should be considered for patients whose nodes are biopsy positive.</p>

5603</li>

5604<li>

5605<strong>

5606Bladder or prostate.</strong>

5607<p id="_2066" tabindex="-1">

5608Bladder preservation is a major goal of therapy for patients with tumors

5609arising in the bladder and/or prostate. Two reviews provide information about the historical, current, and future treatment approaches for patients with bladder and prostate rhabdomyosarcomas.[<a href="#cit/section_6.129">

5610129</a>

5611,<a href="#cit/section_6.130">

5612130</a>

5613]</p>

5614<p id="_1933" tabindex="-1">

5615The initial

5616surgical procedure in most patients consists of a biopsy, which often can be

5617performed using ultrasound guidance or cystoscopy, or by a direct-vision transanal

5618route.[<a href="#cit/section_6.131">

5619131</a>

5620] </p>

5621<p id="_579" tabindex="-1">

5622In rare cases, the tumor is confined to

5623the dome of the bladder and can be completely resected, leaving a functional bladder intact. Otherwise, to preserve

5624a functional bladder in patients with gross residual disease, chemotherapy and

5625RT have been used in North America and some parts of Europe to reduce tumor bulk.[<a href="#cit/section_6.132">

5626132</a>

5627,<a href="#cit/section_6.133">

5628133</a>

5629] This is sometimes followed, when

5630necessary, by a more limited surgical procedure such as partial cystectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.134">

5631134</a>

5632]

5633Early experience with this approach was disappointing, with only 20% to 40% of

5634patients with bladder/prostate tumors alive and with functional

5635bladders 3 years after diagnosis (3-year OS rate was 70% in IRS-II).[<a href="#cit/section_6.134">

5636134</a>

5637,<a href="#cit/section_6.135">

5638135</a>

5639] The later experience from the IRS-III and IRS-IV studies, which used

5640more intensive chemotherapy and RT and had a greater emphasis on bladder preservation, showed 55% of patients alive

5641with functional bladders at 3 years postdiagnosis, with 3-year OS rates

5642 exceeding 80%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.133">

5643133</a>

5644,<a href="#cit/section_6.136">

5645136</a>

5646,<a href="#cit/section_6.137">

5647137</a>

5648]</p>

5649<p id="_2007" tabindex="-1">

5650In a prospective registry study of 19 patients (median age, 1.8 years at diagnosis; range, 0.5&#8211;5.0 years) who were treated with proton therapy, the 5-year OS and PFS rates were 76%. The 5-year local-control rate was 76%. Tumor size predicted the local-control rate, with 5-year local-control rates of 43% for patients whose tumors were larger than 5 cm versus 100% for patients whose tumors were 5 cm or smaller (<em>

5651P</em>

5652 = .006). The four patients who had a relapse all died.[<a href="#cit/section_6.138">

5653138</a>

5654]</p>

5655<p id="_1934" tabindex="-1">

5656 Patients with a primary tumor of the bladder or prostate who present with a large pelvic mass, resulting from a distended bladder caused by outlet obstruction at diagnosis, receive RT. The RT volume is defined by imaging studies after initial chemotherapy to relieve outlet obstruction. This approach to therapy remains generally

5657accepted, with the belief that more effective chemotherapy and RT

5658will continue to increase the frequency of bladder salvage.</p>

5659<p id="_580" tabindex="-1">

5660For patients with biopsy-proven, residual malignant tumor after

5661chemotherapy and RT, appropriate surgical management may include

5662partial cystectomy, prostatectomy, or exenteration (usually approached anteriorly with

5663preservation of the rectum).

5664Very few studies report objective long-term assessment of bladder function. Urodynamic studies can accurately evaluate bladder function.[<a href="#cit/section_6.139">

5665139</a>

5666]</p>

5667<p id="_720" tabindex="-1">

5668An alternative strategy, used in European SIOP protocols, has been to avoid major radical surgery when possible and omit external-beam RT if complete disappearance of tumor can be achieved by chemotherapy and conservative surgical procedures. The goal is to preserve a functional bladder and prostate without incurring the late effects of RT or having to perform a total cystectomy/prostatectomy. From 1984 to 2003, 172 patients with nonmetastatic bladder and/or bladder/prostate rhabdomyosarcoma were enrolled in a SIOP-MMT study. Of the 119 survivors, 50% had no significant local therapy, and only 26% received RT. The 5-year OS rate was 77%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.140">

5669140</a>

5670][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5671Level of evidence C1</a>

5672]</p>

5673<p id="_1800" tabindex="-1">

5674Another alternative strategy in highly selected patients is to perform conservative surgery, followed by brachytherapy at a specialized center.[<a href="#cit/section_6.141">

5675141</a>

5676]; [<a href="#cit/section_6.142">

5677142</a>

5678][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5679Level of evidence C2</a>

5680]; [<a href="#cit/section_6.143">

5681143</a>

5682][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5683Level of evidence C1</a>

5684] A prospective, nonrandomized analysis of this strategy reported the outcomes of 100 children. The 5-year disease-free survival rate was 84%, and the OS rate was 91%. At last follow-up, most survivors presented with only mild-to-moderate genitourinary sequelae and a normal diurnal urinary continence. Five patients required a secondary total cystectomy, three patients for a nonfunctional bladder and two patients for relapse. In another series, bladder-conserving surgery plus brachytherapy for boys with prostate or bladder-neck rhabdomyosarcoma led to excellent survival rates, bladder preservation, and short-term functional results.[<a href="#cit/section_6.43">

568543</a>

5686][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5687Level of evidence C1</a>

5688]</p>

5689<p id="_566" tabindex="-1">

5690In patients who have been treated with chemotherapy and RT for rhabdomyosarcoma arising in the bladder or prostate region, the

5691presence of well-differentiated rhabdomyoblasts in surgical specimens or

5692biopsies obtained after treatment does not appear to be associated with a high

5693risk of recurrence and is not an indication for a major surgical procedure such as

5694total cystectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.136">

5695136</a>

5696,<a href="#cit/section_6.144">

5697144</a>

5698,<a href="#cit/section_6.145">

5699145</a>

5700] One study suggested that in patients with residual bladder tumors with

5701histological evidence of maturation, additional courses of chemotherapy should be given before cystectomy is considered.[<a href="#cit/section_6.136">

5702136</a>

5703]

5704Surgery should be considered if malignant tumor cells do not disappear

5705over time after initial chemotherapy and RT. Because of limited data, it is unclear whether this situation is analogous for patients

5706with rhabdomyosarcoma arising in other parts of the body.</p>

5707</li>

5708<li>

5709<strong>

5710Kidney.</strong>

5711<p id="_606" tabindex="-1">

5712The kidney is rarely the primary site for sarcoma. Ten patients were identified among 5,746 eligible patients enrolled in IRSG protocols, including six with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma and four with undifferentiated sarcoma. The tumors were large (mean widest diameter, 12.7 cm), and anaplasia was present in four (67%) patients. Of the patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, three Group I and Group II patients survived, one Group III patient died of infection, and two Group IV patients died of recurrent disease; these children were aged 5.8 and 6.1 years at diagnosis. This limited experience concluded that the kidney is an unfavorable site for primary sarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.146">

5713146</a>

5714]</p>

5715</li>

5716<li>

5717<strong>

5718Vulva, vagina, or uterus.</strong>

5719<p id="_567" tabindex="-1">

5720For patients with genitourinary primary tumors of the vulva, vagina, or uterus, the

5721initial surgical procedure is usually a vulvar or transvaginal biopsy. Initial radical surgery is not indicated for rhabdomyosarcoma of the vulva, vagina, or uterus.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

57224</a>

5723] Conservative

5724surgical intervention for vaginal rhabdomyosarcoma, with primary chemotherapy

5725and radiation (external beam or brachytherapy) for Group II or III disease results in excellent

57265-year survival rates.[<a href="#cit/section_6.48">

572748</a>

5728,<a href="#cit/section_6.147">

5729147</a>

5730,<a href="#cit/section_6.148">

5731148</a>

5732][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5733Level of evidence C1</a>

5734]</p>

5735<p id="_581" tabindex="-1">

5736In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075582">

5737COG-ARST0331</a>

5738 study, there was an unacceptably high rate of local recurrences in girls with Group III vaginal tumors who did not receive RT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.48">

573948</a>

5740][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5741Level of evidence C2</a>

5742] In 21 girls with genitourinary tract disease who were not treated with RT (mostly Group III vaginal primary tumors), the 3-year FFS rate was 57%, compared with 77% in the other 45 patients with non&#8211;female genitourinary primary tumors (<em>

5743P</em>

5744 = .02).[<a href="#cit/section_6.49">

574549</a>

5746][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5747Level of evidence B4</a>

5748] Therefore, the COG-STS recommended that RT be administered to patients with residual viable vaginal tumor, beginning at week 12.[<a href="#cit/section_6.50">

574950</a>

5750][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5751Level of evidence C1</a>

5752]</p>

5753<p id="_582" tabindex="-1">

5754Because of the small number of patients with

5755uterine rhabdomyosarcoma, it is difficult to make a definitive treatment

5756decision, but chemotherapy with or without RT is effective.[<a href="#cit/section_6.147">

5757147</a>

5758,<a href="#cit/section_6.149">

5759149</a>

5760] Twelve of 14 girls with primary cervical embryonal (mainly botryoid) rhabdomyosarcoma were disease-free after VAC chemotherapy and conservative surgery. Of note, two girls also had a pleuropulmonary blastoma and another had a Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_6.150">

5761150</a>

5762]

5763Exenteration is usually not required for primary tumors at these sites, but may be done if needed, with rectal preservation possible in most cases.</p>

5764<p id="_1829" tabindex="-1">

5765 Four cooperative groups in the United States and Europe evaluated patients with localized vaginal or uterine tumors (N = 427). Some patients received initial RT for local control of residual disease after induction chemotherapy, while others had it later, or not at all if no demonstrable disease was found. The 10-year EFS rate was 74%, and the 10-year OS rate was 92%. Unfavorable factors were positive lymph node disease and uterine corpus primary site. There was no statistical difference in outcomes between patients who received early RT and patients who received later RT. About one-half of these patients were cured without radical surgery or systematic RT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.42">

576642</a>

5767][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5768Level of evidence C1</a>

5769]</p>

5770<p id="_2067" tabindex="-1">

5771A study of five CWS trials (and one registry) included 67 patients with localized vaginal or uterine rhabdomyosarcoma diagnosed at a median age of 2.89 years (0.09&#8211;18.08). Multimodality treatment consisted of chemotherapy (n = 66), secondary surgery (n = 32), and RT (n = 11). The study reported the following results:[<a href="#cit/section_6.151">

5772151</a>

5773][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5774Level of evidence C1</a>

5775]</p>

5776<div class="pdq-content-list">

5777<ul id="_2081">

5778<li>

5779Diagnosis at age 12 months or younger was the only significant negative prognostic factor influencing EFS.</li>

5780<li>

5781The 10-year EFS rate for infants aged 12 months or younger was 50%, and the OS rate was 81%.</li>

5782<li>

5783 In contrast, children with local disease older than 1 year to age 10 years had a 10-year EFS rate of 78% and an OS rate of 94% (<em>

5784P</em>

5785 = .038). Children older than 10 years had a 10-year EFS rate of 82% and an OS rate of 88% (<em>

5786P</em>

5787 = .53). </li>

5788<li>

5789Metastatic disease was observed in four patients, three of whom are alive. </li>

5790<li>

5791Relapsed disease occurred in 5 of 12 infants aged 1 year or younger and 10 of 55 children at a median of 1.38 years (0.53&#8211;2.97) after initial diagnosis. </li>

5792<li>

5793Treatment of patients with relapsed disease consisted of multimodality treatment (n = 13) or resection only (n = 2). Nine patients (60%) were alive in clinical remission at a median of 7.02 years (1.23&#8211;16.72) after diagnosis of relapsed disease.</li>

5794</ul>

5795</div>

5796<p id="_2029" tabindex="-1">

5797The INSTRuCT group summarized its consensus expert opinion about local treatment of female genital tract tumors as follows:[<a href="#cit/section_6.152">

5798152</a>

5799]</p>

5800<div class="pdq-content-list">

5801<ul id="_2030">

5802<li>

5803Prognosis for female genital tract tumors is favorable, with an excellent response to chemotherapy.</li>

5804<li>

5805Definitive local control can often be achieved by chemotherapy alone.</li>

5806<li>

5807Adequate biopsy is required and should provide sufficient tissue to establish the diagnosis and for further molecular or genetic analysis.</li>

5808<li>

5809Initial complete surgical resection before chemotherapy can be avoided in most cases:<div class="pdq-content-list">

5810<ul id="_2046">

5811<li>

5812Vaginal: Vaginectomy is unnecessary.</li>

5813<li>

5814Cervix: Up-front vaginectomy/hysterectomy is usually not indicated.</li>

5815<li>

5816Uterus: Up-front hysterectomy is usually not indicated.</li>

5817</ul>

5818</div>

5819</li>

5820<li>

5821Primary re-excision to achieve complete resection is usually not indicated.</li>

5822<li>

5823Patients with tumors that are localized to the vagina or cervix and who demonstrate incomplete response after induction chemotherapy receive local RT (brachytherapy).</li>

5824<li>

5825Hysterectomy is indicated for patients with tumors of the corpus uteri who have persistent tumor after definitive initial therapy.</li>

5826<li>

5827Fertility preservation is a consideration for all patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.152">

5828152</a>

5829]</li>

5830</ul>

5831</div>

5832<p id="_642" tabindex="-1">

5833For girls with genitourinary primary tumors who will receive pelvic irradiation, ovarian transposition (oophoropexy) before radiation therapy should be considered unless dose estimations suggest that ovarian function is likely to be preserved.[<a href="#cit/section_6.153">

5834153</a>

5835] Alternatively, ovarian tissue preservation is under investigation and can be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_6.154">

5836154</a>

5837]</p>

5838</li>

5839</ol>

5840</div>

5841</section>

5842<section id="_568">

5843<h4 id="_568_toc">

5844Unusual primary sites</h4>

5845<p id="_569" tabindex="-1">

5846Rhabdomyosarcoma occasionally arises in sites other than those previously discussed. </p>

5847<div class="pdq-content-list">

5848<ol id="_843">

5849<li>

5850<strong>

5851Brain.</strong>

5852<p id="_844" tabindex="-1">

5853Patients with localized primary rhabdomyosarcoma of the brain can occasionally be cured using a combination of tumor excision, RT, and chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.155">

5854155</a>

5855][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5856Level of evidence C2</a>

5857]</p>

5858</li>

5859<li>

5860<strong>

5861Larynx.</strong>

5862<p id="_570" tabindex="-1">

5863Patients with laryngeal rhabdomyosarcoma will usually be treated with chemotherapy and RT after biopsy in an attempt to preserve the larynx.[<a href="#cit/section_6.156">

5864156</a>

5865]</p>

5866</li>

5867<li>

5868<strong>

5869Diaphragm.</strong>

5870<p id="_571" tabindex="-1">

5871Patients with diaphragmatic tumors often have locally advanced disease that is not grossly resectable initially because of fixation to adjacent vital structures such as the lung, great vessels, pericardium, and/or liver. In such circumstances, chemotherapy and RT should be initiated after diagnostic biopsy. Removal of residual tumor at a later date if clinically indicated could be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_6.157">

5872157</a>

5873]</p>

5874</li>

5875<li>

5876<strong>

5877Ovary.</strong>

5878<p id="_573" tabindex="-1">

5879Two well-documented cases of primary ovarian rhabdomyosarcoma (one Stage III and one Stage IV) have been reported to supplement the eight previously reported patients. These two patients were alive at 20 and 8 months after diagnosis. Six of the previously reported eight patients had died of their disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.158">

5880158</a>

5881][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5882Level of evidence C2</a>

5883] Treatment with combination chemotherapy, followed by removal of the residual mass or masses, can sometimes be successful.[<a href="#cit/section_6.158">

5884158</a>

5885]</p>

5886</li>

5887</ol>

5888</div>

5889</section>

5890<section id="_2099">

5891<h4 id="_2099_toc">

5892Unknown primary sites</h4>

5893<p id="_2094" tabindex="-1">

5894The EpSSG reported a retrospective analysis of ten patients with rhabdomyosarcoma and unknown primary sites, most of whom were adolescents (median age, 15.8 years; range, 4.6&#8211;20.4 years).[<a href="#cit/section_6.159">

5895159</a>

5896] Nine patients had fusion-positive alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma. Seven patients had multiple organ involvement, two patients had only bone marrow disease, and one patient had only leptomeningeal dissemination. All patients received chemotherapy, four received radiation therapy, and none underwent surgery. Three patients underwent allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. At the time of this analysis, only two patients were alive in complete remission: one who was treated with radiation therapy, and one who was treated with a bone marrow transplantation.</p>

5897</section>

5898<section id="_574">

5899<h4 id="_574_toc">

5900Metastatic disease</h4>

5901<p id="_575" tabindex="-1">

5902Primary resection of metastatic disease at diagnosis (Stage 4, M1, Group IV) is rarely indicated. A site of gross disease is rarely cured with chemotherapy alone; thus, the COG recommends RT to sites of gross disease.</p>

5903<p id="_2068" tabindex="-1">

5904In the COG protocols, resection of the primary tumor in patients with metastatic disease may be considered before initiating chemotherapy if a complete resection is anticipated without the loss of form or function. After induction chemotherapy, delayed resection can be performed, with the same caveat regarding complete resection without loss of form or function, followed by RT of the primary tumor. The paradigm of aggressive local control of primary tumors in patients with metastases is supported by a European evaluation of 101 patients treated from 1998 to 2011 using MMT protocols. OS rates were best when both surgical resection and RT were combined (44%) versus surgical resection alone (19%) or RT alone (16%) (<em>

5905P</em>

5906 &lt; .006).[<a href="#cit/section_6.160">

5907160</a>

5908][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5909Level of evidence C1</a>

5910] Outcome also correlated with completeness of the surgical resection (R0, 41%; R1, 56%; R2, 20%; <em>

5911P</em>

5912 &lt; .03). Primary resection of metastatic disease at diagnosis (Stage 4, M1, Group IV) is rarely indicated. Treatment of metastatic disease occurs near the end of therapy using RT and, rarely, resection or other ablative techniques. The primary treatment for bony metastatic disease is RT.</p>

5913<p id="_2069" tabindex="-1">

5914Members of the EpSSG evaluated the role of indeterminate pulmonary nodules at diagnosis in patients with rhabdomyosarcoma. The criteria for indeterminate pulmonary nodules were one to four nodules smaller than 5 mm or one nodule measuring 5 mm to 10 mm. Of 316 patients, 67 patients had nodules and 249 patients did not have nodules. At a median follow-up of 75 months, the 5-year EFS rate was 77% for patients with nodules and 73.2% for patients without nodules (<em>

5915P</em>

5916 = .68). The 5-year OS rate was 82% for patients with nodules and 80.8% for patients without nodules (<em>

5917P</em>

5918 = .76). The authors concluded that there was no need to perform a biopsy on or upstage the patients with indeterminate pulmonary nodules at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.161">

5919161</a>

5920][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5921Level of evidence C1</a>

5922]</p>

5923<p id="_845" tabindex="-1">

5924Evidence (treatment of lung-only metastatic disease):</p>

5925<div class="pdq-content-list">

5926<ol id="_846">

5927<li>

5928The CWS reviewed four consecutive trials and identified 29 patients with M1 embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma and metastasis limited to the lung at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.162">

5929162</a>

5930][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5931Level of evidence C1</a>

5932]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5933<ul id="_847">

5934<li>

5935They reported a 5-year EFS rate of approximately 38% for the cohort.</li>

5936<li>

5937The study did not identify any benefit for local control of pulmonary metastasis, whether by lung irradiation (n = 9), pulmonary metastasectomy (n = 3), or no targeted pulmonary therapy (n = 19).</li>

5938</ul>

5939</div>

5940</li>

5941<li>

5942The IRSG reviewed 46 IRS-IV (1991&#8211;1997) patients with metastatic disease at diagnosis confined to the lungs. Only 11 patients (24%) had a biopsy of the lung, including six at the time of primary diagnosis. They were compared with 234 patients with single nonlung metastatic sites or multiple other sites of metastases. The lung-only patients were more likely to have embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma and parameningeal primary tumors than the larger group of 234 patients, and they were less likely to have regional lymph node disease at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.163">

5943163</a>

5944][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5945Level of evidence C1</a>

5946]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5947<ul id="_848">

5948<li>

5949At 4 years, the FFS rate was 35% and the OS rate was 42%, better than for those with two or more sites of metastases (<em>

5950P</em>

5951 = .005 and .002, respectively).</li>

5952<li>

5953Age younger than 10 years at diagnosis was also a favorable prognostic factor.</li>

5954<li>

5955Lung irradiation was recommended by the protocols for the lung-only group, but many did not receive it. Patients who received lung irradiation had better FFS and OS at 4 years than those who did not receive lung irradiation (<em>

5956P</em>

5957 = .01 and <em>

5958P</em>

5959 = .039, respectively).</li>

5960</ul>

5961</div>

5962</li>

5963</ol>

5964</div>

5965</section>

5966</section>

5967<section id="_133">

5968<h3 id="_133_toc">

5969Chemotherapy</h3>

5970<p id="_134" tabindex="-1">

5971 All children with rhabdomyosarcoma should receive

5972chemotherapy. The intensity and duration of the chemotherapy are dependent on

5973the Risk Group assignment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.164">

5974164</a>

5975] For more information about Risk Groups, see <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_348">

5976Table 6</a>

5977.</p>

5978<p id="_634" tabindex="-1">

5979Adolescents treated with chemotherapy for rhabdomyosarcoma experience less hematologic toxicity and more peripheral nerve toxicity than do younger patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.165">

5980165</a>

5981]</p>

5982<section id="_137">

5983<h4 id="_137_toc">

5984 Low-risk Group</h4>

5985<p id="_849" tabindex="-1">

5986Cooperative group studies have defined low-risk patient populations who have better outcomes. The specific definition of the low-risk group is protocol dependent, and while outcomes have typically been excellent, some subgroups of low-risk patients have received relatively aggressive therapy. In the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002995">

5987D9602</a>

5988 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075582">

5989ARST0331</a>

5990 studies, low-risk patients had localized (nonmetastatic) embryonal histology tumors in favorable sites that were grossly resected (Groups I and II), embryonal tumors in the orbit that were not completely resected (Group III), and localized tumors in unfavorable sites that were grossly resected (Groups I and II). Approximately 25% of newly diagnosed patients are low risk. For more information, see <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_257">

5991Table 5</a>

5992 in the <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_128">

5993Stage Information for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

5994 section. </p>

5995<p id="_2070" tabindex="-1">

5996COG and EpSSG studies have evaluated two- and three-drug chemotherapy schedules with varying intensity of alkylator therapy and variations in length of therapy. The goals are to maximize cure rates while attempting to mitigate late effects of chemotherapy. These cooperative groups have evaluated different approaches in different patient subsets.</p>

5997<p id="_851" tabindex="-1">

5998Evidence (chemotherapy for low-risk Group patients):</p>

5999<div class="pdq-content-list">

6000<ol id="_2071">

6001<li>

6002The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002995">

6003COG-D9602</a>

6004 study stratified 388 patients with low-risk embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma into two groups.[<a href="#cit/section_6.166">

6005166</a>

6006] Treatment for subgroup A patients (n = 264; Stage 1 Group I/IIA, Stage 2 Group I, and Stage 1 Group III orbit) consisted of VA for 48 weeks with or without RT. Patients with subgroup B disease (n = 78; Stage 1 Group IIB/C, Stage I Group III nonorbit, Stage 2 Group II, and Stage 3 Group I/II disease) received VAC (total cumulative cyclophosphamide dose of 28.6 g/m<span class="sup">

60072</span>

6008). Radiation doses were reduced from 41.4 Gy to 36 Gy for Stage 1 Group IIA patients and from 50 Gy or 59 Gy to 45 Gy for Group III orbit patients.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6009<ul id="_918">

6010<li>

6011For subgroup A patients, the 5-year overall FFS rate was 89%, and the OS rate was 97%.</li>

6012<li>

6013For subgroup B patients, the 5-year FFS rate was 85%, and the OS rate was 93%.</li>

6014</ul>

6015</div>

6016<table id="_2077" class="table-default expandable-container">

6017<caption>

6018Table 8. D9602 Risk Assignment for Low-Risk Patients</caption>

6019<colgroup>

6020<col width="33.33%">

6021<col width="16.66%">

6022<col width="16.66%">

6023<col width="16.66%">

6024<col width="16.66%">

6025</colgroup>

6026<THead>

6027<tr>

6028<th>

6029Subset</th>

6030<th>

6031Tumor Site</th>

6032<th>

6033Tumor Size</th>

6034<th>

6035Surgical-Pathological Group</th>

6036<th>

6037Nodes</th>

6038</tr>

6039</THead>

6040<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

6041<tr>

6042<td colspan="5">

6043N0 = absence of nodal spread; N1 = presence of regional nodal spread beyond the primary site.</td>

6044</tr>

6045</TFoot>

6046<tbody>

6047<tr>

6048<td rowspan="3">

6049<strong>

6050A</strong>

6051 </td>

6052<td>

6053Favorable</td>

6054<td>

6055Any</td>

6056<td>

6057I, IIA</td>

6058<td>

6059N0</td>

6060</tr>

6061<tr>

6062<td>

6063Orbital</td>

6064<td>

6065Any</td>

6066<td>

6067I, II, III</td>

6068<td>

6069N0</td>

6070</tr>

6071<tr>

6072<td>

6073Unfavorable</td>

6074<td>

6075&#8804;5 cm</td>

6076<td>

6077I</td>

6078<td>

6079N0</td>

6080</tr>

6081<tr>

6082<td rowspan="3">

6083<strong>

6084B</strong>

6085</td>

6086<td>

6087Favorable (orbital or nonorbital) </td>

6088<td>

6089Any</td>

6090<td>

6091IIB, IIC, III</td>

6092<td>

6093N0, N1</td>

6094</tr>

6095<tr>

6096<td>

6097Unfavorable</td>

6098<td>

6099&lt;5 cm</td>

6100<td>

6101II</td>

6102<td>

6103N0</td>

6104</tr>

6105<tr>

6106<td>

6107Unfavorable</td>

6108<td>

6109&gt;5 cm</td>

6110<td>

6111I, II</td>

6112<td>

6113N0, N1</td>

6114</tr>

6115</tbody>

6116</table>

6117</li>

6118<li>

6119The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00075582">

6120COG-ARST0331</a>

6121 trial evaluated a refinement of therapy for two subsets of low-risk patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.50">

612250</a>

6123] For subset 1 patients, this study reduced the length of therapy by using only four cycles of VAC (cumulative cyclophosphamide dose of 4.8 g/m<span class="sup">

61242</span>

6125) followed by four VA cycles over 22 weeks. Group II and III patients received local RT. For subset 2 patients, the goal of this study was to reduce the total cumulative cyclophosphamide dose, compared with the previous IRS-IV study, without compromising FFS, and to decrease the risk of permanent infertility. Patients received four cycles of VAC (equivalent cyclophosphamide dose as subset 1) followed by VA over 46 weeks.[<a href="#cit/section_6.49">

612649</a>

6127][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6128Level of evidence B4</a>

6129] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6130<ol id="_2072" class="lower-alpha">

6131<li>

6132Subset 1 enrolled 271 newly diagnosed patients with low-risk embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, defined as patients who presented with Stage 1 or Stage 2 tumors; Group I or Group II tumors; or Stage 1, Group III orbital tumors. This noninferiority trial used a fixed outcome on the basis of expected FFS for similar patients treated in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002995">

6133D9602</a>

6134 trial.[<a href="#cit/section_6.50">

613550</a>

6136]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6137<ul id="_1980">

6138<li>

6139There were 35 treatment failures observed (48.8 expected).</li>

6140<li>

6141The 3-year FFS rate was 89%, and the OS rate was 98%. Thus, shorter duration of therapy did not appear to compromise outcome in these patients.</li>

6142</ul>

6143</div>

6144</li>

6145<li>

6146Subset 2 included patients with Stage 1, Group III nonorbital tumors or Stage 3, Group I/II embryonal tumors. Treatment consisted of four cycles of VAC chemotherapy followed by 12 cycles of VA therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.48">

614748</a>

6148,<a href="#cit/section_6.49">

614949</a>

6150]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6151<ul id="_1981">

6152<li>

6153Among 66 eligible patients, there were 20 failures, with an estimated 3-year FFS rate of 70% and an OS rate of 92%.</li>

6154<li>

6155FFS rates at 3 years were even worse (57%) for girls with genital tract tumors. </li>

6156<li>

6157Using reduced total cyclophosphamide, researchers observed suboptimal FFS rates among patients with subset 2 low-risk rhabdomyosarcoma. Eliminating RT for girls with Group III vaginal tumors in combination with reduced total cyclophosphamide appeared to contribute to the suboptimal outcome. However, the OS rate appeared to be similar to the OS rate in previous studies with higher-dose cyclophosphamide. These patients (Stage I, Group III nonorbit and Stage 3, Group I/II) are now being treated in the intermediate-risk <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02567435">

6158ARST1431 (NCT02567435)</a>

6159 trial.</li>

6160</ul>

6161</div>

6162</li>

6163<li>

6164For patients with an orbital primary tumor who achieved only a partial response or stability after 12 weeks of induction chemotherapy, the 5-year FFS rate was only 84%, compared with 100% for patients who achieved a CR.[<a href="#cit/section_6.66">

616566</a>

6166][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6167Level of evidence C2</a>

6168] </li>

6169</ol>

6170</div>

6171<table id="_2078" class="table-default expandable-container">

6172<caption>

6173Table 9. ARST0331 Risk Assignment for Low-Risk Patients</caption>

6174<colgroup>

6175<col width="20.00%">

6176<col width="20.00%">

6177<col width="20.00%">

6178<col width="20.00%">

6179<col width="20.00%">

6180</colgroup>

6181<THead>

6182<tr>

6183<th>

6184Subset</th>

6185<th>

6186Tumor Site&#160;</th>

6187<th>

6188Tumor Size&#160;</th>

6189<th>

6190Surgical-Pathological Group&#160;</th>

6191<th>

6192Nodes&#160;</th>

6193</tr>

6194</THead>

6195<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

6196<tr>

6197<td colspan="5">

6198N0 = absence of nodal spread; N1 = presence of regional nodal spread beyond the primary site.</td>

6199</tr>

6200</TFoot>

6201<tbody>

6202<tr>

6203<td rowspan="4">

6204<strong>

62051</strong>

6206</td>

6207<td rowspan="2">

6208Favorable&#160;</td>

6209<td rowspan="2">

6210Any&#160;</td>

6211<td>

6212I</td>

6213<td>

6214N0</td>

6215</tr>

6216<tr>

6217<td>

6218II</td>

6219<td>

6220N0, N1</td>

6221</tr>

6222<tr>

6223<td>

6224Orbital&#160;</td>

6225<td>

6226Any&#160;</td>

6227<td>

6228III&#160;</td>

6229<td>

6230N0&#160;</td>

6231</tr>

6232<tr>

6233<td>

6234Unfavorable&#160;</td>

6235<td>

6236&lt;5 cm</td>

6237<td>

6238I, II</td>

6239<td>

6240N0&#160;</td>

6241</tr>

6242<tr>

6243<td rowspan="2">

6244<strong>

62452</strong>

6246</td>

6247<td>

6248Favorable (nonorbital)</td>

6249<td>

6250Any</td>

6251<td>

6252III</td>

6253<td>

6254N0, N1</td>

6255</tr>

6256<tr>

6257<td>

6258Unfavorable</td>

6259<td>

6260&gt;5 cm</td>

6261<td>

6262I, II</td>

6263<td>

6264N0, N1</td>

6265</tr>

6266</tbody>

6267</table>

6268</li>

6269<li>

6270The EpSSG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379457">

6271RMS-2005</a>

6272 study prospectively evaluated the reduction in chemotherapy for patients with low-risk embryonal histology rhabdomyosarcoma. Between October 2005 and December 2016, 178 patients with Group I N0 disease were enrolled.[<a href="#cit/section_6.167">

6273167</a>

6274][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810033&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6275Level of evidence B4</a>

6276]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6277<ul id="_2073">

6278<li>

6279The 5-year EFS rate was 90.8% (95% CI, 85.0%&#8211;94.4%), and the OS rate was 95.7% (95% CI, 90.5%&#8211;98.1%).</li>

6280<li>

6281Subgroup A: Patients younger than 10 years with tumors smaller than 5 cm received eight courses of VA therapy for 22 weeks. The EFS rate for this subgroup of 70 patients was 95.5% (95% CI, 86.6%&#8211;98.5%), and the OS rate was 100%.</li>

6282<li>

6283Subgroup B: Patients who were older than 10 years or had tumors larger than 5 cm received four courses of IVA (VA plus ifosfamide) and five courses of VA for 25 weeks. The EFS rate for this subgroup was 87.8% (95% CI, 79.3%&#8211;93.0%), and the OS rate was 93% (95% CI, 84.8%&#8211;96.8%).</li>

6284<li>

6285Treatment with VA for eight courses was effective and well tolerated by subgroup A patients with low-risk embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. A reduction from nine courses of IVA in previous studies to four courses of IVA plus five courses of VA also produced good results.</li>

6286</ul>

6287</div>

6288</li>

6289<li>

6290The COG and EpSSG studies defined low-risk patient populations, largely based on histology. Genomic classification refined the risk classification for rhabdomyosarcoma and will be used in future COG studies.[<a href="#cit/section_6.168">

6291168</a>

6292] Tumor samples from patients enrolled in COG trials (1988&#8211;2017), U.K. MMT, and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00379457">

6293RMS-2005</a>

6294 studies (1995&#8211;2016) were subjected to custom-capture sequencing. DNA from 641 patients was suitable for analysis. Mutations, indels, gene deletions, and amplifications were identified, and survival analysis was performed. <div class="pdq-content-list">

6295<ul id="_2074">

6296<li>

6297A median of one mutation per tumor was found.</li>

6298<li>

6299In <em class="gene-name">

6300FOXO1</em>

6301 fusion&#8211;negative cases, mutation of any RAS pathway members was found in more than 50% of cases. In 21% of cases, no putative driver mutation was identified.</li>

6302<li>

6303Mutations in <em class="gene-name">

6304BCOR</em>

6305 (15%), <em class="gene-name">

6306NF1</em>

6307 (15%), and <em class="gene-name">

6308TP53</em>

6309 (13%) were found at a higher incidence than previously reported.</li>

6310<li>

6311<em class="gene-name">

6312TP53</em>

6313 mutations were associated with worse outcomes in both fusion-negative and fusion-positive cases. </li>

6314<li>

6315Mutations of <em class="gene-name">

6316MYOD1</em>

6317 were associated with a dismal survival.</li>

6318</ul>

6319</div>

6320</li>

6321<li>

6322

6323The COG and European investigators pooled the results of patients with rhabdomyosarcoma who had definitive surgery of the primary tumor before the initiation of systemic chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.169">

6324169</a>

6325] A total of 113 patients aged 0 to 18 years were identified and enrolled from January 1995 to December 2016 in COG (n = 64) and European protocols. Patients with genitourinary nonbladder and prostate rhabdomyosarcomas were excluded. The recommended chemotherapy in the European protocols was VA for 24 weeks or ifosfamide plus VA. The COG protocols recommended VA for 48 weeks or VA plus cyclophosphamide. <div class="pdq-content-list">

6326<ul id="_2095">

6327<li>

6328With a median follow-up of 97.5 months, the 5-year PFS rate was 80.0% (71.2%&#8211;86.4%), and the OS rate was 92.5% (85.6%&#8211;96.2%). There were no significant differences in outcomes between the chemotherapy regimens. </li>

6329<li>

6330Tumor size (&lt;5 cm vs. &gt;5 cm) significantly influenced OS (96.2% [88.6%&#8211;98.8%] vs. 80.6% [59.5%&#8211;91.4%]; <em>

6331P</em>

6332 = .01). </li>

6333<li>

6334The authors suggested that to reduce the burden of treatment, VA for 24 weeks may be considered in children with tumors smaller than 5 cm.

6335</li>

6336</ul>

6337</div>

6338</li>

6339</ol>

6340</div>

6341</section>

6342<section id="_234">

6343<h4 id="_234_toc">

6344Intermediate-risk Group</h4>

6345<p id="_752" tabindex="-1">

6346Approximately 50% of newly diagnosed patients are in the intermediate-risk category. In North America, VAC is the standard multiagent chemotherapy regimen used for intermediate-risk patients. In Europe, ifosfamide is typically used in place of cyclophosphamide. COG studies for intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma use VAC plus vincristine and irinotecan (VI).</p>

6347<p id="_855" tabindex="-1">

6348Evidence (chemotherapy for intermediate-risk Group patients):</p>

6349<div class="pdq-content-list">

6350<ol id="_856">

6351<li>

6352The IRS-IV study randomly assigned intermediate-risk patients to receive either standard VAC therapy or one of two other

6353chemotherapy regimens using ifosfamide as the alkylating agent. This category includes patients with embryonal

6354rhabdomyosarcoma at unfavorable sites (Stages 2 and 3) with gross residual disease (i.e.,

6355 Group III), and patients with nonmetastatic alveolar

6356rhabdomyosarcoma (Stages 2 and 3) at any site (Groups I, II, and III).[<a href="#cit/section_6.36">

635736</a>

6358] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6359<ul id="_857">

6360<li>

6361At 3 years, intermediate-risk patients had survival

6362rates from 84% to 88%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.36">

636336</a>

6364]</li>

6365<li>

6366There was no difference in outcome between these three treatments. The VAC regimen was easier to administer, confirming VAC as the standard chemotherapy combination for children with intermediate-risk

6367rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.36">

636836</a>

6369]</li>

6370<li>

6371Survival in patients with tumors of embryonal

6372histology treated in the IRS-IV trial (who received higher doses of alkylating agents) was compared with similar patients treated in the IRS-III trial (who received lower

6373doses of alkylating agents). A benefit was suggested with the use of higher doses of cyclophosphamide for certain groups of

6374intermediate-risk patients. These included patients with tumors at favorable

6375sites and positive lymph nodes, patients with gross residual disease, or patients with tumors at unfavorable sites who underwent grossly complete

6376resections, but not patients with unresected embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma at

6377unfavorable sites.[<a href="#cit/section_6.170">

6378170</a>

6379] For other groups of intermediate-risk patients, an intensification of cyclophosphamide was feasible but did not improve outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_6.171">

6380171</a>

6381] A single-institution retrospective review of patients with head and neck rhabdomyosarcoma identified an increased risk of local failure with the use of reduced-dose cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_6.172">

6382172</a>

6383]</li>

6384</ul>

6385</div>

6386</li>

6387<li>

6388The COG has also evaluated whether the addition of topotecan and cyclophosphamide to standard VAC therapy improved outcome for children with intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma. Topotecan was prioritized for evaluation on the basis of its preclinical activity in rhabdomyosarcoma xenograft models as well as its single-agent activity in previously untreated children with rhabdomyosarcoma, particularly those with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.173">

6389173</a>

6390,<a href="#cit/section_6.174">

6391174</a>

6392] Furthermore, the combination of cyclophosphamide and topotecan demonstrated substantial activity, both in patients with recurrent disease and in newly diagnosed patients with metastatic disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.175">

6393175</a>

6394,<a href="#cit/section_6.176">

6395176</a>

6396]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6397<ol id="_1964" class="lower-alpha">

6398<li>

6399The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

6400COG-D9803</a>

6401 clinical trial for newly diagnosed patients with intermediate-risk disease randomly assigned patients to receive either VAC therapy or VAC therapy with additional courses of topotecan and cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_6.177">

6402177</a>

6403][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6404Level of evidence A1</a>

6405]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6406<ul id="_1965">

6407<li>

6408Patients who received topotecan and cyclophosphamide fared no better than those treated with VAC alone. The 4-year FFS rate was 73% with VAC and 68% with VAC plus vincristine, topotecan, and cyclophosphamide.</li>

6409</ul>

6410</div>

6411</li>

6412</ol>

6413</div>

6414</li>

6415<li>

6416 In a limited-institution pilot study, a combination of vincristine/doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide (VDC) alternating with ifosfamide/etoposide (IE) was used to treat patients with intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.178">

6417178</a>

6418][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6419Level of evidence C1</a>

6420]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6421<ul id="_1966">

6422<li>

6423 The relative efficacy of this approach versus the standard approach requires further investigation.</li>

6424</ul>

6425</div>

6426</li>

6427<li>

6428A European trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002898">

6429SIOP-MMT-95</a>

6430) included 457 patients with incompletely resected embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, undifferentiated sarcoma, or soft tissue primitive neuroectodermal tumor. In this study, carboplatin, epirubicin, and etoposide was added to standard IVA therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.179">

6431179</a>

6432]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6433<ul id="_859">

6434<li>

6435 The addition of carboplatin, epirubicin, and etoposide did not improve outcome. The 3-year OS rate was 82% for patients who received IVA and 80% for patients who received IVA plus carboplatin, epirubicin, and etoposide. </li>

6436<li>

6437Toxicity was significantly worse for patients in the six-drug arm.</li>

6438</ul>

6439</div>

6440</li>

6441<li>

6442The COG reported a prospective randomized trial of two treatment strategies for patients with intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.180">

6443180</a>

6444][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6445Level of evidence A1</a>

6446] Patients were randomly assigned to receive treatment with either VAC or VAC with half of the cyclophosphamide cycles replaced with vincristine/irinotecan (VAC/VI). All patients received a lower cumulative dose of cyclophosphamide and earlier introduction of RT than did patients who were treated in previous COG studies. Patients who were treated with VAC/VI received half as much cumulative cyclophosphamide than did patients who were treated with VAC.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6447<ul id="_1830">

6448<li>

6449 At a median follow-up of 4.8 years, the 4-year EFS was 63% with VAC and 59% with VAC/VI (<em>

6450P</em>

6451 = .51), and the 4-year OS was 73% for VAC and 72% for VAC/VI (<em>

6452P</em>

6453 = .80). The COG concluded that the addition of VI to VAC did not improve EFS or OS for patients with intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma. </li>

6454<li>

6455Among patients with Group III embryonal tumors, local failure was higher in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00354835">

6456ARST0531 (NCT00354835)</a>

6457 trial than in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

6458D9803 (NCT00003958)</a>

6459 trial (27.9% vs. 19.4%) and was similar for the VAC and VAC/VI arms.</li>

6460<li>

6461After adjusting for other prognostic factors, OS was inferior in the ARST0531 trial.</li>

6462<li>

6463VAC/VI produced less hematologic toxicity, had a lower cumulative cyclophosphamide dose, and continues to be the backbone for the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02567435">

6464ARST1431 (NCT02567435)</a>

6465 study.</li>

6466</ul>

6467</div>

6468</li>

6469<li>

6470The EpSSG performed a randomized phase III trial to test the addition of vinorelbine and low-dose cyclophosphamide as maintenance chemotherapy in patients with high-risk rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.181">

6471181</a>

6472] <p id="_1988" tabindex="-1">

6473The patients classified as high risk by the EpSSG had: </p>

6474<div class="pdq-content-list">

6475<ul id="_2086">

6476<li>

6477Nonmetastatic incompletely resected embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma at unfavorable sites with unfavorable age (aged 10 years or older) or a tumor larger than 5 cm, or both; </li>

6478<li>

6479Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma with nodal involvement; or </li>

6480<li>

6481Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma without nodal involvement. </li>

6482</ul>

6483</div>

6484<p id="_2087" tabindex="-1">

6485These patients would be classified as intermediate risk by the COG.</p>

6486<p id="_1989" tabindex="-1">

6487Patients received initial treatment with cycles of IVA&#8212;ifosfamide (6 g/m<span class="sup">

64882</span>

6489), dactinomycin (1.5 mg/m<span class="sup">

64902</span>

6491), and vincristine (1.5 mg/m<span class="sup">

64922</span>

6493)&#8212;for 7 weeks, followed by randomization to continue IVA or IVA with doxorubicin (60 mg/m<span class="sup">

64942</span>

6495). IVA represents a lower alkylating agent dose than the cyclophosphamide dose of 2.2 g/m<span class="sup">

64962</span>

6497 used in COG rhabdomyosarcoma studies. Patients assessed to be in complete remission at the end of initial therapy were randomly assigned to either observation or the addition of six 4-week cycles of maintenance chemotherapy with vinorelbine (25 mg/m<span class="sup">

64982</span>

6499) on days 1, 8, and 15 of each cycle with continuous daily cyclophosphamide (25 mg/m<span class="sup">

65002</span>

6501/day).</p>

6502 <div class="pdq-content-list">

6503<ul id="_1976">

6504<li>

6505The 5-year DFS rate was 69.8% for patients in the observation group and 77.6% for patients in the maintenance chemotherapy group (<em>

6506P</em>

6507 = .061). </li>

6508<li>

6509The 5-year OS rate was 73.7% for patients in the observation group and 86.5% for patients in the maintenance chemotherapy group (<em>

6510P</em>

6511 = .0097).</li>

6512<li>

6513The addition of doxorubicin did not appear to confer any improvement in outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_6.182">

6514182</a>

6515]</li>

6516</ul>

6517</div>

6518</li>

6519<li>

6520The CWS conducted a phase III trial (RMS-96) in patients with high-risk nonmetastatic rhabdomyosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma recruited between 1995 to 2004 from the CWS and Italian Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee institutions.[<a href="#cit/section_6.183">

6521183</a>

6522] There were 557 evaluable patients with localized rhabdomyosarcoma. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either a four-drug regimen (vincristine, ifosfamide, doxorubicin, dactinomycin; 284 rhabdomyosarcoma patients) or six-drug regimen (carboplatin, epirubicin, vincristine, dactinomycin, ifosfamide, and etoposide; 273 rhabdomyosarcoma patients). <div class="pdq-content-list">

6523<ul id="_2101">

6524<li>

6525The addition of etoposide and carboplatin and increased single-dose ifosfamide did not improve the EFS and overall outcome. </li>

6526<li>

6527Toxicities and secondary malignancies were identical in both treatment arms.</li>

6528</ul>

6529</div>

6530</li>

6531</ol>

6532</div>

6533<p id="_860" tabindex="-1">

6534Approximately 20% of Group III patients will have a residual mass at the completion of therapy. The presence of a residual mass had no adverse prognostic significance.[<a href="#cit/section_6.177">

6535177</a>

6536,<a href="#cit/section_6.184">

6537184</a>

6538] Aggressive alternative therapy is not warranted for patients with rhabdomyosarcoma who have a residual mass at the end of planned therapy unless it has biopsy-proven residual malignant disease. A 2009 analysis by the COG reported that for Group III patients, best response (complete resolution versus partial response or no response) to initial chemotherapy had no impact on overall outcome.[<a href="#cit/section_6.184">

6539184</a>

6540] In 2020, the COG reported a retrospective analysis of 601 patients with clinical Group III disease. The patients were enrolled in two COG studies (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00354835">

6541ARST0531</a>

6542 [n = 285] and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

6543D9803</a>

6544 [n = 316]) and completed all protocol therapy without developing progressive disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.185">

6545185</a>

6546] Response was defined radiographically: 393 patients had complete resolution (65.4%), and 208 patients had partial response/no response (34.6%). The overall 5-year FFS rate was 75% for patients who achieved complete resolution and 66.5% for those who had a partial response/no response (adjusted [adj.] <em>

6547P</em>

6548 = .094). Radiographic response was not associated with OS at any site of disease (adj. <em>

6549P</em>

6550 = .21). Resection of the end-of-therapy mass did not improve FFS (<em>

6551P</em>

6552 = .12) or OS (<em>

6553P</em>

6554 = .37). Patients with parameningeal primary sites who achieved complete resolution had significantly improved FFS (adj. <em>

6555P</em>

6556 = .037), while those with nonparameningeal primary sites had similar outcomes (adj. <em>

6557P</em>

6558 = .47). In conclusion, complete resolution status at the end of protocol therapy in patients with parameningeal clinical Group III rhabdomyosarcoma was associated with improved FFS but not OS.</p>

6559<p id="_2076" tabindex="-1">

6560While induction chemotherapy is commonly administered for 9 to 12 weeks, 2.2% of patients with intermediate-risk rhabdomyosarcoma in the IRS-IV and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003958">

6561D9803</a>

6562 studies were found to have early disease progression and did not receive their planned local control therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.180">

6563180</a>

6564][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6565Level of evidence A1</a>

6566]</p>

6567</section>

6568<section id="_239">

6569<h4 id="_239_toc">

6570High-risk Group</h4>

6571<p id="_892" tabindex="-1">

6572High-risk patients have metastatic disease in one or more sites at diagnosis (Stage IV, Group IV). These patients continue to have a relatively poor prognosis with current therapy (5-year survival rate of &#8804;50%), and new approaches to treatment are needed to improve survival in this group.[<a href="#cit/section_6.163">

6573163</a>

6574,<a href="#cit/section_6.186">

6575186</a>

6576,<a href="#cit/section_6.187">

6577187</a>

6578] Two retrospective studies have examined patients who present with metastases limited to the lungs;[<a href="#cit/section_6.162">

6579162</a>

6580,<a href="#cit/section_6.163">

6581163</a>

6582] results are summarized in the <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_574">

6583Metastatic disease</a>

6584 section of this summary.</p>

6585<p id="_861" tabindex="-1">

6586The standard systemic therapy for children with metastatic rhabdomyosarcoma is the three-drug combination of VAC. </p>

6587<p id="_862" tabindex="-1">

6588Evidence (chemotherapy for high-risk Group patients):</p>

6589<div class="pdq-content-list">

6590<ol id="_863">

6591<li>

6592A multinational pooled analysis included 788 patients with high-risk rhabdomyosarcoma who were treated with multiagent chemotherapy (all regimens used cyclophosphamide or ifosfamide plus dactinomycin and vincristine, with or without other agents), followed by local therapy (surgery with or without RT) within 3 to 5 months after starting chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.188">

6593188</a>

6594][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6595Level of evidence C1</a>

6596]<p id="_864" tabindex="-1">

6597 The analysis identified several adverse prognostic factors (Oberlin risk factors):</p>

6598<div class="pdq-content-list">

6599<ul id="_770">

6600<li>

6601Age at diagnosis younger than 1 year or 10 years and older.</li>

6602<li>

6603Unfavorable primary site (all sites that are not orbit, nonparameningeal head and neck, genitourinary tract other than bladder/prostate, and biliary tract).</li>

6604<li>

6605Bone and/or bone marrow involvement.</li>

6606<li>

6607Three or more different metastatic sites or tissues. </li>

6608</ul>

6609</div>

6610<p id="_865" tabindex="-1">

6611The EFS rate at 3 years depended on the number of adverse prognostic factors:[<a href="#cit/section_6.188">

6612188</a>

6613][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6614Level of evidence C1</a>

6615]</p>

6616<div class="pdq-content-list">

6617<ul id="_866">

6618<li>

6619 The EFS rate was 50% for patients without any of these adverse prognostic factors.</li>

6620<li>

6621The EFS rates were 42% for patients with one adverse prognostic factor, 18% for patients with two adverse prognostic factors, 12% for patients with three adverse prognostic factors, and 5% for patients with four adverse prognostic factors (<em>

6622P</em>

6623 &lt; .0001).</li>

6624</ul>

6625</div>

6626</li>

6627</ol>

6628</div>

6629<p id="_867" tabindex="-1">

6630Many clinical trials have tried to improve outcomes by adding additional agents to standard VAC chemotherapy or substituting new agents for one or more components of VAC chemotherapy. To date, no chemotherapy regimens have been shown to be more effective than VAC, including the following: </p>

6631<div class="pdq-content-list">

6632<ol id="_868">

6633<li>

6634In the IRS-IV study, three combinations of drug pairs were studied in an up-front window: IE, vincristine/melphalan (VM),[<a href="#cit/section_6.189">

6635189</a>

6636] and ifosfamide/doxorubicin (ID).[<a href="#cit/section_6.190">

6637190</a>

6638] These patients received VAC after the up-front window agents were evaluated at weeks 6 and 12. <div class="pdq-content-list">

6639<ul id="_869">

6640<li>

6641OS rates for patients treated with IE and ID were comparable (31% and 34%, respectively) and better than for those treated with VM (22%).[<a href="#cit/section_6.190">

6642190</a>

6643] </li>

6644<li>

6645Results with VAC chemotherapy for Stage IV rhabdomyosarcoma in the North American experience are similar.</li>

6646</ul>

6647</div>

6648</li>

6649<li>

6650Results from a phase II window trial of patients with metastatic disease at presentation and treated with topotecan and cyclophosphamide showed activity for this two-drug combination.[<a href="#cit/section_6.175">

6651175</a>

6652,<a href="#cit/section_6.176">

6653176</a>

6654] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6655<ul id="_870">

6656<li>

6657Survival was not different from that seen with previous regimens.</li>

6658<li>

6659An up-front window trial of topotecan in previously untreated children and adolescents with metastatic rhabdomyosarcoma showed similar results.[<a href="#cit/section_6.174">

6660174</a>

6661]</li>

6662</ul>

6663</div>

6664</li>

6665<li>

6666 Irinotecan and the VI combination have also been evaluated as up-front window trials by the COG-STS.[<a href="#cit/section_6.191">

6667191</a>

6668]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6669<ul id="_871">

6670<li>

6671The response rates were better when irinotecan was administered with vincristine than without it.</li>

6672<li>

6673Survival in a preliminary analysis was not improved

6674over previous experience.</li>

6675</ul>

6676</div>

6677</li>

6678<li>

6679In a French study, 20 patients with metastatic disease at diagnosis received window therapy with doxorubicin for two courses.[<a href="#cit/section_6.192">

6680192</a>

6681]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6682<ul id="_872">

6683<li>

6684 Thirteen of 20 patients responded to therapy, and four patients had progressive disease.</li>

6685</ul>

6686</div>

6687</li>

6688<li>

6689A study from the SIOP demonstrated continued poor outcomes for patients with high-risk features such as age 10 years and older or bone/bone marrow involvement. This study compared a standard six-drug combination followed by vincristine/doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide (VDC) maintenance versus an arm that evaluated a window of single-agent doxorubicin or carboplatin followed by sequential high-dose monotherapy courses, including cyclophosphamide, etoposide, and carboplatin followed by maintenance VAC.[<a href="#cit/section_6.193">

6690193</a>

6691]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6692<ul id="_873">

6693<li>

6694 No benefit was seen for the high-dose therapy arm.</li>

6695</ul>

6696</div>

6697</li>

6698<li>

6699A study of patients with previously untreated metastatic rhabdomyosarcoma from the COG-STS examined outcomes of 109 patients with the disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.188">

6700188</a>

6701] Several treatment strategies, all given over 54 planned weeks, were used:<div class="pdq-content-list">

6702<ol id="_897" class="lower-alpha">

6703<li>

6704A period of compressed (every 2 weeks) schedule of chemotherapy using VDC alternating with IE.</li>

6705<li>

6706The addition of VI, including during RT.</li>

6707<li>

6708A period of VDC therapy.</li>

6709</ol>

6710</div>

6711<p id="_898" tabindex="-1">

6712The following results were observed:</p>

6713<div class="pdq-content-list">

6714<ul id="_874">

6715<li>

6716Using Oberlin risk factors (age &lt;1 or &gt;10 years, unfavorable primary site, number of metastatic sites, and presence or absence of bone/bone marrow involvement), the strategy improved outcome compared with historical controls for patients with lower-risk disease. The 3-year EFS rates were 69% for those with an Oberlin risk factor score of zero or one and 60% for patients younger than 10 years with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.194">

6717194</a>

6718][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6719Level of evidence C2</a>

6720]</li>

6721<li>

6722However, patients with more than two Oberlin risk factors had a 3-year EFS rate of 20%, comparable to historical outcomes. This intensive protocol did not appear to improve outcome for the highest-risk patients.</li>

6723</ul>

6724</div>

6725</li>

6726<li>

6727The EpSSG performed a randomized prospective phase III trial of patients with high-risk rhabdomyosarcoma. They compared a standard arm comprising nine cycles of IVA with an investigational arm comprising four cycles of IVA plus doxorubicin, followed by five cycles of IVA.[<a href="#cit/section_6.182">

6728182</a>

6729][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6730Level of evidence C1</a>

6731]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6732<ul id="_1831">

6733<li>

6734 The investigational therapy was associated with increased toxicity, including treatment-related mortality, and was not associated with improvement in either EFS or OS.</li>

6735</ul>

6736</div>

6737</li>

6738<li>

6739The COG performed two nonrandomized pilot trials in patients with high-risk rhabdomyosarcoma. All patients received 54 weeks of chemotherapy, including VI, interval-compressed VDC alternating with IE, and vincristine/dactinomycin/cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_6.195">

6740195</a>

6741][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6742Level of evidence C2</a>

6743]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6744<ol id="_1841" class="lower-alpha">

6745<li>

6746In pilot 1, patients received intravenous cixutumumab (3, 6, or 9 mg/kg) once weekly throughout therapy. Cixutumumab is a monoclonal antibody against the insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor.</li>

6747<li>

6748In pilot 2, patients received oral temozolomide (100 mg/m<span class="sup">

67492</span>

6750) daily for 5 days with irinotecan.</li>

6751</ol>

6752</div>

6753<p id="_1844" tabindex="-1">

6754The following results were observed:</p>

6755<div class="pdq-content-list">

6756<ul id="_1842">

6757<li>

6758With a median follow-up of 2.9 years, the 3-year EFS rate was 16% (95% CI, 7%&#8211;25%) for patients who received cixutumumab and 18% (95% CI, 2%&#8211;35%) for patients who received temozolomide.</li>

6759<li>

6760These results did not differ from the results observed in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00354744">

6761ARST0431 (NCT00354744)</a>

6762 trial that used the same chemotherapy regimen.</li>

6763</ul>

6764</div>

6765</li>

6766<li>

6767A European multinational collaboration investigated an intensive induction regimen followed by 1 year of maintenance therapy for patients with high-risk rhabdomyosarcoma who were aged 21 years or younger. Induction therapy consisted of four cycles of ifosfamide, vincristine, dactinomycin, and doxorubicin followed by five cycles of ifosfamide, vincristine, and dactinomycin. Maintenance therapy comprised 48 weeks of low-dose intravenous vinorelbine and low-dose oral cyclophosphamide. There were 270 evaluable patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.196">

6768196</a>

6769] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6770<ul id="_2090">

6771<li>

6772The 3-year EFS rate was 34.9% (95% CI, 29.1%&#8211;40.8%), and the OS rate was 47.9% (95% CI, 41.6%&#8211;53.9%).</li>

6773<li>

6774 The investigators simultaneously conducted a prospective randomized trial that tested the addition of bevacizumab to chemotherapy. In a subset of 102 patients, 50 were assigned to receive bevacizumab. The addition of bevacizumab did not improve EFS or OS.</li>

6775</ul>

6776</div>

6777 </li>

6778</ol>

6779</div>

6780</section>

6781</section>

6782<section id="_349">

6783<h3 id="_349_toc">

6784Other Therapeutic Approaches</h3>

6785<div class="pdq-content-list">

6786<ul id="_350">

6787<li>

6788 High-dose chemotherapy with autologous and allogeneic stem cell rescue has been evaluated in a limited number of patients with rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.197">

6789197</a>

6790-<a href="#cit/section_6.199">

6791199</a>

6792] The use of this modality has failed to improve the outcomes of patients with newly diagnosed or recurrent rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.199">

6793199</a>

6794]</li>

6795<li>

6796The National Cancer Institute's (NCI) intramural Pediatric Oncology Branch conducted a pilot study of cytoreductive treatment followed by consolidative immunotherapy incorporating T-cell reconstitution, plus a dendritic-cell and tumor-peptide vaccine that was given with minimal toxicity to patients with translocation-positive metastatic or recurrent Ewing sarcoma (n = 37) and alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma (n = 15). Ten patients with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma had improved survival, compared with five patients who did not receive immunotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.200">

6797200</a>

6798][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6799Level of evidence C1</a>

6800] </li>

6801</ul>

6802</div>

6803</section>

6804<section id="_1871">

6805<h3 id="_1871_toc">

6806Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</h3>

6807<p id="_1873" tabindex="-1">

6808Information about NCI-supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

6809NCI website</a>

6810. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

6811ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

6812.</p>

6813<p id="_1874" tabindex="-1">

6814The following is an example of a national and/or institutional clinical trial that is currently being conducted:</p>

6815<div class="pdq-content-list">

6816<ul id="_1875">

6817<li>

6818<strong>

6819<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT05304585">

6820ARST2032 (NCT05304585)</a>

6821</strong>

6822 (Chemotherapy for the Treatment of Patients With Newly Diagnosed Very Low-Risk and Low-Risk, Fusion-Negative Rhabdomyosarcoma)<strong>

6823:</strong>

6824 The COG redefined low-risk rhabdomyosarcoma using both clinical and molecular criteria. The new criteria will be used in this study. Patients are required to enroll in the COG <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02402244">

6825APEC14B1</a>

6826 trial and the Molecular Characterization Initiative. Low-risk patients have both fusion-negative and wild-type <em class="gene-name">

6827MYOD1</em>

6828 and <em class="gene-name">

6829TP53</em>

6830. In this trial, very low-risk patients will receive 24 weeks of VA therapy, and low-risk patients will receive four cycles of VAC followed by VA for a total of 24 weeks.<table id="_2079" class="table-default expandable-container">

6831<caption>

6832Table <span class="sup">

6833</span>

6834 ARST2032 Risk Assignment for Low-Risk Patients</caption>

6835<colgroup>

6836<col width="16.66%">

6837<col width="16.66%">

6838<col width="16.66%">

6839<col width="16.66%">

6840<col width="16.66%">

6841<col width="16.66%">

6842</colgroup>

6843<THead>

6844<tr>

6845<th>

6846Subset</th>

6847<th>

6848Fusion status</th>

6849<th>

6850Tumor Site&#160;</th>

6851<th>

6852Tumor Size&#160;</th>

6853<th>

6854Surgical-pathological Group&#160;</th>

6855<th>

6856<em class="gene-name">

6857MYOD1</em>

6858 or <em class="gene-name">

6859TP53</em>

6860 Status</th>

6861</tr>

6862</THead>

6863<tbody>

6864<tr>

6865<td>

6866<strong>

6867Very Low Risk</strong>

6868</td>

6869<td>

6870Negative</td>

6871<td>

6872Favorable&#160;</td>

6873<td>

6874Any&#160;</td>

6875<td>

6876I</td>

6877<td>

6878Wild-type</td>

6879</tr>

6880<tr>

6881<td rowspan="3">

6882<strong>

6883Low Risk</strong>

6884</td>

6885<td rowspan="3">

6886Negative</td>

6887<td>

6888Favorable</td>

6889<td>

6891<td>

6892II</td>

6894Wild-type</td>

6895</tr>

6896<tr>

6897<td>

6898Unfavorable </td>

6899<td>

6900&gt;5 cm</td>

6901<td>

6902I, II</td>

6903</tr>

6904<tr>

6905<td>

6906Orbit </td>

6907<td>

6908Any</td>

6909<td>

6910III</td>

6911</tr>

6912</tbody>

6913</table>

6914</li>

6915</ul>

6916</div>

6917</section>

6918<section id="_TrialSearch_130_sid_6">

6919<h3 id="_TrialSearch_130_sid_6_toc">

6920Current Clinical Trials</h3>

6921<p id="_TrialSearch_130_22" tabindex="-1">

6922Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

6923advanced clinical trial search</a>

6924 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

6925General information</a>

6926 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

6927</section>

6962</li>

6965[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6966</li>

Cancer 127 (2): 275-283, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33079399&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33079399&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6969[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6970</li>

6971<li id="section_6.11">

6972Maurer HM, Beltangady M, Gehan EA, et al.: The Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study-I. A final report. Cancer 61 (2): 209-20, 1988.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3275486&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3275486&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6973[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6974</li>

6975<li id="section_6.12">

6976Wolden SL, Anderson JR, Crist WM, et al.: Indications for radiotherapy and chemotherapy after complete resection in rhabdomyosarcoma: A report from the Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Studies I to III. J Clin Oncol 17 (11): 3468-75, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10550144&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10550144&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6977[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6978</li>
