7738 <section id="_85">

7739

7740 <h2>

7741Treatment of Progressive or Recurrent Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</h2>

7742

7743 <div id="_section_85" class="pdq-sections">

7744<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

7745<h6>

7746In This Section</h6>

7747<ul>

7748<li>

7749<a href="#_875_toc">

7750Prognosis and Prognostic Factors</a>

7751</li>

7752<li>

7753<a href="#_876_toc">

7754Treatment Options for Progressive or Recurrent Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

7755</li>

7756<li>

7757<a href="#_1942_toc">

7758Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for Progressive or Recurrent Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

7759</li>

7760<li>

7761<a href="#_TrialSearch_85_sid_7_toc">

7762Current Clinical Trials</a>

7763</li>

7764</ul>

7765</nav>

7766<section id="_875">

7767<h3 id="_875_toc">

7768Prognosis and Prognostic Factors</h3>

7769<p id="_86" tabindex="-1">

7770Although patients with progressive or recurrent rhabdomyosarcoma sometimes

7771achieve complete remission with secondary therapy, the long-term prognosis

7772is usually poor.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

77731</a>

7774,<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

77752</a>

7776] Rhabdomyosarcoma may relapse locally or in the lung, bone, or bone marrow. Less commonly, the site of first recurrence can be the breast in adolescent females or the liver.[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

77773</a>

7778]</p>

7779<p id="_772" tabindex="-1">

7780The following studies reported on the prognostic factors associated with progressive or recurrent disease:</p>

7781<div class="pdq-content-list">

7782<ul id="_773">

7783<li>

7784 In a 1999 study of 605 children, the prognosis was most

7785favorable (5-year survival rates, 50%&#8211;70%) for children who initially

7786presented with Stage 1 or Group I disease and embryonal/botryoid histology with small tumors and for those with local or regional nodal recurrence. Patients with Group I alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma or undifferentiated sarcoma had 5-year overall survival (OS) rates of 40% to 50%. This population of patients with improved outcomes encompasses only 20% of all patients with a relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

77871</a>

7788][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7789Level of evidence C1</a>

7790]</li>

7791<li>

7792In a 2014 study of 24 children, 22 (82%) children with initially localized orbital sarcoma survived at least 5 years after relapse following re-treatment with curative intent.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

77934</a>

7794][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7795Level of evidence C1</a>

7796] </li>

7797<li>

7798A 2005 study of 125 patients with nonmetastatic rhabdomyosarcoma whose disease recurred after previous complete remission observed that favorable factors at initial diagnosis included: nonalveolar histology; primary site in the orbit, genitourinary/nonbladder-prostate, or head/neck nonparameningeal regions; tumor size of 5 cm or smaller; local relapse; relapse after 18 months from the primary diagnosis; and lack of initial radiation therapy (RT).[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

77992</a>

7800]</li>

7801<li>

7802A report of 337 patients with nonmetastatic rhabdomyosarcoma in 2008 observed that favorable factors at initial diagnosis were age 10 years or younger, embryonal histology, tumor size of 5 cm or smaller, favorable site, and lack of initial RT.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

78035</a>

7804]</li>

7805<li>

7806In a 2009 study of 234 patients who had a relapse after achieving complete remission and completing primary treatment, the favorable prognostic factors for 3-year OS were reported. These factors were favorable primary site, local relapse, time to relapse of more than 12 months, tumor size of 5 cm or smaller, and no previous RT.[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

78076</a>

7808][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7809Level of evidence C1</a>

7810]</li>

7811<li>

7812A 2011 study of 474 patients with nonmetastatic rhabdomyosarcoma who had complete local control at the primary site noted the unfavorable factors for survival 3 years after first relapse. These unfavorable factors included relapse with metastatic disease, previous (initial) RT, tumor size more than 5 cm, time to relapse of less than 18 months, regional lymph node involvement, alveolar histology, and unfavorable disease at primary diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

78137</a>

7814]</li>

7815<li>

7816In 2013, 90 patients with nonmetastatic alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma were re-treated with additional chemotherapy, with or without local re-excision of the primary site (if indicated) and with or without RT. The four most important factors for survival after relapse were no lymph node involvement, no metastases, adequate local therapy, and a second complete remission. The OS rate at 5 years was 21%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

78178</a>

7818][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7819Level of evidence C1</a>

7820]</li>

7821<li>

7822A single-institution, retrospective review identified 23 patients with central nervous system (CNS) relapse after initial treatment for rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

78239</a>

7824][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7825Level of evidence C1</a>

7826] High-risk features at initial presentation included 16 alveolar patients, 13 Stage 4 patients, and 13 patients with primary tumor in parameningeal locations. All of the patients died. Twenty-one patients died of CNS disease, and two died of metastatic disease at other sites. Median survival post-CNS relapse was 5 months (range, 0.1&#8211;49 months).</li>

7827</ul>

7828</div>

7829</section>

7830<section id="_876">

7831<h3 id="_876_toc">

7832Treatment Options for Progressive or Recurrent Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</h3>

7833<p id="_877" tabindex="-1">

7834The selection of

7835additional treatment depends on many factors, including the site(s) of progression or recurrence,

7836previous treatment, and individual patient considerations. </p>

7837<p id="_878" tabindex="-1">

7838Treatment options for progressive or recurrent childhood rhabdomyosarcoma include the following:</p>

7839<div class="pdq-content-list">

7840<ol id="_888">

7841<li>

7842<strong>

7843Surgery.</strong>

7844 Treatment for local or regional recurrence may include wide local excision or aggressive surgical removal of tumor, particularly in the absence of widespread bony metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

784510</a>

7846,<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

784711</a>

7848] Some survivors have also been reported after surgical removal of only one or a few metastases in the lung.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

784910</a>

7850] A review examined 108 Italian children with bladder or prostate tumors who did not achieve tumor eradication after chemotherapy, with or without RT. The study found that only two factors correlated with inability to achieve progression-free survival (PFS) at 5 or more years: initial histology showing undifferentiated sarcoma (<em>

7851P</em>

7852 = .008) and diameter of the surgically removed tumor exceeding 5 cm. Positive tumor margins at the salvage operation did not predict ultimate failure.[<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

785312</a>

7854][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7855Level of evidence C2</a>

7856]</li>

7857<li>

7858<strong>

7859RT.</strong>

7860 RT should be considered for patients with rhabdomyosarcoma who have not already received RT in the area of recurrence, or selectively for those who have received previous RT, particularly for those in whom surgical excision is not possible. RT techniques may include external beam in fractionated or hypofractionated courses (e.g., stereotactic body radiation therapy, CyberKnife, or brachytherapy). The rationale is primarily to improve local control that can translate into a better quality of life. An impact on OS is unlikely because of the metastatic disease that often occurs. Even a benefit on local control is difficult to unequivocally demonstrate because of small patient numbers in available reports. For example, in a multi-institutional study of 23 patients with local relapse only (n = 19) or local relapse with distant failure (n = 4) who were managed with (n = 12) or without (n = 11) re-irradiation, the local failure-free survival and OS in re-irradiated versus unirradiated patients was 19.6 months versus 12.4 months (<em>

7861P</em>

7862 = .1) and 26.1 months versus 18.8 months (<em>

7863P</em>

7864 = .46). In this report, patients with favorable site and Group 3 disease local (only) failure, and/or embryonal histology had improved 3-year local relapse-free survival rates with re-irradiation (62.3% vs. 40%; <em>

7865P</em>

7866 = .11).[<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

786713</a>

7868]</li>

7869<li>

7870<strong>

7871Chemotherapy.</strong>

7872 A German study found that treatment with multiagent chemotherapy incorporating carboplatin and etoposide, plus RT, was efficacious for patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (5-year event-free survival [EFS] rate, 41%), but it was less effective for patients with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma (5-year EFS rate, 25%).[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

787314</a>

7874] Previously unused, active, single agents or combinations of drugs may also enhance the likelihood of disease control.</li>

7875</ol>

7876</div>

7877</section>

7878<p id="_248" tabindex="-1">

7879The following chemotherapy regimens have been used to treat progressive or recurrent rhabdomyosarcoma: </p>

7880<div class="pdq-content-list">

7881<ol id="_880">

7882<li>

7883Carboplatin and etoposide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

788414</a>

7885]</li>

7886<li>

7887Ifosfamide, carboplatin, and etoposide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.15">

788815</a>

7889,<a href="#cit/section_7.16">

789016</a>

7891]</li>

7892<li>

7893Cyclophosphamide and topotecan.[<a href="#cit/section_7.17">

789417</a>

7895]</li>

7896<li>

7897Topotecan, carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, and etoposide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

789818</a>

7899]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7900<ol id="_1949" class="lower-alpha">

7901<li>

7902In a 2018 Italian study, 38 patients with recurrent or refractory rhabdomyosarcoma were treated with topotecan, carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, and etoposide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

790318</a>

7904][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7905Level of evidence C1</a>

7906]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7907<ul id="_1950">

7908<li>

7909Nine of 32 patients had a complete or partial response. However, the 5-year OS rate was 17%, and the PFS rate was 14%.</li>

7910</ul>

7911</div>

7912</li>

7913</ol>

7914</div>

7915</li>

7916<li>

7917Single-agent vinorelbine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

791819</a>

7919,<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

792020</a>

7921] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7922<ul id="_882">

7923<li>

7924In one phase II trial, 4 of 11 patients with recurrent rhabdomyosarcoma responded to single-agent vinorelbine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

792519</a>

7926]</li>

7927<li>

7928In another trial, 6 of 12 young patients (aged 9&#8211;29 years) had a partial response.[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

792920</a>

7930]</li>

7931</ul>

7932</div>

7933</li>

7934<li>

7935Vinorelbine and cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

793621</a>

7937,<a href="#cit/section_7.22">

793822</a>

7939] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7940<ol id="_1951" class="lower-alpha">

7941<li>

7942In a pilot study, three of nine patients with rhabdomyosarcoma had an objective response.[<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

794321</a>

7944]</li>

7945<li>

7946In a phase II study in France (N = 50), children with recurrent or refractory rhabdomyosarcoma were treated with vinorelbine and low-dose oral cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.22">

794722</a>

7948][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7949Level of evidence C3</a>

7950]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7951<ul id="_1952">

7952<li>

7953Four complete responses and 14 partial responses were observed, for an objective response rate of 36%.</li>

7954</ul>

7955</div>

7956</li>

7957</ol>

7958</div>

7959</li>

7960<li>

7961Gemcitabine and docetaxel.[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

796223</a>

7963] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7964<ul id="_884">

7965<li>

7966In a single-institution trial, two patients (N = 5) with recurrent rhabdomyosarcoma achieved an objective response.[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

796723</a>

7968]</li>

7969</ul>

7970</div>

7971</li>

7972<li>

7973Sirolimus.[<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

797424</a>

7975]</li>

7976<li>

7977Topotecan, vincristine, and doxorubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

797825</a>

7979][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7980Level of evidence C3</a>

7981]</li>

7982<li>

7983Vincristine, irinotecan, and temozolomide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.26">

798426</a>

7985-<a href="#cit/section_7.28">

798628</a>

7987] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7988<ol id="_1953" class="lower-alpha">

7989<li>

7990One of four patients with recurrent alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma had a complete radiographic response sustained for 27 weeks with no grade 3 or 4 toxicities.[<a href="#cit/section_7.26">

799126</a>

7992]; [<a href="#cit/section_7.27">

799327</a>

7994][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7995Level of evidence C2</a>

7996]</li>

7997<li>

7998A group of 15 patients with relapsed rhabdomyosarcoma were treated with vincristine, irinotecan, and temozolomide. Many of the patients had received previous relapse therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.28">

799928</a>

8000][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8001Level of evidence C1</a>

8002]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8003<ul id="_1954">

8004<li>

8005There were no complete or partial remissions; four patients had stable disease, and 11 patients had progressive disease.</li>

8006</ul>

8007</div>

8008</li>

8009</ol>

8010</div>

8011</li>

8012<li>

8013Vincristine, irinotecan, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, etoposide, ifosfamide, and tirapazamine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.29">

801429</a>

8015]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8016<ol id="_1955" class="lower-alpha">

8017<li>

8018In 2019, the Children's Oncology Group (COG) reported three trials of patients with recurrent or refractory rhabdomyosarcoma with specific criteria for eligibility. Unfavorable-risk patients with measurable disease could undergo a 6-week phase II window study of vincristine and irinotecan (VI). Patients with at least a partial response then received 44 weeks of assigned chemotherapy. Unfavorable-risk patients without measurable disease, no radiographic response, or refusal to go on window therapy received 31 weeks of multiagent chemotherapy plus tirapazamine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.29">

801929</a>

8020][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8021Level of evidence C1</a>

8022]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8023<ul id="_1956">

8024<li>

8025Favorable-risk patients had a 3-year failure-free survival (FFS) rate of 79% and an OS rate of 84%.</li>

8026<li>

8027Thirty patients with unfavorable-risk disease who were not treated with VI had a 3-year FFS rate of 21% and an OS rate of 39%.</li>

8028</ul>

8029</div>

8030</li>

8031</ol>

8032</div>

8033</li>

8034<li>

8035Irinotecan with or without vincristine and with or without temozolomide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.30">

803630</a>

8037-<a href="#cit/section_7.35">

803835</a>

8039] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8040<ol id="_1957" class="lower-alpha">

8041<li>

8042A COG prospective, randomized, up-front window trial, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00025363">

8043COG-ARST0121</a>

8044, compared VI (20 mg/m<span class="sup">

80452</span>

8046/d) daily &#215; 5 days for 4 weeks per 6-week treatment cycle (Regimen 1A) and irinotecan (50 mg/m<span class="sup">

80472</span>

8048/d) daily &#215; 5 days for 2 weeks per 6-week treatment cycle (Regimen 1B) in poor-risk patients with relapsed or progressive rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_7.34">

804934</a>

8050][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8051Level of evidence A1</a>

8052] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8053<ul id="_1958">

8054<li>

8055At 1 year after initiation of treatment for recurrence, the FFS rate was 37% and the OS rate was 55% for Regimen 1A.</li>

8056<li>

8057At 1 year after initiation of treatment for recurrence, the FFS rate was 38% and OS rate was 60% for Regimen 1B.</li>

8058<li>

8059The Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee of the COG recommended the more convenient Regimen 1B for further investigation.</li>

8060</ul>

8061</div>

8062</li>

8063<li>

8064In a European Soft Tissue Sarcoma Study Group study, 120 patients with recurrent or refractory rhabdomyosarcoma were randomly assigned to receive either VI or vincristine, irinotecan, and temozolomide (VIT).[<a href="#cit/section_7.36">

806536</a>

8066][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8067Level of evidence A1</a>

8068]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8069<ul id="_1959">

8070<li>

8071The objective response rate was 44% (24 of 55 evaluable patients) for patients who received VIT, compared with 31% (18 of 58) for patients who received VI. </li>

8072<li>

8073The patients in the VIT arm achieved significantly better OS (adjusted hazard ratio [HR], 0.55; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.35&#8211;0.84; <em>

8074P</em>

8075 = .006), than patients on the VI arm, with consistent PFS results (adjusted HR, 0.68; 95% CI, 0.46&#8211;1.01; <em>

8076P</em>

8077 = .059). </li>

8078<li>

8079Overall, patients experienced grade 3 or greater adverse events more frequently with VIT than VI (98% vs. 78%, respectively; <em>

8080P</em>

8081 = .009), including a significant excess of hematological toxicity (81% vs. 61%; <em>

8082P</em>

8083 = .025).</li>

8084</ul>

8085</div>

8086</li>

8087</ol>

8088</div>

8089</li>

8090<li>

8091Temsirolimus, irinotecan, and temozolomide.[<a href="#cit/section_7.37">

809237</a>

8093] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8094<ol id="_1960" class="lower-alpha">

8095<li>

8096In a phase I trial of these agents, four patients had rhabdomyosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_7.37">

809737</a>

8098]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8099<ul id="_1961">

8100<li>

8101The regimen was well tolerated.</li>

8102<li>

8103One patient had a partial response, and another patient had stable disease.</li>

8104</ul>

8105</div>

8106</li>

8107</ol>

8108</div>

8109</li>

8110<li>

8111Temsirolimus, cyclophosphamide, and vinorelbine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.38">

811238</a>

8113] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8114<ol id="_1962" class="lower-alpha">

8115<li>

8116A COG randomized, phase II, selection-design study of patients with relapsed rhabdomyosarcoma compared bevacizumab with temsirolimus, both administered with cyclophosphamide and vinorelbine.[<a href="#cit/section_7.39">

811739</a>

8118][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8119Level of evidence C2</a>

8120]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8121<ul id="_1963">

8122<li>

8123Patients on the temsirolimus arm had improved EFS (<em>

8124P</em>

8125 = .003). The 6-month and 12-month EFS rates in the temsirolimus arm were 65% (95% CI, 44%&#8211;79%) and 40.5% (95% CI, 25.6%&#8211;55.3%), respectively, compared with 50% (95% CI, 32%&#8211;66%) and 18.2% (95% CI, 6.8%&#8211;29.6%) in the bevacizumab arm.</li>

8126<li>

8127The complete response rate (complete remission plus partial remission) was higher on the temsirolimus arm (47%) than on the bevacizumab arm (28%). The difference was not statistically significant at the 0.05 level (<em>

8128P</em>

8129 = .12).</li>

8130<li>

8131These results are the basis for the subsequent COG trial randomizing the use of temsirolimus for newly diagnosed patients with nonmetastatic rhabdomyosarcoma (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02567435">

8132ARST1431 [NCT02567435]</a>

8133).</li>

8134</ul>

8135</div>

8136</li>

8137</ol>

8138</div>

8139</li>

8140</ol>

8141</div>

8142<p id="_1821" tabindex="-1">

8143Very intensive chemotherapy followed by autologous bone marrow reinfusion is also under investigation for patients with recurrent rhabdomyosarcoma. However, a review of the published data did not determine a significant benefit for patients who underwent this salvage treatment approach.[<a href="#cit/section_7.40">

814440</a>

8145-<a href="#cit/section_7.42">

814642</a>

8147]</p>

8148<p id="_1850" tabindex="-1">

8149Patients or families who desire additional disease-directed therapy should consider entering trials of novel therapeutic approaches because no standard agents have demonstrated clinically significant activity.</p>

8150<p id="_1851" tabindex="-1">

8151Regardless of whether a decision is made to pursue disease-directed therapy at the time of progression, palliative care remains a central focus of management. This ensures that quality of life is maximized while attempting to reduce symptoms and stress related to the terminal illness.</p>

8152<section id="_1942">

8153<h3 id="_1942_toc">

8154Treatment Options Under Clinical Evaluation for Progressive or Recurrent Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</h3>

8155</section>

8156<p id="_1943" tabindex="-1">

8157Information about National Cancer Institute (NCI)&#8211;supported clinical trials can be found on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search">

8158NCI website</a>

8159. For information about clinical trials sponsored by other organizations, see the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/">

8160ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

8161.</p>

8162<p id="_1944" tabindex="-1">

8163The following are examples of national and/or institutional clinical trials that are currently being conducted:</p>

8164<div class="pdq-content-list">

8165<ul id="_1945">

8166<li>

8167<strong>

8168<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02332668">

8169ADVL1621 (NCT02332668)</a>

8170</strong>

8171 (A Study of Pembrolizumab [MK-3475] in Pediatric Participants With Advanced Melanoma or Advanced, Relapsed, or Refractory PD-L1-Positive Solid Tumors or Lymphoma [MK-3475-051/KEYNOTE-051])<strong>

8172:</strong>

8173 This is a two-part study of pembrolizumab in pediatric participants who have either advanced melanoma or a programmed cell death ligand 1&#8211;positive advanced, relapsed, or refractory solid tumor or lymphoma. Part 1 will find the maximum tolerated dose/maximum administered dose, confirm the dose, and find the recommended phase II dose for pembrolizumab therapy. Part 2 will further evaluate the safety and efficacy at the pediatric recommended phase II dose.</li>

8174<li>

8175<strong>

8176<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03709680">

8177ADVL1921 (NCT03709680)</a>

8178</strong>

8179 (Study of Palbociclib Combined With Chemotherapy In Pediatric Patients With Recurrent/Refractory Solid Tumors)<strong>

8180:</strong>

8181 This study will evaluate palbociclib in combination with chemotherapy (temozolomide and irinotecan) in children, adolescents, and young adults with recurrent or refractory solid tumors. The main purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety of palbociclib in combination with chemotherapy to estimate the maximum tolerated dose. Pharmacokinetics and efficacy of palbociclib in combination with chemotherapy will be evaluated.</li>

8182<li>

8183<strong>

8184<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03155620">

8185APEC1621 (NCT03155620)</a>

8186</strong>

8187 (Pediatric MATCH: Targeted Therapy Directed by Genetic Testing in Treating Pediatric Patients with Relapsed or Refractory Advanced Solid Tumors, Non-Hodgkin Lymphomas, or Histiocytic Disorders)<strong>

8188:</strong>

8189 NCI-COG Pediatric Molecular Analysis for Therapeutic Choice (MATCH), referred to as Pediatric MATCH, will match targeted agents with specific molecular changes identified in a patient's tumor (refractory or recurrent). Children and adolescents aged 1 to 21 years are eligible for the trial.<p id="_1807" tabindex="-1">

8190Patients with tumors that have molecular variants addressed by open treatment arms in the trial may be enrolled in treatment on Pediatric MATCH. Additional information can be obtained on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/nci-supported/pediatric-match">

8191NCI website</a>

8192 and <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03155620">

8193ClinicalTrials.gov website</a>

8194.</p>

8195

8196</li>

8197<li>

8198New agents under

8199clinical evaluation in phase I and phase II trials should be considered for

8200relapsed patients.</li>

8201</ul>

8202</div>

8203<section id="_TrialSearch_85_sid_7">

8204<h3 id="_TrialSearch_85_sid_7_toc">

8205Current Clinical Trials</h3>

8206<p id="_TrialSearch_85_22" tabindex="-1">

8207Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

8208advanced clinical trial search</a>

8209 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

8210General information</a>

8211 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

8212</section>

8360<li id="section_7.37">

8361Bagatell R, Norris R, Ingle AM, et al.: Phase 1 trial of temsirolimus in combination with irinotecan and temozolomide in children, adolescents and young adults with relapsed or refractory solid tumors: a Children's Oncology Group Study. Pediatr Blood Cancer 61 (5): 833-9, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24249672&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24249672&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8362[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8363</li>

8364<li id="section_7.38">

8365Mascarenhas L, Meyer WH, Lyden E, et al.: Randomized phase II trial of bevacizumab and temsirolimus in combination with vinorelbine (V) and cyclophosphamide (C) for first relapse/disease progression of rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS): a report from the Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG). [Abstract] J Clin Oncol 32 (Suppl 5): A-10003, 2014. <a href="https://ascopubs.org/doi/abs/10.1200/jco.2014.32.15_suppl.10003" title="https://ascopubs.org/doi/abs/10.1200/jco.2014.32.15_suppl.10003">

8366Also available online</a>

8367. Last accessed June 13, 2022.</li>

8368<li id="section_7.39">

8369Mascarenhas L, Chi YY, Hingorani P, et al.: Randomized Phase II Trial of Bevacizumab or Temsirolimus in Combination With Chemotherapy for First Relapse Rhabdomyosarcoma: A Report From the Children's Oncology Group. J Clin Oncol 37 (31): 2866-2874, 2019.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31513481&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31513481&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8370[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8371</li>

8372<li id="section_7.40">

8373Weigel BJ, Breitfeld PP, Hawkins D, et al.: Role of high-dose chemotherapy with hematopoietic stem cell rescue in the treatment of metastatic or recurrent rhabdomyosarcoma. J Pediatr Hematol Oncol 23 (5): 272-6, 2001 Jun-Jul.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11464981&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11464981&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8374[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8375</li>

8376<li id="section_7.41">

8377Admiraal R, van der Paardt M, Kobes J, et al.: High-dose chemotherapy for children and young adults with stage IV rhabdomyosarcoma. Cochrane Database Syst Rev (12): CD006669, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21154373&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21154373&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8378[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8379</li>

8380<li id="section_7.42">

8381Peinemann F, Kr&#246;ger N, Bartel C, et al.: High-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation for metastatic rhabdomyosarcoma--a systematic review. PLoS One 6 (2): e17127, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21373200&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21373200&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8382[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8383</li>

8384</ol>

8385</div>

8386

8387 </section>

8388

8389

8390

8391 <section id="_148">

8392

8393 <h2>

8394Changes to This Summary (01/10/2023)</h2>

8395

8396 <div id="_section_148" class="pdq-sections">

8397<p id="_154" tabindex="-1">

8398The PDQ cancer information summaries are reviewed regularly and updated as

8399new information becomes available. This section describes the latest

8400changes made to this summary as of the date above.</p>

8401<p id="_2100" tabindex="-1">

8402<strong>

8403<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1">

8404General Information About Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

8405</strong>

8406</p>

8407<p id="_2102" tabindex="-1">

8408Revised <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_170">

8409text</a>

8410 to state that between 1975 and 2020, childhood cancer mortality decreased by more than 50%. Between 1975 and 2017, the 5-year relative survival rate for patients with rhabdomyosarcoma increased from 53% to 71% for children younger than 15 years and from 30% to 52% for adolescents aged 15 to 19 years (cited National Cancer Institute as reference 2 and Surveillance Research Program, National Cancer Institute as reference 3).</p>

8411<p id="_2115" tabindex="-1">

8412Revised <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_584">

8413text</a>

8414 to state that childhood rhabdomyosarcoma accounts for approximately 2.7% of cancer cases among children aged 0 to 14 years and 1.4% of the cases among adolescents and young adults aged 15 to 19 years. The incidence is 4.6 cases per 1 million children younger than 20 years, which translates into about 350 new cases per year.</p>

8415<p id="_2103" tabindex="-1">

8416Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_1881">

8417circulating tumor DNA and RNA</a>

8418 as a prognostic factor for children or adolescents with rhabdomyosarcoma.</p>

8419<p id="_2104" tabindex="-1">

8420Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_2096">

8421text</a>

8422 about an international consortium study that identified 40 infants with spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma and reported that infants with congenital spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma have a favorable outcome compared with infants with other subtypes of rhabdomyosarcoma (cited Whittle et al. as reference 41).</p>

8423<p id="_2116" tabindex="-1">

8424Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_2092">

8425text</a>

8426 about the results of a study that compared outcomes of adolescents and young adults with those of children with rhabdomyosarcoma (cited Ferrari et al. as reference 44).</p>

8427<p id="_2105" tabindex="-1">

8428Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_2091">

8429text</a>

8430 about the results of an European Paediatric Soft Tissue Sarcoma Study Group (EpSSG) retrospective analysis of 109 patients with rhabdomyosarcoma with extremity primary tumors distal to the elbow or knee who were treated in the EpSSG RMS 2005 trial, which concluded that popliteal and epitrochlear nodes should be considered as true (distal) regional nodes, instead of in-transit metastases (cited Terwisscha van Scheltinga et al. as reference 87).</p>

8431<p id="_2106" tabindex="-1">

8432Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_2093">

8433text</a>

8434 about the results of an EpSSG retrospective analysis of 1,294 children with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma enrolled in the EpSSG RMS 2005 protocol, which concluded that regional nodal involvement is an independent prognostic factor in patients with embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma; therefore, it is appropriate to include this population in the high-risk category (cited Ben-Arush et al. as reference 88).</p>

8435<p id="_2107" tabindex="-1">

8436Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_2098">

8437Circulating tumor DNA and RNA</a>

8438 as a new subsection.</p>

8439<p id="_2119" tabindex="-1">

8440<strong>

8441<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_13">

8442Cellular Classification for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

8443</strong>

8444</p>

8445<p id="_2120" tabindex="-1">

8446Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_638">

8447text</a>

8448 to state that one study analyzed the clinical and mutational spectrum of 24 pediatric fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma tumors with high levels of myogenic differentiation. The analysis revealed that most tumors arose in the head and neck or genitourinary region. The overall survival rate was 100% for these patients (cited Teot et al. as reference 7).</p>

8449<p id="_2117" tabindex="-1">

8450<strong>

8451<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_128">

8452Stage Information for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

8453</strong>

8454</p>

8455<p id="_2118" tabindex="-1">

8456Revised <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_257">

8457Table 5</a>

8458 to update the incidence of each disease Group.</p>

8459<p id="_2108" tabindex="-1">

8460<strong>

8461<a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_130">

8462Treatment of Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

8463</strong>

8464</p>

8465<p id="_2109" tabindex="-1">

8466Revised <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_598">

8467text</a>

8468 to state that the overall survival was superior in patients treated with radical radiation therapy (RT) than partial RT; however, it should be noted that some component of the difference in survival likely relates to the patients selected to receive radical versus partial RT rather than the type of RT administered.</p>

8469<p id="_2110" tabindex="-1">

8470Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_2064">

8471text</a>

8472 to state that recommendations for paratesticular primary tumors are primarily based on the results from cooperative group trials and a recent International Soft Tissue Sarcoma Consortium consensus opinion.</p>

8473<p id="_2111" tabindex="-1">

8474Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_2099">

8475Unknown primary sites</a>

8476 as a new subsection.</p>

8477<p id="_2112" tabindex="-1">

8478Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_2071">

8479text</a>

8480 about the results of a

8481Children's Oncology Group and European investigation of patients with rhabdomyosarcoma who had definitive surgery of the primary tumor before the initiation of systemic chemotherapy, which concluded that vincristine and dactinomycin for 24 weeks may be considered in children with tumors smaller than 5 cm (cited Bisogno et al. as reference 169).</p>

8482<p id="_2113" tabindex="-1">

8483Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_856">

8484text</a>

8485 about the results of a Cooperative Weichteilsarkom Studiengruppe (CWS) phase III trial of high-risk nonmetastatic rhabdomyosarcoma and Ewing sarcoma patients who were recruited between 1995 to 2004 from the CWS and Italian Soft Tissue Sarcoma Committee institutions (cited Sparber-Sauer et al. as reference 183).</p>

8486<p id="_2114" tabindex="-1">

8487Added <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_868">

8488text</a>

8489 about the results of a European multinational collaboration that investigated an intensive induction regimen followed by 1 year of maintenance therapy for patients with high-risk rhabdomyosarcoma who were aged 21 years or younger (cited Schoot et al. as reference 196).</p>

8490<p id="_disclaimerHP_3" tabindex="-1">

8491This summary is written and maintained by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

8492PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

8493, which is

8494editorially independent of NCI. The summary reflects an independent review of

8495the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or NIH. More

8496information about summary policies and the role of the PDQ Editorial Boards in

8497maintaining the PDQ summaries can be found on the <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq#_AboutThis_1">

8498About This PDQ Summary</a>

8499 and <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq">

8500PDQ&#174; Cancer Information for Health Professionals</a>

8501 pages.

8502</p>

8503</div>

8504

8505 </section>

8506

8507

8508

8509 <section id="_AboutThis_1">

8510

8511 <h2>

8512About This PDQ Summary</h2>

8513

8514 <div id="_section_AboutThis_1" class="pdq-sections">

8515<section id="_AboutThis_2">

8516<h3 id="_AboutThis_2_toc">

8517Purpose of This Summary</h3>

8518<p id="_AboutThis_3" tabindex="-1">

8519This PDQ cancer information summary for health professionals provides comprehensive, peer-reviewed, evidence-based information about the treatment of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma. It is intended as a resource to inform and assist clinicians in the care of their patients. It does not provide formal guidelines or recommendations for making health care decisions.</p>

8520</section>

8521<section id="_AboutThis_4">

8522<h3 id="_AboutThis_4_toc">

8523Reviewers and Updates</h3>

8524<p id="_AboutThis_5" tabindex="-1">

8525This summary is reviewed regularly and updated as necessary by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

8526PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

8527, which is editorially independent of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The summary reflects an independent review of the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or the National Institutes of Health (NIH).</p>

8528<p id="_AboutThis_22" tabindex="-1">

8529 Board members review recently published articles each month to determine whether an article should:</p>

8530<div class="pdq-content-list">

8531<ul id="_AboutThis_6">

8532<li>

8533be discussed at a meeting,</li>

8534<li>

8535be cited with text, or</li>

8536<li>

8537replace or update an existing article that is already cited.</li>

8538</ul>

8539</div>

8540<p id="_AboutThis_7" tabindex="-1">

8541Changes to the summaries are made through a consensus process in which Board members evaluate the strength of the evidence in the published articles and determine how the article should be included in the summary.</p>

8542<p id="" tabindex="-1">

8543The lead reviewers for Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma Treatment are:</p>

8544<div class="pdq-content-list">

8545<ul id="">

8546<li>

8547Louis S. Constine, MD (James P. Wilmot Cancer Center at University of Rochester Medical Center)</li>

8548<li>

8549Holcombe Edwin Grier, MD</li>

8550<li>

8551Andrea A. Hayes-Dixon, MD, FACS, FAAP (Howard University)</li>

8552<li>

8553William H. Meyer, MD</li>

8554<li>

8555Paul A. Meyers, MD (Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center)</li>

8556<li>

8557Alberto S. Pappo, MD (St. Jude Children's Research Hospital)</li>

8558<li>

8559Stephen J. Shochat, MD (St. Jude Children's Research Hospital)</li>

8560<li>

8561Malcolm A. Smith, MD, PhD (National Cancer Institute)</li>

8562</ul>

8563</div>

8564<p id="_AboutThis_9" tabindex="-1">

8565Any comments or questions about the summary content should be submitted to Cancer.gov through the NCI website's <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

8566Email Us</a>

8567. Do not contact the individual Board Members with questions or comments about the summaries. Board members will not respond to individual inquiries.</p>

8568</section>

8569<section id="_AboutThis_10">

8570<h3 id="_AboutThis_10_toc">

8571Levels of Evidence</h3>

8572<p id="_AboutThis_11" tabindex="-1">

8573Some of the reference citations in this summary are accompanied by a level-of-evidence designation. These designations are intended to help readers assess the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches. The PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board uses a <a href="/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/treatment">

8574formal evidence ranking system</a>

8575 in developing its level-of-evidence designations.</p>

8576</section>

8577<section id="_AboutThis_12">

8578<h3 id="_AboutThis_12_toc">

8579Permission to Use This Summary</h3>

8580<p id="_AboutThis_13" tabindex="-1">

8581PDQ is a registered trademark. Although the content of PDQ documents can be used freely as text, it cannot be identified as an NCI PDQ cancer information summary unless it is presented in its entirety and is regularly updated. However, an author would be permitted to write a sentence such as &#8220;NCI&#8217;s PDQ cancer information summary about breast cancer prevention states the risks succinctly: [include excerpt from the summary].&#8221;</p>

8582<p id="_AboutThis_14" tabindex="-1">

8583The preferred citation for this PDQ summary is:</p>

8584<p id="_AboutThis_15" tabindex="-1">

8585PDQ&#174; Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board. PDQ Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma Treatment. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Updated &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. Available at: <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq">

8586https://www.cancer.gov/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq</a>

8587. Accessed &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. [PMID: 26389243]</p>

8588<p id="_AboutThis_16" tabindex="-1">

8589Images in this summary are used with permission of the author(s), artist, and/or publisher for use within the PDQ summaries only. Permission to use images outside the context of PDQ information must be obtained from the owner(s) and cannot be granted by the National Cancer Institute. Information about using the illustrations in this summary, along with many other cancer-related images, is available in <a href="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/" title="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/">

8590Visuals Online</a>

8591, a collection of over 2,000 scientific images.

8592

8593</p>

8594</section>

8595<section id="_AboutThis_17">

8596<h3 id="_AboutThis_17_toc">

8597Disclaimer</h3>

8598<p id="_AboutThis_18" tabindex="-1">

8599Based on the strength of the available evidence, treatment options may be described as either &#8220;standard&#8221; or &#8220;under clinical evaluation.&#8221; These classifications should not be used as a basis for insurance reimbursement determinations. More information on insurance coverage is available on Cancer.gov on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care">

8600Managing Cancer Care</a>

8601 page.</p>

8602</section>

8603<section id="_AboutThis_20">

8604<h3 id="_AboutThis_20_toc">

8605Contact Us</h3>

8606<p id="_AboutThis_21" tabindex="-1">

8607More information about contacting us or receiving help with the Cancer.gov website can be found on our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact">

8608Contact Us for Help</a>

8609 page. Questions can also be submitted to Cancer.gov through the website&#8217;s <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

8610Email Us</a>

8611.</p>

8612</section>

8792 <div class="mobile-lg:grid-col-6 desktop:grid-col-4">
